Common.Name: Puerto Rican Ground Sloth
Mass.Reference: Turvey and Fritz 2011 Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society B
Diet.Method: Functional craniodental morphology; Proxy dental wear (microwear)
Diet.Notes: Microwear suggests a frugivorous/folivorous lifestyle, probably also semi-arboeal (as suggested by craniodental morphology)
Diet.Reference: Pujos et al. 2012 Journal of Mammalian Evolution; Resar et al. 2013 Kirtlandia
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Smith et al. 2010 Nature Geoscience lists sloths as hindgut fermenters, because of their body size. However, all extant sloth species are foregut fermenters (Clauss 2004 Mammal Review). Fermentation type is a conservative trait, and extant two-toed and three-toed sloth species are more closely related to various of the now-extinct ground sloths than they are to each other (Pujos et al. 2012 Journal of Mammalian Evolution; Presslee et al. 2019 Nature Ecology and Evolution). Foregut fermentation is either the ancestral fermentation type of all sloth species, or it evolved at least twice in distinct (extant) sloth lineages. The most parsimonious fermentation type for extinct sloths would thus be foregut fermentation. However, Megatheriids pose a biological anamoly as there are no foregut fermentation species known at those body sizes (largest known was Sivatherium, a giraffid at 1250 kg). Vizcaino et al. 2006 and Clauss et al. 2003 suggests therefore that the extremely large Megatheriid sloths (Genera Megatherium and Eremotherium) may have been hindgut fermenters. As is, without better evidence, we will consider all sloths outliers in the ilk of Sivatherium and classify them as foregut fermenters until better evidence is available.
Fermentation.Type.Reference: McDonald and Pelikan 2006 Quaternary International; Clauss 2004 Mammal Review; Pujos et al. 2012 Journal of Mammalian Evolution; Presslee et al. 2019 Nature Ecology and Evolution; Vizcaino et al. 2006 Ameghiniana; Clauss et al. 2003 Oecologia
Limb.Morphology.Notes: Most taxa had the capacity, given their wide structural vertebral, to forage upright, resting on their tail. Appendicular morphology, particularly of the humerus, of all sloth families, other than the Mylodontidae, suggest a generalized locomotion habit (de Oliveira and Santos 2008).
Limb.Morphology.Reference: Naish 2012 Tetrapod Zoology; de Oliveira and Santos 2018 Journal of Morphology
Habitat.Notes: Functional morphology suggests a semi-arboreal habit.
Habitat.Reference: Grass 2014 Thesis; White 1993 Journal of Vertebrate Paleontology

Mass.Reference: Turvey and Fritz 2011 Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society B
Diet.Notes: Pujos et al. 2012 uses the width of mandibular symphysis relative to mandibular length to argue that this genus were browsers. No empirical, proxy evidence found per species. Resar 2012 analyzed microwear of an unidentified member of genus and suggested a folivorous/frugivorous diet.
Diet.Reference: Pujos et al. 2012 Journal of Mammalian Evolution; Resar 2012 Thesis
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Smith et al. 2010 Nature Geoscience lists sloths as hindgut fermenters, because of their body size. However, all extant sloth species are foregut fermenters (Clauss 2004 Mammal Review). Appendicular morphology, particularly of the humerus, of all sloth families, other than the Mylodontidae, suggest a generalized locomotion habit (de Oliveira and Santos 2008).
Limb.Morphology.Reference: Naish 2012 Tetrapod Zoology; de Oliveira and Santos 2018 Journal of Morphology
Habitat.Notes: Functional morphology suggests a semi-arboreal habit.
Habitat.Reference: Pujos et al. 2012 Journal of Mammalian Evolution

Common.Name: Addax
Diet.Notes: Grazer of harsh deserts, subsisting on desert grasses. Will consume forbs and shrubs during drought, and relishes on bitter melon for water content. Can survive years without drinking water, if forage is of sufficient quality.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Hummel et al. 2008 Comparative Biochemistry and Physiology; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: An extreme desert species that prefers open, flat topographies with sturdy soil substraes. During summer will move into areas with trees for shade, which appears to be a key habitat constraint.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa

Common.Name: Impala
Diet.Notes: Classic mixed feeding diet of grasses and shrubs
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Kartzinel et al 2015 Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: A water-dependent species of open woodland and savannas. No evidence that this species, or any relative, substantially uses arboreal or aquatic habitats
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa

Common.Name: Hildebrandt's Elephant Bird
Mass.Reference: Hansford and Turvey 2018 Royal Society Open Science
Diet.Notes: Isotopes indicate a browsing diet of C3 and possible CAM vegetation. This family was likely nocturnal, based on reconstruction of optical lobe (Torres et al. 2018).
Diet.Reference: Clarke et al. 2006 Quaternary Science Reviews; Tovondrafale et al. 2014 Malagasy Nature; Torres et al. 2018 Proceedings of the Royal Society B
Fermentation.Type.Method: Inferred from Infraclass; Inferred from diet
Fermentation.Type.Notes: No empirical evidence nor expert opinions regarding the fermentation type of these massive birds. Their nearest, albeit very distant, relative are kiwis in New Zealand (Mitchell et al. 2014), who are insectivores. Given their massive size, and the evolution of colon-based fermentation among other large-bodied ratites (rheas and ostriches), we are going to infer hindgut colon digestion. However, note that emus and cassuaries have only simple guts. It should be noted that all ratites lack crops (Sales 2006).
Fermentation.Type.Reference: Sales 2006 Avian and Poultry Biology Reviews; Mitchell et al. 2014 Science
Limb.Morphology.Notes: Other than the miharung, which was unguligrade, and loons and grebes, which are plantigrade, all other birds are digitigrade.
Habitat.Notes: No evidence found that elephant birds significantly used aquatic habitats. Given their body size they were certainly not arboreal.

Common.Name: Giant Elephant Bird
Mass.Reference: Hansford and Turvey 2018 Royal Society Open Science
Diet.Notes: Isotopes indicate a browsing diet of C3 and possible CAM vegetation. This family was likely nocturnal, based on reconstruction of optical lobe (Torres et al. 2018).
Diet.Reference: Clarke et al. 2006 Quaternary Science Reviews; Tovondrafale et al. 2014 Malagasy Nature; Torres et al. 2018 Proceedings of the Royal Society B
Fermentation.Type.Method: Inferred from Infraclass; Inferred from diet
Fermentation.Type.Notes: No empirical evidence nor expert opinions regarding the fermentation type of these massive birds. Their nearest, albeit very distant, relative are kiwis in New Zealand (Mitchell et al. 2014), who are insectivores. Given their massive size, and the evolution of colon-based fermentation among other large-bodied ratites (rheas and ostriches), we are going to infer hindgut colon digestion. However, note that emus and cassuaries have only simple guts. It should be noted that all ratites lack crops (Sales 2006).
Fermentation.Type.Reference: Sales 2006 Avian and Poultry Biology Reviews
Limb.Morphology.Notes: Other than the miharung, which was unguligrade, and loons and grebes, which are plantigrade, all other birds are digitigrade
Habitat.Notes: No evidence found that elephant birds significantly used aquatic habitats. Given their body size they were certainly not arboreal.

Mass.Notes: Primary source inaccessible
Diet.Notes: No empirical evidence found.
Diet.Reference: Smith et al. 2018 Science; Smith et al. 2003 Ecology
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Method: Observed low sample size (1-5) habitat use; Inferred from absence of evidence
Habitat.Notes: No evidence of aquatic habitat use in this species or extant relatives
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Common.Name: Giant Panda
Diet.Notes: The classic bamboo specialist. Bamboo is seen as browse, rather than a grass (taxonomically more correct) because it is lignified and hence closer to woody vegetation.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2009 Handbook of the Mammals of the World
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Despite their plant-based diet of bamboo, panda bears retain a simple carnivore style stomach, which substantially reduces their digestive efficiency.
Fermentation.Type.Reference: Hume 2002 Acta Zoologica Sinica; Dierenfeld et al. 1982 The Journal of Nutrition
Habitat.Notes: Panda bears are largely terrestrial consumers of bamboo. Iwaniuk et al. 2000 lists panda bears as semi-arboreal as they do climb frequently and possess 'false-thumbs' apparently adapted for tree-climbing. However, given that tree-climbing appears to be opportunistic we are scoring this species as terrestrial, recognizing that this is a debatable classification.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2013 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Iwaniuk et al. 2000 Canadian Journal of Zoology

Common.Name: Bear Cuscus
Diet.Notes: Nugraha et al. 2017 found that their primary diet was shoots and young leaves. Folivorous. Similar results by Repi et al. 2019 Biodiversitas, finding a completely folivorous diet with fruits composing ~1%.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2015 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Nugraha et al. 2017 Jurnal Wasian; Repi et al. 2019 Biodiversitas
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Hindgut caecum fermenters are generally smaller-bodied than hindgut colon fermenters. In colon fermenters the caecum is largely modified to become part of the colon, whereas in caecum fermenters, they remain separate structures. Caecums are generally modified into complex structures that retain solutes and fine particles for fermentation while larger particles are excreted through colon, reducing the extent of plant-wall breakdown.
Habitat.Notes: This species prefers undisturbed moist,  lowland forests, from sea level up to as high as ~1000m. This species appears to be almost exclusively arboreal.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2015 Handbook of the Mammals of the World

Common.Name: Hartebeest
Diet.Method: Observed DNA metabarcoding; Observed fecal analysis; Proxy isotopes (C13)
Diet.Notes: Specialized grazers, as supported by DNA metabarcoding and isotopes, which indicate 95-100% of diet is grass. However, in some studies browse has been observed in fecal contents and stomach contents. Observed dietary composition in one study by Codron et al. 2018 found 25% of diet was browse. Given that this reflects an unusual condition, potentially of animals on a starvation diet, we will score browse only as 1. It could also be arguably scored as a 0.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Venter and Kalube-Sabiti 2016 African Journal of Wildlife Research; Pansu et al. 2019 Journal of Ecology; Codron et al. 2018 Ecology and Evolution; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: A species of grassland - woodland edge. Historically, some subspecies were common in desert and semi-desert habitats but have since been hunted out.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa

Common.Name: Moose
Diet.Notes: Spitzer et al. 2020 report that in over 50 years of dietary studies, moose only consumed grass between <1% (winter) and 5% (summer). Diet is primarily browse and underwater plants, on which they are particularly dependent..
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Spitzer et al. 2020 Oikos
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: Denizen of boreal forests to tundra, particularly in areas with marshes. Moose are limited by high temperatures and by snow pack over 70 cm.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Common.Name: Blunt-toothed Giant Hutia
Mass.Notes: McFarlane et al. 1998 report a mean body mass of 94 kg. Raia et al. 2010 report this as a log body mass of 4.97, which gives the estimate in this dataset once converted back to kilograms. While the McFarlane estimate is an assumed average body mass without justification (i.e. expert opinion) it is based upon earlier work of the authors. They refer to Biknevicius et al. 1993. In this paper the authors estimate the body mass of Amblyrhiza inundata based on anteroposterior diameters and cortical cross-sectional areas of humeral and femoral diaphyses. These estimates are based on bone fragments from 14 different specimens. The authors note that the size of this species is notoriously variable variable.
Mass.Reference: Raia et al. 2010 Global Ecology and Biogeography; McFarlane et al. 1998 Quaternary Research; Biknevicius et al. 1993 American Museum Novitates
Diet.Notes: No data found
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Rodents possess hindgut caecum fermentation systems. Hindgut caecum fermenters are generally smaller-bodied than hindgut colon fermenters. In colon fermenters the caecum is largely modified to become part of the colon, whereas in caecum fermenters, they remain separate structures. Caecums are generally modified into complex structures that retain solutes and fine particles for fermentation while larger particles are excreted through colon, reducing the extent of plant-wall breakdown.
Habitat.Notes: While most hutias are semi-arboreal, this animal was gigantic. Arboreality was highly unlikely and would be extremely functionally distinct globally. Unfortunately, little is known empirically about this animal
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2013 Handbook of the Mammals of the World

Common.Name: Dibatag
Diet.Notes: Dibatags primarily consume browse, but will also feed on soft, low-fiber grass at the onset of rainy season
Diet.Reference: Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: A species of semi-arid scrubland, preferring sandy to gravelly soils with high concentrations of ferrous-oxide.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Common.Name: Aoudad
Diet.Notes: In some regions aoudads have a diet principally composed of browse, in others of grasses. They are apparently a true mixed feeder.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Gray and Simpson 1980 Mammalian Species; Fernandez-Olalla et al 2016 Journal of Arid Environments; Mimoun and Nouira 2015 South African Journal of Science
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: No evidence that this species, or any relative, substantially uses arboreal or aquatic habitats. Aoudad prefer steep, vertiginous terrain but also require some shade during summer, thus move into semi-open woodlands at times.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa

Common.Name: Bush Moa
Diet.Notes: Coprolites and gizzards indicate a diet almost exclusively of browse (0.2% graminoid) (data from Wood et al. 2020)
Diet.Reference: Wood et al. 2020 New Zealand Journal of Ecology
Fermentation.Type.Method: Inferred from Infraclass; Inferred from diet
Fermentation.Type.Notes: No empirical evidence nor expert opinions regarding the fermentation type of these birds. Their nearest, albeit distant, relatives are the tinamous of South America (Mitchell et al. 2014, Phillips et al. 2010), who are generalist herbivores with enlarged cecas (Garitano-Zavala et al. 2003). However, given their massive size, and the evolution of colon-based fermentation among other large-bodied ratites (rheas and ostriches), we are going to infer hindgut colon digestion as to the best of our knowledge there are no hindgut ceca fermentating animals of these sizes, and given that other truly herbivorous ratites have colons. However, emus and cassuaries have only simple guts. Also, it should be noted that all ratites lack crops (Sales 2006).
Fermentation.Type.Reference: Sales 2006 Avian and Poultry Biology Reviews; Mitchell et al. 2014 Science; Phillips et al. 2010 Systematic Biology; Garitano-Zavala et al. 2003 Ornitologia Neotropical
Limb.Morphology.Notes: Other than the miharung, which was unguligrade, and loons and grebes, which are plantigrade, all other birds are digitigrade
Habitat.Notes: Most moa species, with the exception of the rarely-preserved North Island species, have had their habitat well-described and ranged low rainforest to high elevation tundra. No description of use of aquatic resources or specialized aquatic adaptions.
Habitat.Reference: Worthy 1990 New Zealand Journal of Zoology

Common.Name: Fossil springbok
Mass.Notes: Primary source inaccessible
Diet.Method: Functional craniodental morphology; Proxy dental wear (microwear and mesowear); Proxy isotopes (C13)
Diet.Notes: Funtional morphology, isotopes, and dental wear all indicate a mixed feeding diet of browse, forbs, and grass.
Diet.Reference: Faith and Behrensmeyer 2013 Paleobiology; Sewell et al. 2019 Journal of Archaeological Science
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Method: Observed low sample size (1-5) habitat use; Inferred from absence of evidence
Habitat.Notes: No evidence that this species, or any relative, substantially uses arboreal or aquatic habitats
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Common.Name: Fossil springbok
Mass.Notes: Primary source inaccessible
Diet.Method: Proxy dental wear (microwear and mesowear); Proxy isotopes (C13)
Diet.Notes: Isotopes and dental wear indicate a diet primarily of graze.
Diet.Reference: Sewell et al. 2019 Journal of Archaeological Science
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Method: Observed low sample size (1-5) habitat use; Inferred from absence of evidence
Habitat.Notes: No evidence that this species, or any relative, substantially uses arboreal or aquatic habitats
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Common.Name: Springbok
Diet.Notes: Springboks will consume young succulent grasses during rainy season, but prefer to browse.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: A species of arid regions, preferring short-grass. They are excluded from woodland savannas from a tick-borne disease to which they are highly susceptible. They avoid areas with water.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa

Mass.Method: Inferred from relative of suggested similar size
Mass.Notes: Assumed of a similar size as Blastocerus dichotomus.
Diet.Notes: No empirical evidence found.
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Method: Observed low sample size (1-5) habitat use; Inferred from absence of evidence
Habitat.Notes: No evidence of aquatic habitat use in this species or extant relatives
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Common.Name: Pronghorn
Diet.Notes: Pronghorn diet consists primarily of forbs and shrubs, with very little grass consumption.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Scasta et al. 2016 Rangeland Ecology and Management; Cain et al. 2017 Wildlife Biology
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Method: Observed low sample size (1-5) habitat use; Inferred from absence of evidence
Habitat.Notes: No evidence that this species, or any relative, substantially uses arboreal or aquatic habitats. A denizen of open grasslands, although can be observed in open pine forest (EJL personal observation)
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Common.Name: Blackbuck
Diet.Notes: Blackbucks are primarily grazers of short stature grasses such as Cynodon dactylon. When grazing quality deteriorates in the dry season they will switch to a diet of forbs, shrubs, fruit, and mast. It is unclear the percent contributions of these, but overall textual descriptions and reported evidence (e.g. in Baskaran et al. 2016) indicate that this species should be scored 3-1 graze-browse
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Jhala and Isvaran 2016 The Ecology of Large Herbivores in South and Southeast Asia; Baskaran et al. 2016 Mammalian Biology
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Method: Observed low sample size (1-5) habitat use; Inferred from absence of evidence
Habitat.Notes: Blackbuck are plains animals whose abundance in regions with scattered forest and scrub is largely contingent on amount of grassland available. No evidence of significant aquatic foraging or usage.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Common.Name: Arabian Tahr
Diet.Notes: Rare and elusive animal with little known about their diet. What evidence there is indicates a browsing diet.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wood 1992 International Zoo Yearbook; Al Majaini 1999 Thesis
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: Arabian tahrs are mountain ungulates of steep, vertiginous terrain. No evidence of significant aquatic foraging or usage.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; Ross et al. 2019 Oryx

Common.Name: Sloth Lemur
Mass.Notes: The estimate is the mean of four different regression estimates based upon femur (n = 1) midshaft cortical area. The reported body mass estimates are rounded versions of those provided in Fleagle and Gilbert 2008.
Mass.Reference: Werdelin and Sanders 2010 Cenozoic Mammals of Africa; Fleagle and Gilbert 2008 Elwyn Simons a Search for Origins
Diet.Method: Functional craniodental morphology; Proxy dental wear (microwear)
Diet.Notes: Dental wear indicates that this family were seed predators, consuming a mixed diet of foliage and fruit
Diet.Reference: Godfrey et al. 2004 Journal of Human Evolution; Crowley and Godfrey 2012 Leaping Ahead
Fermentation.Type.Method: Inferred from body mass; Inferred from sister Family
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Hindgut, but type unknown. Sister family to Indriidae, who have hindgut-caecum digestive systems. However, other than the capybara (45kg) there are few extant species, with caecum digestive systems and body masses much above 10kg (Hume 2002). Unlike the other extinct lemur families, family level inference based on body mass is suspect for Palaeopropithecidae as their body masses are highly variable (from 11kg to 160kg). Going to infer hindgut colon for Archaeoindris and hindgut caecum for the smaller bodied species.
Fermentation.Type.Reference: Campbell et al. 2000 American Journal of Primatology; Clauss et al. 2003 Oecologia
Habitat.Notes: Functional morphology suggests this species was arboreal but more terrestrial than modern sloth lemurs
Habitat.Reference: Jungers et al. 1997 PNAS

Mass.Notes: The estimate is the mean of four different regression estimates based upon humerus (n = 7) midshaft cortical area and four different regression estimates based upon femur (n = 8) midshaft cortical area. The reported body mass estimates are rounded versions of those provided in Fleagle and Gilbert 2008.
Mass.Reference: Werdelin and Sanders 2010 Cenozoic Mammals of Africa; Fleagle and Gilbert 2008 Elwyn Simons a Search for Origins
Diet.Method: Observed coprolites; Proxy dental wear (microwear); Proxy isotopes (C13)
Diet.Notes: Dental wear (microwear) indicates that these were hard-object specialists, likely seed predators. Bone collagen isotopes indicates a browsing diet. Coprolites contained plant fiber, frog and bat bones, and gastropod shells
Diet.Reference: Godfrey et al. 2004 Journal of Human Evolution; Vasey et al. 2012 Leaping Ahead
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Foregut fermentation is very rare in Primates (only colobin monkeys have foregut fermentation), so presume hindgut - and because they are large-bodied, they are almost certainly using a colon-type fermentation chamber, even though extant lemurs use a caecum-style chamber.
Fermentation.Type.Reference: Campbell et al. 2000 American Journal of Primatology; Hume 2002 Acta Zoologica Sinica
Habitat.Notes: Functional morphology suggests that this species was most likely not arboreal
Habitat.Reference: Jungers et al. 2005 Journal of Human Evolution

Mass.Notes: The estimate is the mean of four different regression estimates based upon humerus (n = 2) midshaft cortical area and four different regression estimates based upon femur (n = 3) midshaft cortical area. The reported body mass estimates are rounded versions of those provided in Fleagle and Gilbert 2008.
Mass.Reference: Werdelin and Sanders 2010 Cenozoic Mammals of Africa; Fleagle and Gilbert 2008 Elwyn Simons a Search for Origins
Diet.Notes: Dental wear indicates hard-object specialists and seed predators / frugivores. Bone collagen carbon isotope values indicating a browsing diet.
Diet.Reference: Godfrey et al. 2004 Journal of Human Evolution
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Foregut fermentation is very rare in Primates (only colobin monkeys have foregut fermentation), so presume hindgut - and because they are large-bodied, they are almost certainly using a colon-type fermentation chamber, even though extant lemurs use a caecum-style chamber.
Fermentation.Type.Reference: Campbell et al. 2000 American Journal of Primatology; Hume 2002 Acta Zoologica Sinica
Habitat.Notes: Functional morphology suggests that this species was most likely not arboreal
Habitat.Reference: Jungers et al. 2005 Journal of Human Evolution

Common.Name: Short-faced bear
Mass.Notes: Prevosti and Vizcaino 2006 base their estimate on Soibelzon 2002, who provides estimates for the mass of Arctotherium tarijense using six different regressions, based on M1 length and occipital condyle length. However, it is unclear how Prevosti and Vizcaino 2006 came up with the value of 139.42 kg. It does not appear in Soibelzon 2002. Prevosti and Vizcaino 2006 provide a body mass range of 102-189 kg. This suggest they based their estimate on regression A2 and B2 in Soibelzon 2002, though this is speculative. The Prevosti and Vizcaino estimate seems realistic, though, as it falls within the range of mass estimates provided by Soibelzon 2002.
Mass.Reference: Prevosti and Vizcaino 2006 Acta Palaeontologica Polonica; Soibelzon 2002 Thesis
Diet.Method: Functional craniodental morphology; Proxy isotopes (C13, N15)
Diet.Notes: Isotopes indicate a broad diet of C3 vegetation. Also likely a scavenger (Prevosti and Martin 2013). Figueirido and Soibelzon 2010 also suggest it was primarily an herbivore based on morphology.
Diet.Reference: Figueirido and Soibelzon 2010 Lethaia; Prevosti and Martin 2013 Quaternary International
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Bears possess simple carnivore style stomachs, without significant fermentation of plant components of their diet. Their diet thus tends towards high-nutrient foods, fruits, and starches
Habitat.Notes: Predicted to be exclusively terrestrial through morphological inference of elbow joint similarity to extant species.
Habitat.Reference: Meloro et al. 2019 Journal of Mammalian Evolution

Common.Name: Short-faced bear
Mass.Notes: Presumably mandible length, though the measurment is not specified. Comparison species unknown.
Diet.Notes: Functional morphology suggests that these short-faced bears were browsing omnivores, similar to most bears
Diet.Reference: Figueirido and Soibelzon 2010 Lethaia
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Bears possess simple carnivore style stomachs, without significant fermentation of plant components of their diet. Their diet thus tends towards high-nutrient foods, fruits, and starches
Habitat.Notes: Predicted to be exclusively terrestrial through morphological inference of elbow joint similarity to extant species.
Habitat.Reference: Meloro et al. 2019 Journal of Mammalian Evolution

Common.Name: Chital
Diet.Notes: Intermediate mixed feeders who prefer graze. They supplement grass consumption with forbs, leaves, flowers, and fruits. Primarily eat green grass, moving into open habitats during the rainy season. Have been observed eating crabs, but this is likely uncommon.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: Denizens of grassland-forest transition zones, preferring moist and dry forest areas near grasslands or shrublands. Also live in swampy meadows, riparian forests, and teak plantations. Avoidant of dense forests and mountainous habitats. A tropical species with limited cold-tolerance with their habitat in introduced range in Hawai'i is limited by frost. In Hawai'i, they will swim between the islands of Maui Nui (EJL, personal observation)
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Common.Name: Calamian Deer
Diet.Notes: Mixed feeder with a preference for graze (Wegge et al. 2006).
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wegge et al. 2006 Ecological Research
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Method: Observed low sample size (1-5) habitat use; Inferred from absence of evidence
Habitat.Notes: Little known, this species has a tiny island-restricted range. Denizens of grasslands, open woodlands, and secondary forests
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Common.Name: Bawean Deer
Diet.Notes: Little known, reported to primarily consume grasses and forbs but also leaves and buds.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Method: Observed low sample size (1-5) habitat use; Inferred from absence of evidence
Habitat.Notes: Little known, this species has a tiny island-restricted range. Denizens of hilly, secondary forests.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Common.Name: Hog Deer
Diet.Notes: Diet is more than 80% graminoids (Tuboi and Hussain 2016), but they also consume herbs, flowers, fruit, and young leaves.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Tuboi and Hussain 2016 Mammalian Biology
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: Hog deers live in wet or moist grasslands, often associated with river systems. Like other axis deer, this species avoids closed canopy forests.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Common.Name: Sloth Lemur
Mass.Notes: The estimate is the mean of four different regression estimates based upon humerus (n = 4) midshaft cortical area and four different regression estimates based upon femur (n = 4) midshaft cortical area. The reported body mass estimates are rounded versions of those provided in Fleagle and Gilbert 2008.
Mass.Reference: Werdelin and Sanders 2010 Cenozoic Mammals of Africa; Fleagle and Gilbert 2008 Elwyn Simons a Search for Origins
Diet.Method: Functional craniodental morphology; Proxy dental wear (microwear)
Diet.Notes: Dental wear indicates that this family were seed predators, consuming a mixed diet of foliage and fruit
Diet.Reference: Godfrey et al. 2004 Journal of Human Evolution; Crowley and Godfrey 2012 Leaping Ahead
Fermentation.Type.Method: Inferred from body mass; Inferred from sister Family
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Hindgut, but type unknown. Sister family to Indriidae, who have hindgut-caecum digestive systems. However, other than the capybara (45kg) there are few extant species, with caecum digestive systems and body masses much above 10kg (Hume 2002). Unlike the other extinct lemur families, family level inference based on body mass is suspect for Palaeopropithecidae as their body masses are highly variable (from 11kg to 160kg). Going to infer hindgut colon for Archaeoindris and hindgut caecum for the smaller bodied species.
Fermentation.Type.Reference: Campbell et al. 2000 American Journal of Primatology; Clauss et al. 2003 Oecologia
Habitat.Notes: Functional morphology suggests this species was less specialized for arboreal lifestyle than Palaeopropithecus, so presume some terrestriality
Habitat.Reference: Jungers et al. 1997 PNAS; Shapiro et al. 2005 American Journal of Physical Anthropology

Common.Name: Hairy Babirusa
Diet.Notes: Buru locals describe babirusa as feeding on leaves, roots, and fruit, but avoiding people's crops (unlike other pigs). They also describe babirusa foraging on coastline, while the tide is out.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Unlike other suids, babyrousa have retained or evolved a form of foregut, sacciform non-ruminant fermentation.
Fermentation.Type.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Leus et al. 1999 Comptes Rendus de lAcademie des Sciences; Meijaard and Groves 2002 Asian Wild Pig News
Habitat.Notes: Described by Pacini and Harper 2008 as semi-aquatic, although this is likely opportunistic. Tthey primariliy occur in tropical lowland evergreen rainforest, up to 800 m in elevation. Local people on Buru island indicate that babirusas are most common in rocky habitats, in hills and mountains
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; Pacini and Harper 2008 Tropical stream ecology

Common.Name: Sulawesi Babirusa
Mass.Notes: Comparison species is Babyrousa babyrussa.
Diet.Method: Observed foraging (captive population); Observed low sample size (1-5) evidence
Diet.Notes: Sulawesi babirusa have been observed catching small mammals and birds in captivity, and have been observed eating a variety of leaves and roots. Fruit is particularly important to their diet and sought after. Babirusa presence appears contingent on fruiting trees, with herds abandoning areas when fruit trees are logged.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Unlike other suids, babyrousa have retained or evolved a form of foregut, sacciform non-ruminant fermentation.
Fermentation.Type.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Leus et al. 1999 Comptes Rendus de lAcademie des Sciences; Meijaard and Groves 2002 Asian Wild Pig News
Habitat.Notes: Babirusa's preferred habitat lowland riparian zones, ponds, and swamplands, where they are adept swimmers. Apparently, human activities have pushed them out of these preferred habitats, and now they occur in dry upland forests in the interior of Sulawesi. Given their habitat flexibility and the anecdotal nature of their aquatic habitat use, we will mark this as 0.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Common.Name: Togian Islands Babirusa
Mass.Notes: Comparison species is Babyrousa babyrussa.
Diet.Notes: Togian babirusa has been described as consuming rhizomes, fallen fruits, and annual forbs. Little empirical evidence found.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Unlike other suids, babyrousa have retained or evolved a form of foregut, sacciform non-ruminant fermentation.
Fermentation.Type.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Leus et al. 1999 Comptes Rendus de lAcademie des Sciences; Meijaard and Groves 2002 Asian Wild Pig News
Habitat.Notes: This species is a denizen of tropical rainforest, often associated with rivers and richly vegetated ponds. Given that the Togian islands consist of very wet forests, they have also been sighted in gardens, regrowing scrub, secondary forests, freshwater swamp, and beaches. Aquatic habitat usage appears opportunistic and thus will be scored as a 0.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Common.Name: Hirola
Diet.Notes: Reviewed by Ruso 2017 and Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa, as well as Wilson and Mittermeier. Diet consists primarily of grasses, but will consume forbs during the dry season. Prefer short green grass, with high leaf to stem ratio.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Ruso 2017 Mammalian Species; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: Hirola dwell in gentle hills along coast, in habitat varying from dry thornbush to light woodland and lush savanna, preferring seasonally inundated floodplain habitats with sandy substrates.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa

Common.Name: American Bison
Diet.Notes: Traditionally considered a grazer but will consume substantial quantities of woody vegetation and forbs during spring and fall (Bergmann et al. 2015). Likewise, climate change driven reductions in C3 grasses and increases in C4 have led to bison increasingly consuming browse instead of C4 grasses (Craine et al. 2015). Reported percentages indicate that their actual realized diet is mixed feeding, even if they prefer grazing and show morphological adaptations for it.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Bergmann et al. 2015 PLoS One; Craine et al. 2015 Scientific Reports
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: Habitat generalists of grassland and woodlands. Formerly made large river-crossing migrations, as they are strong swimmers. No specific evidence of obligate reliance on wetland habitats, though Wilson and Mittermeier mention that sedges in riparian zones are a preferred food item.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; Steenweg et al. 2016 PLoS One

Common.Name: European Bison
Diet.Method: Observed DNA metabarcoding; Observed fecal analysis
Diet.Notes: Traditionally considered a grazer, however, wisent consume a substantial amount of woody and herbaceous biomass. In one study, meta-barcoding indicated that 59% of diet was comprised of woody vegetation, followed by forbs (Kowalczyk et al. 2019). Like bison, wisent's realized diet is mixed feeding.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Cromsigt et al. 2017 Restoration Ecology; Kowalczyk et al. 2011 Forest Ecology and Management
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: European bison are generalist species preferring mosaic habitats of deciduous and mixed forests with open patches.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Common.Name: Marsh Deer
Diet.Notes: Mixed feeding herbivore. An isotopic study (Loponte and Corriale 2013) showed C3 (browse) dominance, but with high variance, supporting others claims of mixed feeding. Indeed, they have been documented eating only ~2% graminoids (Marin et al. 2020 European Journal of Wildlife Research). Diet consists primarily of aquatic and semi-aquatic plants. They tend to focus on easy to digest, low-fiber foods.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Loponte and Corriale 2013 Journal of Archaeological Science; Marin et al. 2020 European Journal of Wildlife Research
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: The coat, hoofs, and leg morphology of this species are adapted for a semi-aquatic habit. They prefer shallow wetlands with vegetation < 70 cm submerged, though will venture into deeper waters and has been observed foraging on floating mats of vegetation.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; Pacini and Harper 2008 Tropical stream ecology

Common.Name: Harlan's muskox; helmeted muskox; bonnet-headed muskox
Mass.Notes: Primary source inaccessible
Diet.Notes: Isotopes indicate a diet of C3 vegetation with minor consumption of C4 plants.
Diet.Reference: Kohn and Mckay 2012 Palaeogeography, Palaeoclimatology, Palaeoecology
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Method: Observed low sample size (1-5) habitat use; Inferred from absence of evidence
Habitat.Notes: No evidence that this species, or any relative, substantially uses arboreal or aquatic habitats
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Mass.Notes: Primary source inaccessible
Diet.Method: Functional craniodental morphology; Inferred from Family
Diet.Notes: Like its extant, small-bodied rat-kangaroo relatives, Borungaboodie was likely to have fed on seeds, fruits, carrion, insects, fungus, and tender browse. No empirical/proxy data found.
Diet.Reference: Prideaux 1999 Records of the Western Australian Museum
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Extant rat-kangaroos have foregut non-ruminant fermentation systems like their Macropodid kin. We thus infer the same for Borungaboodie.
Limb.Morphology.Notes: Following the methods of Kubo et al. 2019 PNAS, Youtube videos of extant Potoroids (dusky rat kangaroo, Hypsiprymnodon moschatus) were viewed to assess foot morphology while walking.
Habitat.Notes: Inhabitants of sclerophyll forest, no indication of aquatic habitat usage.
Habitat.Reference: Prideaux 1999 Records of the Western Australian Museum

Common.Name: Gaur
Mass.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World
Diet.Notes: Gaur have a more diverse diet than many other Asian wild cattle. They've been recorded consuming 66-100% mature and senesced grasses, but also eat substantial amounts of bamboo, herbaceous forbs, shrubs, fruits, bark and tree foliage, though the percentages of browse from these studies are not clear.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Haleem and Ilyas 2018 Zoological Science; Gad and Shyama 2011 Zoological Science; Ahrestani et al. 2012 Journal of Tropical Ecology
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: In their re-introduced range in central India, gaur preferred grassland during summer, but mixed bamboo forest during monsoon and winter. Overall, a more forest-specialized Bos than its congeners. Are noted to be free-water dependent.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; Sankar et al. 2013 Tropical Conservation Science

Common.Name: Banteng
Diet.Notes: Although morphologically a grazer, banteng consume substantial browse seasonally in both in their introduced and native ranges.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Chaiyarat et al. 2017 Mammalia; Bowman et al. 2010 Journal of Biogeography; Gardner et al. 2019 Mammalia
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: Banteng prefer dry, open-forest habitats, or select meadows within forests. Water availability is important as they are daily drinkers.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; Steinmetz 2004 Mammalia

Common.Name: Wild Yak
Mass.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World
Diet.Notes: Wild yaks primarily consume grasses (~70-80%) supplemented with lichen, forbs, and shrubs.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Leslie and Schaller 2009 Mammalian Species; Basumatary et al. 2019 PLoS One
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: Wild yaks live in rugged mountainous areas. During the summer they often graze in nutrient-rich alpine meadows.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; Liang et al. 2017 Oryx

Common.Name: Aurochs
Mass.Notes: The source provided by Smith et al. 2003 does not provide a mass estimate for this species.
Diet.Method: Functional craniodental morphology; Inferred from domestic conspecific; Proxy dental wear (microwear and mesowear); Proxy isotopes (C13, N15)
Diet.Notes: Primarily a grazer, but two studies (Rivals et al. 2017, Rivals and Lister 2016) suggest high enough consumption of browse to classify as a mixed feeder preferring graminoids.
Diet.Reference: Cromsigt et al. 2017 Restoration Ecology; Saarinen et al. 2016 Palaeontologia Electronica; Noe-Nygaard et al. 2005 Journal of Archaeological Science; Rivals et al. 2016 Palaeogeography, Palaeoclimatology, Palaeoecology; Rivals and Lister 2016 Quaternary Science Reviews
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Method: Observed low sample size (1-5) habitat use; Inferred from absence of evidence
Habitat.Notes: A once wide-ranging species, with broad habitat affinities. No evidence that this species, or any relative, is an obligate user of aquatic habitats
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Common.Name: Cow
Species.Status: Extinct after 1500 CE, but wild in introduced range
Mass.Reference: AnAge: The Animal Ageing and Longevity Database
Diet.Notes: While cattle consume browse and forbs, they prefer graminoids.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Method: Observed low sample size (1-5) habitat use; Inferred from absence of evidence
Habitat.Notes: No evidence that this species, or any relative, is an obligate user of aquatic habitats
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Common.Name: Kouprey
Diet.Notes: Not much is known about this rare and elusive bovid. Handbook of the Mammals of the World classifies B. sauveli as consuming grasses, as well as forbs and browse, and possibly digging for tubers with their unusually frayed horns.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Method: Observed low sample size (1-5) habitat use; Inferred from absence of evidence
Habitat.Notes: Kouprey use open deciduous forests, preferring open savanna-like areas. No evidence that this species, or any relative, is an obligate user of aquatic habitats
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Common.Name: Nilgai
Diet.Notes: Not exhaustively studied. Observational evidence and scat analysis diet is predominately graze (~60-70%), supplemented with browse, particularly during dry season. Fruits also can be an important seasonal component of diet.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Bhat et al. 2015 Biomedical and Pharmacology Journal; Moczygemba 2010 Thesis
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: A habitat generalist of mixed savanna, scrub, grasslands. In general nilgai avoid closed habitat, preferring open grassland and scrub, or coastal prairies. Water-availability limits distribution. No evidence that this species or any relative is an obligate user of aquatic habitats
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; Leslie 2008 Mammalian Species

Common.Name: Southern Muriqui
Diet.Notes: Southern muriquis are strictly herbivorous and primarily frugivores, though up to 41-93% of their feeding time is spent eating leaves, with this varying seasonally. Over the course of a year in southern Brazil, 70% of their diet were fruits.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2013 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Righini and Amato 2018 Encyclopedia of Animal Cognition and Behavior
Fermentation.Type.Notes: All primates except colobin monkeys have hindgut fermentation systems. Larger bodied primates use the colon for fermentation, except for Atelidae, which conduct caecum based hindgut fermentation. Hindgut caecum fermenters are generally smaller-bodied than hindgut colon fermenters. In colon fermenters the caecum is largely modified to become part of the colon, whereas in caecum fermenters, they remain separate structures. Caecums are generally modified into complex structures that retain solutes and fine particles for fermentation while larger particles are excreted through colon, reducing the extent of plant-wall breakdown.
Fermentation.Type.Reference: Lambert 1998 Evolutionary Anthropology; Tran 2016 The American Naturalist
Habitat.Notes: Southern muriquis are almost entirely arboreal, spending neglible amounts of time on the ground to drink water or eat soil.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2013 Handbook of the Mammals of the World

Common.Name: Wild water buffalo
Mass.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World
Diet.Notes: Diet varies seasonally from grazer to browser, but overall, and based on morphology, water buffalo are mixed feeders preferring graze, only consuming browse as fresh green grass becomes scare, or during drought.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Shrestha et al. 2020 Ecology and Evolution; Pokhrel et al. 2019 International Journal of Research Studies in Zoology; Bowman et al. 2010 Journal of Biogeography
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: Water buffalo spend considerable time in water, wallowing and resting and generally forage within riparian corridors and floodplains (Choudhury 1994).
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; IUCN Redlist 2018; Choudhury 1994 Oryx

Common.Name: Domestic water buffalo
Mass.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World
Diet.Notes: Diet varies seasonally from grazer to browser, but overall, and based on morphology, water buffalo are mixed feeders preferring graze, only consuming browse as fresh green grass becomes scare, or during drought.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Shrestha et al. 2020 Ecology and Evolution; Pokhrel et al. 2019 International Journal of Research Studies in Zoology; Bowman et al. 2010 Journal of Biogeography
