Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; IUCN Redlist 2018

Common.Name: Lowland Anoa
Diet.Notes: Several fecal studies concur that this species is primarily a browser with dicotyledons and fruits comprising nearly the entirety of their diet.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Pujaningsih et al. 2009 Journal of the Indonesian Tropical Animal Agriculture
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Method: Observed low sample size (1-5) habitat use
Habitat.Notes: Little is known about this species, but they are known to be associated with wetland habitats.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; Pacini and Harper 2008 Tropical stream ecology

Mass.Notes: Rozzi 2017 lists 28 different regressions they used to calculate the body mass of species in the paper (each using a different body measurement), but they do not explicitely say which ones were used the estimate the body mass of Bubablus grovesi. This estimate is based on 32 specimens from six different localities.
Diet.Notes: No empirical evidence found
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: No empirical evidence found.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Common.Name: Tamaraw
Diet.Notes: Very little is known about this species. They are thought to be a grazer of forest edges.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Talbot and Talbot 1965 Mammalia
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Method: Observed low sample size (1-5) habitat use
Habitat.Notes: Tamaraw are little known but primarily dwell in open grassland and forest glades, as well as bamboo-jungle, marshy riparian zones, and drier upland forests.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; Pacini and Harper 2008 Tropical stream ecology

Common.Name: Long-horned Javan water buffalo
Mass.Notes: Comparison species is Bubalus arnee
Diet.Notes: Isotopes indicate a C4 diet, except for one specimen which showed a mixed C3-C4 diet. However, this sample may have been contaminated or be a misplaced specimen (Janssen et al. 2016).
Diet.Reference: Janssen et al. 2016 Quaternary Science Reviews
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: No empirical evidence found.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Common.Name: Mountain Anoa
Diet.Notes: No empirical evidence found
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Method: Inferred from absence of evidence; Inferred from vegetation association
Habitat.Notes: A higher elevation anoa species, who may use swampy habitat but this has been unreported.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; Burton et al. 2005 Mammal Review

Common.Name: Takin
Diet.Notes: Fecal analysis indicates a diet of exclusive browse (Wangchuk et al. 2015). Wilson and Mitteremeier report that indeed this species primarily consumes woody plants, but also some forbs. They will bend down small trees to consume foliage and will also stand on hindlegs to feed.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Schaller et al. 1986 Mammalia; Wangchuk et al. 2015 Journal of Natural History
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: Wangchuk et al. 2015 documented habitat use of dry forest, alpine scrub, meadows, semi-open willow shrublands. No documentation of use of aquatic habitats.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; Wangchuk et al. 2015 Journal of Natural History

Common.Name: Caipora
Mass.Notes: Cartelle and Hartwig 1996 PNAS note that it is difficult to accurately estimate the body mass of Caipora bambuiorum because it is much larger than any of the living atelines.
Mass.Reference: Smith et al. 2003 Ecology; Cartelle and Hartwig 1996 Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America
Diet.Method: Functional craniodental morphology; Inferred from Family
Diet.Notes: Craniodental morphology suggests a mix of frugivory and folivory, which is characteristic of this family.
Diet.Reference: Cooke 2011 The Anatomical Record
Fermentation.Type.Notes: All primates except colobin monkeys have hindgut fermentation systems. Larger bodied primates use the colon for fermentation, except for Atelidae, which conduct caecum based hindgut fermentation. Hindgut caecum fermenters are generally smaller-bodied than hindgut colon fermenters. In colon fermenters the caecum is largely modified to become part of the colon, whereas in caecum fermenters, they remain separate structures. Caecums are generally modified into complex structures that retain solutes and fine particles for fermentation while larger particles are excreted through colon, reducing the extent of plant-wall breakdown.
Habitat.Method: Functional morphology; Observed low sample size (1-5) habitat use; Inferred from vegetation association
Habitat.Notes: This species was likely arboreal, based on its family, habitat associations, and functional morphology.
Habitat.Reference: Cartelle and Hartwig 1996 Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America

Common.Name: Extinct western camel; Camelops
Mass.Notes: Primary source inaccessible. We could only access one the three primary sources listed: Stuart 1991 Biological Reviews. This source provides a mass estimate of 580 kg, so we assume that the mass estimate listed in Smith et al. 2003 comes from the two other sources.
Diet.Method: Observed dental bolus; Proxy isotopes (C13, O18)
Diet.Notes: 36 dental boluses (from 15 individuals) contained 90% non-grass matter (Akersten et al. 1988). Isotopic data from Hidalgo, MX, indicate a C3 dominated diet of browse in mixed open/closed savanna/woodland (Bravo-Cuevas et al. 2017)
Diet.Reference: Akersten et al. 1988 Quaternary Research; Bravo Cuevas et al. 2017 Palaeogeography, Palaeoclimatology, Palaeoecology
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Unlike ruminants, who have 4 chambers in their foregut, camelids have 3 and are considered non-ruminant ruminoids (Jassim and Hogan 2012). Their digestive system is slightly less efficient and has faster throughput than a similar-sized ruminant. They differ from other foregut non-ruminants however in actually ruminating.
Fermentation.Type.Reference: Hume 2002 Acta Zoologica Sinica; Al Jassim and Hogan 2012 Proc. 3rd ISOCARD Conference
Habitat.Method: Observed low sample size (1-5) habitat use; Inferred from absence of evidence
Habitat.Notes: No evidence of aquatic habitat use in this species or extant relatives
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Common.Name: Dromedary camel
Species.Status: Extinct before 1500 CE, but wild in introduced range
Diet.Method: Functional craniodental morphology; Observed fecal analysis; Observed foraging
Diet.Notes: Dromedaries are primarily browsers and are capable of subsisting on extremely low nutrient vegetation. In the Sahara desert, shrubs and forbs comprise 70% of their diet in winter and 90% in summer. In Syria, shrubs dominate during the dry season, but then herbaceous forbs dominate during the wet season. In Australia, their diet is 53% browse, 42% forbs, and 5% grasses. Will browse up to 3.5m in height by breaking off branches or stripping leaves. Dromedaries require 6-8 times more salt than other similar-sized animals, much of which they obtain from halophytic plants.
Diet.Reference: Rowan et al. 2019 Historical Biology; Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Unlike ruminants, who have 4 chambers in their foregut, camelids have 3 and are considered non-ruminant ruminoids (Jassim and Hogan 2012). Their digestive system is slightly less efficient and has faster throughput than a similar-sized ruminant. They differ from other foregut non-ruminants however in actually ruminating.
Habitat.Notes: A desert-dwelling species that can go long periods of time without surface-water. In Australia, they favor bushy semi-arid country and sandy plains, avoiding heavily vegetated areas and hard rocky habitat. Not semi-aquatic in habit.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Common.Name: Bactrian Camel
Diet.Notes: Diet is primarily shrubs and forbs (Mengli et al. 2006, Wilson and Mittermeier 2011), switching from senesced forbs in winter to shrubs in spring, and back to forbs in Autumn. Are capable of utilizing extremely low-quality forage. Can drink salt water and will eat bones, rope, and other strange food items. Wilson and Mittermeier state that bactrian camels are grazers and browsers, yet only describe browse consumption in their subsequent examples. Likewise, we have found no evidence of significant graminoid consumption in the literature.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Mengli et al. 2006 Applied Animal Behaviour Science
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Unlike ruminants, who have 4 chambers in their foregut, camelids have 3 and are considered non-ruminant ruminoids (Jassim and Hogan 2012). Their digestive system is slightly less efficient and has faster throughput than a similar-sized ruminant. They differ from other foregut non-ruminants however in actually ruminating.
Habitat.Notes: A desert-dwelling species that can go long periods of time without surface-water. Not semi-aquatic in habit. In the Gobi desert, they inhabit perhaps the most inhospitable terrain possible, which is hyper arid, with scant vegetation and water. The Gobi desert is a rocky desert of small stones, with sand dunes, and halophytic plains. Apparently bactrian camels avoid open dunes and gravel deserts, preferring moderately hard ground.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Common.Name: Cretan deer
Mass.Notes: The body mass estimate is based upon the size ratio between mainland and island species reported in Raia and Meiri 2006 Evolution. The reference mainland species is likely Praemegaceros verticornis.
Mass.Reference: Raia et al. 2010 Global Ecology and Biogeography
Diet.Notes: No empirical evidence found.
Diet.Reference: Vos et al. 2002 World Islands in Prehistory
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: van der Geer et al. (2006) suggested that this genus was a stocky goat-like rocky hillside herbivore based on body morphometrics
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Common.Name: Cretan deer
Mass.Notes: Comparison species is Candiacervus cretensis
Diet.Notes: No empirical evidence found.
Diet.Reference: Vos et al. 2002 World Islands in Prehistory

Mass.Notes: Comparison species is Candiacervus cretensis
Diet.Notes: No empirical evidence found.
Diet.Reference: Vos et al. 2002 World Islands in Prehistory

Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Common.Name: Wild Goat
Diet.Method: Inferred from domestic conspecific; Observed fecal analysis
Diet.Notes: Goats prefer grasses, but will consume substantial browse in arid environments and when grass is unavailable. A consummate consumer of nearly anything.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: Wild goats are species of vertiginous, rocky habitats. Often in arid to semi-arid areas, but in some parts of range dwell in open pine forests on steep mountain slopes,a voiding dense vegetation and gentle slopes.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; Sarhangzadeh et al. 2013 Caspian Journal Environmental Science

Common.Name: Domestic goat
Diet.Notes: Goats prefer grasses, but will consume substantial browse in arid environments and when grass is unavailable. A consummate consumer of nearly anything.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: A terrestrial species preferring rocky, steep habitats. In areas without predators in their introduced range are common in flat terrain as well. Goats are excellent climbers of trees (yes, even palm trees https://youtu.be/SLOc1WLEGrk), but given that this would be undetectable morphologically for extinct species, and because tree-climbing is not obligate but only opportunistic, we will not score this species as semi-arboreal.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Common.Name: Western Tur
Diet.Notes: Western turs diet vary seasonally, with grasses comprising up to 95% of diet in the summer, falling to 70% in the winter.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: Western turs preferred habitat are forsted mountain sides with rocky retreat terrain. Prior to widespread human development they occurred more commonly in lower elevations (Avaliani et al. 2007)
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; Avaliani et al. 2007

Common.Name: Eastern Tur
Diet.Notes: Seasonally vary between graminoids and forbaceous browse, with graminoids constituting 30-65% of diet, increasing during the summer. Will dig down to 30cm to uncover forage.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Weinberg 2002 Mammalian Species
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: Gavashelishvili 2004 confirm that this is a species reaches highest densities on steep mountain slopes. They are excellent climbers.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; Gavashelishvili 2004 Biological Conservation

Common.Name: Markhor
Diet.Notes: Markhor consume about 50% woody shrubs, 25% forbs, and 25% graminoids. They feed considerably (37% of time in one study) in tree canopies when food scarcity on the ground is low.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Ashraf et al. 2014 Turkish Journal of Zoology
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: Markhor prefer dry, steep terrain near cliffs (Schaller and Khan 1975), but can tolerate high degrees of canopy cover. While they can spend considerable (37%) of their time feeding on foliage in trees, this is not obligate nor are their arboreal adaptations different than adaptations for vertiginous terrain (Wilson and Mittermeier 2011). Thus we are going to classify this species as terrestrial, but recognize that this is ambiguous.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; Schaller and Khan 1975 Biological Conservation

Common.Name: Alpine ibex
Diet.Notes: Alpine ibex predominately consume graminoids (~70%) followed by browse
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Zingg 2009 Thesis
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: Denizens of steep terrain with significant sexual segregation in habitat use, with females using steeper, cliffier terrain. Because of food scarcity, males will also use pastures and and larch woodlands.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; Bon et al. 2001 Animal Behaviour; Grignolio et al. 2003 Folia Zoologica

Common.Name: Nubian Ibex
Diet.Notes: Nubian ibexes consume substantial browse and herbaceous vegetation, including grass. They are considered a dietary generalist, though grasses comprise only around a third of their diet.
Diet.Reference: Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: Forage preferentially in steep, rocky terrain. In flatter, more vegetated habitats display increased levels of vigilance (Iribarren and Kotler 2012)
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; Iribarren and Kotler 2012 Wildlife Biology

Common.Name: Iberian Wild Goat; Spanish Ibex
Diet.Notes: Diet reflects availability: in some regions where browse availability is low, they primarily consume graminoids (69-80%), while in areas with higher browse availability they consume almost entirely browse and forbs.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: Mountain animals who like Capra ibex show sexual segregation in habitat use, with males using riskier and poorer-quality habitats.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; Acevedo and Cassinello 2009 Mammal Review

Common.Name: Siberian Ibex
Diet.Notes: Diet reflects availability and seasonality and can vary from browse dominance to graminoid dominance.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: Like other caprids, Siberian ibexes are mountain species preferring steep, rocky terrain (Li et al. 2015)
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; Li et al. 2015 Pakistan Journal of Zoology

Common.Name: Walia Ibex
Diet.Notes: This species predominately browse, but supplement diet with graze
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Gebremedhin et al. 2016 PLoS One; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: In their tiny distribution in the Simien mountains their primary habitat are steep cliffs inaccessible to livestock and humans. Feeds in alpine steppe and scrub of Ericaceae vegetation. Has also been observed foraging in flat alpine plateaus, which is unusual for ibex.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa

Common.Name: European Roe Deer
Diet.Notes: While considered a strict browser, Spitzer et al. 2020 report that their gut contents on average contain 9% (summer) and 6% (winter) grass, though occassional individuals have been found with up to 25% grass. Given that this is rare, we are scoring graminoid consumption at 0. They are specialized at breaking down secondary plant compounds, for which they have a small rumen, large salivary glands, and a large liver. These adaptations make them insensitive to the toxic effects of high tannin concentrations.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Spitzer et al. 2020 Oikos
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: Morphologically adapted for dense, vegetaion of early successional forests. Agricultural fragmentation beginning in the Neolithic led to range expansion, as the brushy edge habitats are ideal for this species.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Common.Name: Miyako island roe deer
Mass.Notes: Bone measurement not specified. Comparison species is Capreolus pygargus
Diet.Notes: No empirical evidence found.
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.

Habitat.Notes: No evidence of aquatic habitat use in this species or extant relatives
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Common.Name: Siberian Roe Deer
Diet.Notes: Considered a pure browser by Wilson and Mittermeier. However, stomach content analysis in Siberia found that forbs were predominant, followed by grasses, and then shrubs, with grasses comprised up to 64% of diet by late Autumn (Argunov and Stepanov 2011).
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Adhikari et al. 2016 Journal of Asia-Pacific Biodiversity
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: A species of forest clearings and treeless, tallgrass steppe. Particularly adapted to extremely cold and hot temperatures, and are only limited by snow fall greater than 50 cm.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Common.Name: Japanese Serow
Diet.Notes: Classified by most as a browser, but at least one study showed graze dominance in diet, though this study was spatially and temporally limited. Therefore considering species a mixed feeder preferring browse
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Endo et al. 2017 Mammal Study; Takada and Minami 2018 Mammalia; Aiba et al. 2019 Mammal Study
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: Japanese serow are solitary inhabitants of steep, dense, low-visibility shrublands (Takada et al. 2019)
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; Takada et al. 2019 Behavioural Processes

Common.Name: Chinese Serow
Mass.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World
Diet.Notes: Diet is primarily browse, but there are few empirical studies
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Thuc et al. 2012 Tap Chi Sinh Hoc

This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. Habitat.Method: Observed low sample size (1-5) habitat use; Inferred from absence of evidence
Habitat.Notes: Though poorly studied, this species appears to prefer steep terrain and secondary forests and scrublands (Thuc et al. 2014)
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; Thuc et al. 2014 Pacific Conservation Biology

Mass.Notes: Comparison species is Capricornis sumatraensis
Diet.Notes: No data found

Common.Name: Sumatran Serow
Diet.Notes: Little empirical evidence, but considered to be primarily browsers.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World

Diet.Notes: Uncertain. The sole evidence for diet is the large degree of hypsodonty, but the phylogeny is unresolved so imputation is unlikely to give accurate results, thus we will use Faith 2014's classification as grazer.
Diet.Reference: Faith 2014 Earth Science Reviews

Common.Name: Dwarf pronghorn
Mass.Reference: Davis 2017 Proceedings of the Royal Society B; Bravo-Cuevas et al. 2013 Revista Mexicana de Ciencias Geologicas
Diet.Notes: Some evidence for exclusive browsing, some for mixed feeding. Assigning mixed feeding with preferance for browse. Bravo-Cuevas et al. (2017) echoes this with new isotopic data finding a clear mixed feeding signature.
Diet.Reference: Bravo-Cuevas et al. 2013 Revista Mexicana de Ciencias Geologicas; Fuller et al. 2020 Palaeogeography, Palaeoclimatology, Palaeoecology; Bravo Cuevas et al. 2017 Palaeogeography, Palaeoclimatology, Palaeoecology
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Method: Observed low sample size (1-5) habitat use; Inferred from absence of evidence
Habitat.Notes: No evidence that this species, or any relative, substantially uses arboreal or aquatic habitats
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Common.Name: American Beaver
Diet.Notes: Diet includes woody vegetation, emergent vegetation (including graminoids such as sedges and reeds), as well as floating-leaf vegetation. In a subarctic region, 60-80% of diet was aquatic vegetation, primarily sedges (Carex) (Milligan and Humphries 2010).
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2016 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Severud et al. 2013 The American Midland Naturalist; Milligan and Humphries 2010 Oikos
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Rodents possess hindgut caecum fermentation systems. Hindgut caecum fermenters are generally smaller-bodied than hindgut colon fermenters. In colon fermenters the caecum is largely modified to become part of the colon, whereas in caecum fermenters, they remain separate structures. Caecums are generally modified into complex structures that retain solutes and fine particles for fermentation while larger particles are excreted through colon, reducing the extent of plant-wall breakdown.
Habitat.Notes: A classic aquatic / semi-aquatic ecosystem engineer of rivers, streams, and lakes. Ranges from the Arctic to subtropical desert.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2016 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Milligan and Humphries 2010 Oikos; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Common.Name: Eurasian Beaver
Diet.Notes: Diet is primarily woody vegetation and emergent herbaceous vegetation, which however does include a substantial amount of graminoids. Eurasian beavers prefer willows and aspens, but will also consume maples, alders, and oaks. Of felled trees they consume inner cambium, branches, and leaves.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2016 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Law et al. 2014 Aquatic Botany
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Rodents possess hindgut caecum fermentation systems. Hindgut caecum fermenters are generally smaller-bodied than hindgut colon fermenters. In colon fermenters the caecum is largely modified to become part of the colon, whereas in caecum fermenters, they remain separate structures. Caecums are generally modified into complex structures that retain solutes and fine particles for fermentation while larger particles are excreted through colon, reducing the extent of plant-wall breakdown.
Habitat.Notes: A classic aquatic / semi-aquatic ecosystem engineer of rivers, streams, and lakes. Ranges from far Northern to Southern Europe.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2016 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Common.Name: Giant Beaver
Mass.Notes: The estimate is mean of the range (60-100 kg) given by the author, though they mention a range of 50-100 kg elsewhere in the paper.
Mass.Reference: Davis 2017 Proceedings of the Royal Society B; Reynolds 2002 Journal of Mammalogy
Diet.Notes: Plint et al. 2019 analyzed bone collagen isotopes of 11 giant beavers. They found that their isotopic diet profile matched muskrats, whose diet consists primarily of submerged aquatic macrophytes. Thus there is little evidence of tree cutting or consumption of woody plants. No other empirical evidence found.
Diet.Reference: Plint et al. 2019 Scientific Reports
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Extant beavers (21-19kg) possess caecum based digestive systems. other than the capybara (45kg) there are few extant species, with caecum digestive systems and body masses much above 10kg (Hume 2002). However, given that capybaras are rodents like beavers, we will make an inferential leap that these large rodents retained caecum digestive systems
Fermentation.Type.Reference: Hume 2002 Acta Zoologica Sinica; Clauss et al. 2003 Oecologia
Habitat.Notes: This massive, beaver most likely did not build dams, but possess (semi)aquatic morphology.
Habitat.Reference: Rybczynski 2007 Journal of Mammalian Evolution

Common.Name: Dwarf Cassowary
Mass.Notes: This estimate is based on an unknown number of individuals of unknown sex. We collected this value from Dunning 2008 CRC Handbook of Avian Body Masses. This book is a collection of published literature about bird masses and is not the primary source of these estimates.
Mass.Reference: Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; Dunning 2008 CRC Handbook of Avian Body Masses
Diet.Notes: Diet is almost entirely fruit, with minor contributions from flowers, fungus, nd some limited scavenging.
Diet.Reference: Birds of the World 2020 Cornell Lab of Ornithology; Wright 2005 Tropical fruits and frugivores
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Cassuaries have an even simpler stomach than emus with a small caecum and colon and little to no fermentation. They subsist on absorbing readily available nutrients from their foods and thus require a high quality diet.  It should be noted that all ratites lack crops (Sales 2006)
Fermentation.Type.Reference: Sales 2006 Avian and Poultry Biology Reviews
Limb.Morphology.Notes: Other than the miharung, which was unguligrade, and loons and grebes, which are plantigrade, all other birds are digitigrade
Habitat.Notes: Elusive animals of dense forests, who likely use aquatic habitats to some extent, but no indication of obligate water use or specialized adaptations.
Habitat.Reference: Birds of the World 2020 Cornell Lab of Ornithology

Common.Name: Southern Cassowary
Mass.Notes: This estimate is based on an unknown number of individuals of both sexes. We collected this value from Dunning 2008 CRC Handbook of Avian Body Masses. This book is a collection of published literature about bird masses and is not the primary source of these estimates.
Mass.Reference: Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; Dunning 2008 CRC Handbook of Avian Body Masses
Diet.Notes: In Queensland, diet is 99% fruit, with less than 1% flowers, fungus, hair, and bone.
Diet.Reference: Birds of the World 2020 Cornell Lab of Ornithology; Bradford et al. 2008 Biotropica
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Cassuaries have an even simpler stomach than emus with a small caecum and colon and little to no fermentation. They subsist on absorbing readily available nutrients from their foods and thus require a high quality diet.  It should be noted that all ratites lack crops (Sales 2006)
Fermentation.Type.Reference: Sales 2006 Avian and Poultry Biology Reviews

Habitat.Notes: Elusive animals of dense forests, who likely use aquatic habitats to some extent, but no indication of obligate water use or specialized adaptations.
Habitat.Reference: Birds of the World 2020 Cornell Lab of Ornithology

Common.Name: Northern Cassowary
Mass.Notes: This estimate is based the average of the male and female body size. The male mass estimate is based on an unknown number of individuals. The female mass estimate is based on one individual. We collected this value from Dunning 2008 CRC Handbook of Avian Body Masses. This book is a collection of published literature about bird masses and is not the primary source of these estimates.
Mass.Reference: Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; Dunning 2008 CRC Handbook of Avian Body Masses
Diet.Method: Expert Opinion; Observed low sample size (1-5) foraging
Diet.Notes: Diet appears to consist mostly of fruits, supplemented with small animals and fungi, however there is little empirical evidence for this species. The only empirical evidence found constrained its fecal analysis to palm seeds and the study is unavailable.
Diet.Reference: Birds of the World 2020 Cornell Lab of Ornithology; Pangau-Adam and Muhlenberg 2014 Palms
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Cassuaries have an even simpler stomach than emus with a small caecum and colon and little to no fermentation. They subsist on absorbing readily available nutrients from their foods and thus require a high quality diet. It should be noted that all ratites lack crops (Sales 2006)
Fermentation.Type.Reference: Sales 2006 Avian and Poultry Biology Reviews
Limb.Morphology.Notes: Other than the miharung, which was unguligrade, and loons and grebes, which are plantigrade, all other birds are digitigrade
Habitat.Notes: Elusive animals of dense forests, who likely use aquatic habitats to some extent, but no indication of obligate water use or specialized adaptations.
Habitat.Reference: Birds of the World 2020 Cornell Lab of Ornithology

Diet.Notes: Teeth indicate browsing. No other evidence. All peccaries are reported frequently having small amounts of insect and vertebrate matter in their stomachs and have been observed feeding on carrion and killing small mammals. Thus inferring a 1 for meat across peccaries.
Diet.Reference: Missagia et al. 2016 International Journal of Biodiversity
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Peccaries have sacciform foregut digestive systems like hippos and camels, except unlike camels they do not ruminate (e.g. regurgitate partially fermented food for secondary mechanical grinding).
Habitat.Notes: Denizen of arid to semi-arid habitat; Considered to be a cursor and inhabitant of open environments
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; Gasparini et al. 2010 Alcheringa; Gasparini et al. 2009 Neues Jahrbuch fur Geologie und Palaontologie-Abhandlungen

Common.Name: Chacoan Peccary
Diet.Notes: Forages on roots of bromeliads, fruits, flowers, and forbs. All peccaries are reported frequently having small amounts of insect and vertebrate matter in their stomachs and have been observed feeding on carrion and killing small mammals. Thus inferring a 1 for meat across peccaries.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Peccaries have sacciform foregut digestive systems like hippos and camels, except unlike camels they do not ruminate (e.g. regurgitate partially fermented food for secondary mechanical grinding).
Fermentation.Type.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Hume 2002 Acta Zoologica Sinica
Habitat.Notes: A species of the dry Chaco of western Paragua, southeastern Boliva, and northern Argentina. Occupies dense, thorn forests in hot, low rainfall zones. Can be found, but at lower densities, in open woodland.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Mass.Notes: Skull measurement not specified. Comparison species is Valgipes deformis
Diet.Method: Expert Opinion; Observed coprolites (Family); Proxy isotopes (C13)
Diet.Notes: Isotopes indicate a diet primarily of C4 grasses, but also a substantial amount of fruits (23%) and leaves (10%) (Dantas et al. 2020). Coprolites, identified to family Mylodontidae, in Cerro Casa de Piedra, were dominated by grasses, followed by forbs and shrubs (Velazquez et al. 2015 Quaternary International)
Diet.Reference: Pereira et al. 2013 Journal of South American Earth Sciences; Dantas et al. 2020 Quaternary Science Reviews; Velazquez et al. 2015 Quaternary International
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Smith et al. 2010 Nature Geoscience lists sloths as hindgut fermenters, because of their body size. However, all extant sloth species are foregut fermenters (Clauss 2004 Mammal Review). Fermentation type is a conservative trait, and extant two-toed and three-toed sloth species are more closely related to various of the now-extinct ground sloths than they are to each other (Pujos et al. 2012 Journal of Mammalian Evolution; Presslee et al. 2019 Nature Ecology and Evolution). Foregut fermentation is either the ancestral fermentation type of all sloth species, or it evolved at least twice in distinct (extant) sloth lineages. The most parsimonious fermentation type for extinct sloths would thus be foregut fermentation. However, Megatheriids pose a biological anamoly as there are no foregut fermentation species known at those body sizes (largest known was Sivatherium, a giraffid at 1250 kg). Vizcaino et al. 2006 and Clauss et al. 2003 suggests therefore that the extremely large Megatheriid sloths (Genera Megatherium and Eremotherium) may have been hindgut fermenters. As is, without better evidence, we will consider all sloths outliers in the ilk of Sivatherium and classify them as foregut fermenters until better evidence is available.
Fermentation.Type.Reference: McDonald and Pelikan 2006 Quaternary International; Clauss 2004 Mammal Review; Pujos et al. 2012 Journal of Mammalian Evolution; Presslee et al. 2019 Nature Ecology and Evolution; Vizcaino et al. 2006 Ameghiniana; Clauss et al. 2003 Oecologia
Limb.Morphology.Notes: Quantitative geometric morphometrics suggest this family was especially adapted for digging (de Oliveira and Santos 2008)
Limb.Morphology.Reference: Naish 2012 Tetrapod Zoology; de Oliveira and Santos 2018 Journal of Morphology
Habitat.Notes: Functional morphology suggests a terrestrial habit.
Habitat.Reference: Pujos et al. 2012 Journal of Mammalian Evolution

Common.Name: Peters' Duiker
Diet.Notes: One of the most frugivorous of duikers. Fruits compose 83-90% of diet, followed by leaves. This varies seasonally with leaves becoming a substantial portion of diet when fruit is not available.
Diet.Reference: Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: Inhabitants of moist, lowland forest, preferring heterogenous undergrowth and thus amenable to logging and other land-uses.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa

Common.Name: Bay Duiker
Diet.Method: Functional craniodental morphology; Observed fecal analysis; Proxy dental wear (mesowear)
Diet.Notes: Bay duikers are primarily frugivorous.
Diet.Reference: Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa; Gautier Hion et al. 1980 Oecologia; Louys et al. 2011 Journal of Archaeological Science
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: Bay duikers are inhabitants of dense, lowland rainforests with a preference for primary forest.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa

Common.Name: Harvey's Duiker
Diet.Notes: More folivorous than other duikers
Diet.Reference: Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: Harvey's duiker inhabit moist coastal forests and riverine gallery forests. Although occurring in drier forest, they prefer to be in proximity to water.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa

Common.Name: Jentink's Duiker
Diet.Method: Observed low sample size (1-5) foraging observation
Diet.Notes: Handbook of the Mammals of the World indicates diet information is andecdotal, Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa reports the same. Little is known about this species, yet, if they are most likely frugivorous.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: Jentink's duiker occurs in dense primary forests but also secondary scrubland in the periphery of these forests. They hide in hollow logs, and dense underbrush. Will visit coast to consume salt.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa

Common.Name: White-bellied Duiker
Diet.Method: Functional craniodental morphology; Observed fecal analysis; Proxy dental wear (mesowear)
Diet.Notes: 75% of stomach contents were fruit (n=3). Potentially the most dedicated frugivore among duikers.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa; Louys et al. 2011 Journal of Archaeological Science
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: This species is restricted to intact and extensive tropical moist forest. They range from upland to lowland but avoid swamp forests and savanna-forest ecotones.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa

Common.Name: Natal Red Duiker
Diet.Notes: Stomach analysis (n=19) found 66% leaf content, 25% fruits and seeds, and 1% flowers
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: Denizens of dense forests and thickets, occurring in riverine forests, wooded ravines, and dense coast scrub.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa

Common.Name: Black Duiker
Diet.Method: Functional craniodental morphology; Observed fecal analysis; Proxy dental wear (mesowear)
Diet.Notes: Frugivore. Classified as browser.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa; Louys et al. 2011 Journal of Archaeological Science
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: This species is most common in disturbed, secondary forests. Prefers secondary bush and riparian habitats.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa

Common.Name: Black-fronted Duiker
Diet.Method: Functional craniodental morphology; Observed fecal analysis; Proxy dental wear (mesowear)
Diet.Notes: Black-fronted duikers primarily consume fruits and leaves, with substantial geographic variation in species and percentages.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa; Louys et al. 2011 Journal of Archaeological Science
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: Black-fronted duikers prefer swampy, water-logged habitats along streams, for which its elongated hooves are well adapted. Also occurs in upland areas where it is less closely associated with aquatic, marshy habitats, but this appears to be a 'derived' habitat association.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa

Common.Name: Ogilby's Duiker
Diet.Notes: This is relatively recently described species, apparently with similar diet as its congeners
Diet.Reference: Gautier Hion and Gautier 1994 Revue dEcologie
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: This duiker species has broad habitat affinities, occurring in primary and secondary forests and in forest-savanna mosaics.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa

Common.Name: Red-flanked Duiker
Diet.Notes: Red-flanked duikers are browsers/frugivores, supplemented with some meat consumption
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: This species prefers forest-edges in savannoid habitats, particularly riparian woodlands and dense vegetation close to permanent sources of water.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa

Common.Name: Yellow-backed Duiker
Diet.Method: Functional craniodental morphology; Observed fecal analysis; Proxy dental wear (mesowear)
Diet.Notes: Fruits, pods, and seeds are ~80% of diet (stomach analysis). Incredibly, they have been observed capturing and killing pigeons and eating carrion.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa; Louys et al. 2011 Journal of Archaeological Science
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: This species dwells in lowland montane primary and secondary forests and in forest fragments in forest-savanna mosaic ecotones. Can survive well in riparian strips and fragmented woodlands.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa

Common.Name: Abbott's Duiker
Diet.Method: Observed low sample size (1-5) foraging observation
Diet.Notes: Abbott's duiker have been observed eating various types of browse, fruit, frogs, and tubers.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: This species prefers montane forests, including semi-deciduous to evergreen woodlands, and bamboo forests.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa

Common.Name: Weyns's Duiker
Diet.Method: Functional craniodental morphology; Observed fecal analysis; Proxy dental wear (mesowear)
Diet.Notes: Frugivore. Classified as browser here however. Stomach analyses show 18-100% of contents are fruit, followed by foliage, seeds, fallen flowers, and fungi.
Diet.Reference: Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa; Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Louys et al. 2011 Journal of Archaeological Science
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: Habitat affinities vary from the Congo, where this species prefers extensive closed forests, to East Africa where it occurs in small and isolated forest remnants. Avoids swamplands and monotypic forests.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa

Common.Name: Zebra Duiker
Diet.Notes: Stomach contents of 4 individuals were 79% fruit and seeds. Little else is known about this species' diet.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: This species prefers undisturbed lowland, primary forests, but has been detected in low montane and hill forests.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa

Common.Name: White Rhinoceros
Diet.Notes: A true, strict grazer. Forbs compose <1% of diet, with no records of browsing. They favor short-grass swards in the wet season, and tall grasses in the dry season. In their recent review of extant rhino diets, Hullot et al. 2019, confirmed this dietary classification.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa; Hullot et al. 2019 Mammal Research
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Hindgut colon fermenting species sacrifice fermentation efficiency (e.g. completeness) for rate of passage. Cell-walls are only partially digested, but without the chokepoint provided by the rumen, they can continually consume vegetation thus meeting their nutrient demands. As such they are also able to consume lower-quality vegetation.
Limb.Morphology.Notes: Technically unguligrade, but modified with thick fleshy pads to hold weight, therefore functionally more similar to digitigrade
Habitat.Notes: A grassland or savanna species. Like black rhinos and unlike Asian rhinos, they are poor swimmers but do wallow.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Common.Name: Elk moose; Stag-moose
Mass.Notes: Primary source inaccessible
Diet.Notes: No empirical evidence found.
Diet.Reference: Geist 1998 Deer of the world: their evolution, behaviour, and ecology
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Method: Inferred from absence of evidence; Inferred from habitat association (pollen analysis)
Habitat.Notes: This species lived in non-analog tundra - deciduous - conifer habitat. No indication of aquatic habitat use.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; Schubert et al. 2004 Quaternary Research

Common.Name: White-lipped Deer
Diet.Notes: An intermediate feeder that prefers grasses and sedges, but consumes a mixed diet of leaves, and woody plants.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: White-lipped deer are high elevation specialists of scrub and alpine grassland, above tree line. Their adaptations, including short legs, massive haunches, and broad hooves, predispose them for steep terrain
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Common.Name: Ryukyu island deer
Mass.Notes: Based on the cubic ratio of radius length as compared to Cervus nippon
Mass.Reference: Raia et al. 2010 Global Ecology and Biogeography
Diet.Notes: Isotopes and dental wear indicate a broad diet of C3 vegetation and probably <5% C4. This supports theories that the incredibly long lifespan of these island deer (~26 years) drove their hypsodonty, not adaptations for abrasive forage.
Diet.Reference: Kubo et al. 2015 Palaeogeography, Palaeoclimatology, Palaeoecology
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Method: Observed low sample size (1-5) habitat use; Inferred from absence of evidence
Habitat.Notes: No evidence of aquatic habitat use in this species or extant relatives
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Common.Name: Wapiti
Mass.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World
Diet.Notes: Prefers graminoids, followed by forbs. In winter, this species survives on woody browse.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: High habitat flexibility, ranging from forested mountain habitats to open grasslands and chaparral scrub. Limited by snow > 70-75 cm.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Common.Name: Red Deer
Mass.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World
Diet.Notes: Often considered a grazer, but that is probably from lumping forbs with grasses. In over 50 years of studies from Europe, Spitzer et al. 2020 report that grass composed ~38% of diet content.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Spitzer et al. 2020 Oikos
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: Highly adaptable, like C. canadensis. Occurs in woodland-grassland interfaces, mediterranean scrub, alpine meadows, and moors, as well as broadleafed woodlands with meadows.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Common.Name: Sika Deer
Diet.Method: Observed fecal analysis; Proxy dental wear (mesowear)
Diet.Notes: In one study, sika deer ate almost exclusively senesced, dropped leaf litter that was already yellow or brown (Agetsuma et al. 2011). For the most part browsers (in some places primarily of bamboo, which authors consider 'graze'). However, grass also shows up in the diet substantially (>25%)
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Rivals et al. 2014 Journal of Mammalogy; Agetsuma et al. 2011 Mammalian Biology
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: Denizen of woodlands with dense undergrowth, but with adjacent open areas. Limited by snow-depth, with depths over 40 cm limiting their distribution.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Common.Name: Pygmy Hippopotamus
Diet.Notes: Little is known from wild populations, but thought to primarily be browsers and to consume leaves, aquatic plants, fallen fruit, and roots and tubers. Given the importance of graminoids in wetland systems, and their nutritious tubers, it would be unlikely that they do not consume some graminoids
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Hippos are the largest extant foregut digesting species, topped only by Sivatherium, the giant giraffids of the Miocene, which reached ~1,250 kg. Like camelids and kangaroos, they have foregut fermentation systems that are less complex than ruminants and thus have reduced fermentation efficiency but are better able to subsist on higher quantities of lower nutrient foods.
Fermentation.Type.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Hume 2002 Acta Zoologica Sinica
Habitat.Notes: A species of dense woodlands in West Africa, preferring streams in forests and areas with low-hanging palm trees.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Common.Name: South Island Goose
Mass.Reference: Worthy and Holdaway 2002 The lost world of the moa: prehistoric life of New Zealand
Diet.Notes: Considered related to the Cape Barren Goose of Australia (Cereopsis novaehollandiae) (Worthy et al. 2009), which is a grazer but also consumes forbs and succulents. No detailed, empirical dietary analysis found.
Diet.Reference: Worthy et al. 2009 Journal of Zoology; The Australia Museum 2019
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Geese mechanically grind food with their especially strong muscular gizzard and then ferment it in their caecums, as well as in their large intestines. This allows geese to digest more fiber than similar sized ducks or galliformes, however they still digest significantly less cellulose than similar sized mammalian herbivores (Buchsbaum et al. 1986). Geese possess medium to large caecums (Clench and Mathias 1995) which allow digestion of ~28% of the cellulose and 25% of the hemicellulose present in their food (Buschbaum et al. 1986)
Fermentation.Type.Reference: Buckland and Guy 2002 Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations; Buchsbaum et al. 1986 Ecology; Clench and Mathias 1995 Wilson Bulletin
Limb.Morphology.Notes: Other than the miharung, which was unguligrade, and loons and grebes, which are plantigrade, all other birds are digitigrade
Habitat.Notes: No empirical evidence found. Wikipedia describes these birds as terrestrial, similar to the Hawaiian nene in their reduction of foot webbing, however no source is given. New Zealand Organisms Register classifies them as terrestrial as well.
Habitat.Reference: New Zealand Organisms Register 2020; Wikipedia 2020

Common.Name: North Island Goose
Mass.Reference: Worthy and Holdaway 2002 The lost world of the moa: prehistoric life of New Zealand
Diet.Notes: Considered related to the Cape Barren Goose of Australia (Cereopsis novaehollandiae) (Worthy et al. 1997), which is a grazer but also consumes forbs and succulents. No detailed, empirical dietary analysis found.
Diet.Reference: Worthy et al. 2009 Journal of Zoology; The Australia Museum 2019
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Geese mechanically grind food with their especially strong muscular gizzard and then ferment it in their caecums, as well as in their large intestines. This allows geese to digest more fiber than similar sized ducks or galliformes, however they still digest significantly less cellulose than similar sized mammalian herbivores (Buchsbaum et al. 1986). Geese possess medium to large caecums (Clench and Mathias 1995) which allow digestion of ~28% of the cellulose and 25% of the hemicellulose present in their food (Buschbaum et al. 1986)
Fermentation.Type.Reference: Buckland and Guy 2002 Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations; Buchsbaum et al. 1986 Ecology; Clench and Mathias 1995 Wilson Bulletin
Limb.Morphology.Notes: Other than the miharung, which was unguligrade, and loons and grebes, which are plantigrade, all other birds are digitigrade
Habitat.Notes: No empirical evidence found. Wikipedia describes these birds as terrestrial, similar to the Hawaiian nene in their reduction of foot webbing, however no source is given. New Zealand Organisms Register classifies them as terrestrial as well.
Habitat.Reference: New Zealand Organisms Register 2020; Wikipedia 2020

Common.Name: Wooly Rhinoceros
Mass.Notes: Asensio et al. 2004 do not specify which of these methods was used for this species. They simply states '[For perissodactyla] body masses were calculated using dental measurements and Janis equations (1990). Only when there were no dental data available did we use post-cranial measurements and Scotts equations (1990) to estimate body mass'. Also that a different version of this manuscript exists, with Prado as first author.
Diet.Method: Observed low sample size (1-5) fossil evidence (preserved horn isotopes); Observed low sample size (1-5) fossil evidence (stomach); Proxy dental wear (microwear and mesowear); Proxy isotopes (C13, N15)
Diet.Notes: Isotopic analysis of a permafrost preserved horn indicate that they were summer grazers and winter browsers, though study is somewhat speculative. Micro and meso wear indicate clear preference for grazing (Rivals and Lister 2016). Pollen analysis of a preserved stomach indicated grass and sagebrush (Artemesia) were the primary component of the diet of that single permafrost preserved individual. Stefaniak et al. 2020 compile available evidence and report new isotopic data, concluding that this species was primarily a grazer, including of Carex, though it supplemented its diet with foliage of woody plants at different times of year and in different regions.
Diet.Reference: Tiunov and Kirillova 2010 Rapid Communications in Mass Spectrometry; Rivals and Lister 2016 Quaternary Science Reviews; Boeskorov et al. 2011 Quaternary Science Reviews; Stefaniak et al. 2020 Quaternary International
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Hindgut colon fermenting species sacrifice fermentation efficiency (e.g. completeness) for rate of passage. Cell-walls are only partially digested, but without the chokepoint provided by the rumen, they can continually consume vegetation thus meeting their nutrient demands. As such they are also able to consume lower-quality vegetation.
Limb.Morphology.Notes: Technically unguligrade, but modified with thick fleshy pads to hold weight, therefore functionally more similar to digitigrade
Habitat.Method: Inferred from Genus; Inferred from absence of evidence; Inferred from habitat association (proxy isotopes C13, N15); Inferred from habitat association (pollen analysis)
Habitat.Notes: Denizens of open arctic steppe, until these environements became more forested, which does not appear to have led to their extinction (Kuzmin 2010). No evidence to suggest aquatic habits, though diet in at least one study area appears to have been dominated by Carex. They appear to have been denizens of open woodlands and meadows.
Habitat.Reference: Kuzmin 2010 Boreas; Stefaniak et al. 2020 Quaternary International

Common.Name: Angolan Colobus
Mass.Reference: Kelt and Meyer 2008 Global Ecology and Biogeography
Diet.Notes: Primarily folivorous, although also consumes seeds, fruit pulp, flowers, and lichen.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2013 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Colobin monkeys appear to be the sole primate group that has developed foregut, non-ruminant fermentation.
Fermentation.Type.Reference: Hume 2002 Acta Zoologica Sinica; Lambert 1998 Evolutionary Anthropology; Nijboer and Clauss 2006 Thesis
