Habitat.Notes: Dwell in primary and secondary lowland rainforest and gallery forest, as well as montane forests up to 3000-4000 m. They prefer the highest levels of forest canopy, but will occassionally descend to ground to feed on herbaceous vegetation. Does not seem to constitute enough terrestrial use to be 'semi-arboreal'
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2013 Handbook of the Mammals of the World

Common.Name: Guereza
Mass.Reference: Kelt and Meyer 2008 Global Ecology and Biogeography
Diet.Notes: Extremely variable diet between populations, with some showing more folivory than known in any other primate (89%), while in other locations diet is 44%-81% fruit.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2013 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Colobin monkeys appear to be the sole primate group that has developed foregut, non-ruminant fermentation.
Fermentation.Type.Reference: Hume 2002 Acta Zoologica Sinica; Lambert 1998 Evolutionary Anthropology; Nijboer and Clauss 2006 Thesis
Habitat.Notes: This species prefers disturbed secondary forests, potentially because of increased tree diversity or reduced secondary defenses. Prefers highest canopy.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2013 Handbook of the Mammals of the World

Common.Name: Black Colobus
Mass.Reference: Kelt and Meyer 2008 Global Ecology and Biogeography
Diet.Notes: 53-56% of diet are seeds, followed by leaves (38%). Seeds are preferred, then young leaves, then mature leaves.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2013 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Colobin monkeys appear to be the sole primate group that has developed foregut, non-ruminant fermentation.
Fermentation.Type.Reference: Hume 2002 Acta Zoologica Sinica; Lambert 1998 Evolutionary Anthropology; Nijboer and Clauss 2006 Thesis
Habitat.Notes: This species dwells in dense primary or old secondary rainforests, as well as coastal evergreen, lowland moist, montane, and swamp forests. Occassionally seen in coastal sand dune meadow woodlands. Stays high in canopy.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2013 Handbook of the Mammals of the World

Common.Name: White-thighed Colobus
Mass.Reference: Kelt and Meyer 2008 Global Ecology and Biogeography
Diet.Notes: Primarily folivorous (79% of diet), with fruits and seeds composing 11%.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2013 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Colobin monkeys appear to be the sole primate group that has developed foregut, non-ruminant fermentation.
Fermentation.Type.Reference: Hume 2002 Acta Zoologica Sinica; Lambert 1998 Evolutionary Anthropology; Nijboer and Clauss 2006 Thesis
Habitat.Notes: Lowland rainforests, swamp forests, gallery forests, and dry forests. Will dwell in forests patches in savannas which they reach by crossing open terrain.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2013 Handbook of the Mammals of the World

Common.Name: Black Wildebeest
Diet.Notes: Considered hypergrazers from observation, proxy isotopes, and stomach contents. Their diet is almost exclusively grasses.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: This species is strongly associated with open plains and karoo shrublands. No mention of aquatic affinity.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa

Common.Name: Common Wildebeest
Diet.Method: Observed fecal analysis; Observed foraging; Proxy isotopes (C13)
Diet.Notes: Common wildebeest have diets primarily comprised of graze (~65%-87%) and shrubs (25%-10%). Evidence from feeding experiments suggests they prefer to consume grass. Assigning a 1 to browse following the median of their observed browse consumption.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: Closely associated with shortgrass grassland and Acacia savanna. Avoids wetlands, preferring well-drained soils with firm footing.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa

Common.Name: Gomphothere
Mass.Notes: The mass value is the mean of the two best mass estimates from forelimb and hindlimb bones given by author. These are based, respetively, on the humerus diaphysis anteroposterior diameter and the fibula circumference
Mass.Reference: Davis 2017 Proceedings of the Royal Society B; Christiansen 2004 Zoological Journal of the Linnean Society
Diet.Method: Functional craniodental morphology; Proxy isotopes (C13, O18)
Diet.Notes: Sanchez et al. 2004 analyzed 68 specimens from 24 Middle Pleistocene and Late Pleistocene localities with isotopes (C13, O18). Found them to be mixed feeder in general, but in Bolivia was more of a grazer and in Chile an exclusive browser. In Hidalgo, MX, Bravo-Cuevas et al. 2017 found them to be browsers primarily. MacFadden and Shockey suggest that this taxa was primarily a grazer with principal coordinate analysis. In sum, this suggests they were true mixed feeders.
Diet.Reference: Sanchez et al. 2004 Paleobiology; Bravo Cuevas et al. 2017 Palaeogeography, Palaeoclimatology, Palaeoecology; MacFadden and Shockey 1997 Paleobiology
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Hindgut colon fermenting species sacrifice fermentation efficiency (e.g. completeness) for rate of passage. Cell-walls are only partially digested, but without the chokepoint provided by the rumen, they can continually consume vegetation thus meeting their nutrient demands. As such they are also able to consume lower-quality vegetation.
Habitat.Notes: Extant relatives and diet suggest a terrestrial habit, with only opportunistic use of aquatic environments.

Common.Name: Trumpeter Swan
Mass.Notes: Primary source inaccessible
Mass.Reference: Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; Dunning 2008 CRC Handbook of Avian Body Masses
Diet.Notes: In Yellowstone National Park the diet of trumpeter swans was predominantly aquatic plants, including foliage and their tubers. Diet is well-reviewed by the Cornell Lab of Ornithology who describe trumpeter swans as principally consuming aquatic vegetation during the summer and breeding season. However, in the winter their diet switches to terrestrial plants, including berries, herbs, and grasses. Insects and small fish constiute a minor portion of diet, we believe than 10%. They also feed significantly on grain crops, which we score as browse. Overall, we estimate that this species is 3-1 browsing-grazing
Diet.Reference: Squires and Anderson 1995 American Midland Naturalist; All About Birds 2020 Cornell Lab of Ornithology
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Geese mechanically grind food with their especially strong muscular gizzard and then ferment it in their caecums, as well as in their large intestines. This allows geese to digest more fiber than similar sized ducks or galliformes, however they still digest significantly less cellulose than similar sized mammalian herbivores (Buchsbaum et al. 1986). Geese possess medium to large caecums (Clench and Mathias 1995) which allow digestion of ~28% of the cellulose and 25% of the hemicellulose present in their food (Buschbaum et al. 1986)
Fermentation.Type.Reference: Buckland and Guy 2002 Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations; Buchsbaum et al. 1986 Ecology; Clench and Mathias 1995 Wilson Bulletin
Limb.Morphology.Notes: Other than the miharung, which was unguligrade, and loons and grebes, which are plantigrade, all other birds are digitigrade
Habitat.Notes: The diet of this swan is a mixture of terrestrial and aquatic vegetation. Though their breeding cycle and migration cycle predominantly rely on aquatic habits, they can forage significantly in terrestrial environments, where they mow grass and eat fallen grain.
Habitat.Reference: Squires and Anderson 1995 American Midland Naturalist; All About Birds 2020 Cornell Lab of Ornithology; Birds of the World 2020 Cornell Lab of Ornithology

Common.Name: Maltese Swan
Mass.Notes: This mass estimates assumes that Cygnus falconeri was anatomically similar to Cygnus cygnus.
Diet.Notes: No empirical proxy evidence regarding the diet of this goose.
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Geese mechanically grind food with their especially strong muscular gizzard and then ferment it in their caecums, as well as in their large intestines. This allows geese to digest more fiber than similar sized ducks or galliformes, however they still digest significantly less cellulose than similar sized mammalian herbivores (Buchsbaum et al. 1986). Geese possess medium to large caecums (Clench and Mathias 1995) which allow digestion of ~28% of the cellulose and 25% of the hemicellulose present in their food (Buschbaum et al. 1986)
Fermentation.Type.Reference: Buckland and Guy 2002 Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations; Buchsbaum et al. 1986 Ecology; Clench and Mathias 1995 Wilson Bulletin
Limb.Morphology.Notes: Other than the miharung, which was unguligrade, and loons and grebes, which are plantigrade, all other birds are digitigrade
Habitat.Notes: There is little published about this very large swan. Their body mass suggests that they may have been flightless (Alcover 2000). Given the lack of description of any specialized derivation from swan-hood other than body mass, we suspect that they had a similar terrestrial and aquatic habit.
Habitat.Reference: Alcover 2000 Tropics

Common.Name: Mute Swan
Mass.Notes: Primary source inaccessible
Mass.Reference: Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; Dunning 2008 CRC Handbook of Avian Body Masses
Diet.Notes: Stomach contents of introduced mute swans in Eastern North America show an almost exclusive diet of aquatic plants, mostly of above ground plant parts. Tubers and aquatic invertebrates were consumed infrequently (Bailey et al. 2008). In their review, Cornell Lab of Ornithology describe consumption of grains (including crop grains) and grasses and of invertebrates, amphibians, and fish, particularly during their molt. Grasses and invertebrates do not appear in these descriptions to constitute enough for be scored as 2 or 1 respectively.
Diet.Reference: Bailey et al. 2008 The Journal of Wildlife Management; All About Birds 2020 Cornell Lab of Ornithology
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Geese mechanically grind food with their especially strong muscular gizzard and then ferment it in their caecums, as well as in their large intestines. This allows geese to digest more fiber than similar sized ducks or galliformes, however they still digest significantly less cellulose than similar sized mammalian herbivores (Buchsbaum et al. 1986). Geese possess medium to large caecums (Clench and Mathias 1995) which allow digestion of ~28% of the cellulose and 25% of the hemicellulose present in their food (Buschbaum et al. 1986)
Fermentation.Type.Reference: Buckland and Guy 2002 Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations; Buchsbaum et al. 1986 Ecology; Clench and Mathias 1995 Wilson Bulletin
Limb.Morphology.Notes: Other than the miharung, which was unguligrade, and loons and grebes, which are plantigrade, all other birds are digitigrade
Habitat.Notes: Like trumpeter swans, mute swans consume a mixture of terrestrial and aquatic vegetation. Though they primarily rely on aquatic habits they  still forage significantly in terrestrial environments, where they mow grass and eat fallen grain.
Habitat.Reference: Bailey et al. 2008 The Journal of Wildlife Management; All About Birds 2020 Cornell Lab of Ornithology; Birds of the World 2020 Cornell Lab of Ornithology

Common.Name: Common Fallow Deer; European Fallow Deer; Fallow Deer
Diet.Notes: Stomach content analysis (n=325) showed variation from graminoid dominance (with broadleaves as well) for summer, to nut mast through fall, to browse during winter. In a huge review, Spitzer et al. 2020 found that Dama dama are the most graminoid-consuming of any European deer species, with grass comprising 56% of diet on average
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Jackson 1977 Journal of Zoology; Spitzer et al. 2020 Oikos
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: A habitat generalist, often in broadleaved forests, with adjacent open terrain, but also in Mediterranean scrubland. Distribution across Europe derives from ancient, Roman, introductions. Original range in Anatolia, Turkey was likely more Mediterranean. Limited by cold temperatures and snow cover.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Common.Name: Persian Fallow Deer
Diet.Notes: Rare, cryptic and little studied. This species is considered an intermediate feeder of thickets and shrublands, probably consuming substantial browse.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Method: Observed low sample size (1-5) habitat use; Inferred from absence of evidence
Habitat.Notes: Only a small, relictual population survives, dwelling in riparian woodlands. Historic habitat affinities remain unknown.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Mass.Method: Inferred from relative of suggested similar size
Mass.Reference: Faith et al. 2012 Palaeogeography, Palaeoclimatology, Palaeoecology
Diet.Method: Proxy dental wear (mesowear); Proxy isotopes (C13, O18)
Diet.Notes: Mesowear and isotopes indicate a grazing diet of C4 grasses.
Diet.Reference: Garrett et al. 2015 Journal of Human Evolution; Rowan et al. 2015 Palaeogeography, Palaeoclimatology, Palaeoecology
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Method: Inferred from Genus; Inferred from absence of evidence
Habitat.Notes: No evidence of aquatic habitat use in this species or extant relatives
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Common.Name: Topi
Diet.Notes: 99-98% of topi stomach contents from one study were graminoids, echoed by carbon isotope studies. Green leaf specialist of fresh grass.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: This species is closely associated with floodplain habitats, and has experienced population declines from hydroelectric development. However, it is unclear the extent to which this species utilizes aquatic habitats per se.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa

Mass.Notes: The authors do not specify whether the estimate is based on anteroposterior tooth lengths or cranial occipital height.
Mass.Reference: Bibi and Kiessling 2015 Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America
Diet.Method: Functional craniodental morphology; Proxy dental wear (microwear); Proxy isotopes (C13, O18)
Diet.Notes: Cluster analysis from mesowear data indicates a grazing diet, which also corresponds to their craniodental morphology. Isotopes (Codron et al. 2008) support this designation as well.
Diet.Reference: Codron et al. 2008 Oikos; Stynder 2009 Quaternary Research
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Method: Inferred from Genus; Inferred from absence of evidence
Habitat.Notes: No evidence of aquatic habitat use in this species or extant relatives
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa

Common.Name: Blesbok
Diet.Notes: 60-90% grass. Otherwise will consume forbs, particularly in burned areas. Confirmed with carbon isotope data.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: This species generally occupies flat or undulating grasslands, usually in the vicinity of surface-water.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa

Common.Name: Beautiful Armadillo
Mass.Notes: McDonald 2005 provides two mass estimates for Dasypus bellus (10.07 kg and 17.68 kg). PHYLACINE v1.2 uses the upper estimate only. Our mass estimates are derived from PHYLACINE so we follow this decision.
Mass.Reference: Davis 2017 Proceedings of the Royal Society B; McDonald 2005 Bulletin of the Florida Museum of Natural History
Diet.Notes: Given its close relation to extant armadillos and lack of specialized grinding teeth, this species is expected to have consumed a variety of insects, fruits, and tubers.
Diet.Reference: McDonald 2005 Bulletin of the Florida Museum of Natural History
Fermentation.Type.Method: Inferred from Order; Inferred from diet
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Hindgut, but type unknown. The extant relatives, armadillos, are insectivores and have simple sac stomachs. Some have suggested the same for glyptodonts (Bocherens et al. 2017 Gondwana Research), but it seems impossible that they would sustain their metabolism as herbivores without fermentation. However, since  this species is omnivorous, much more akin to extant armadillos in diet, we are going to infer 'simple gut'.
Fermentation.Type.Reference: Smith et al. 2010 Nature Geoscience; Bocherens et al. 2017 Gondwana Research
Limb.Morphology.Notes: Plantigrady is one component of a suite of traits, including armor, low metabolism, ability to withstand hypoxia, and other slow life history habits
Limb.Morphology.Reference: Superina and Loughry 2011 Journal of Mammalian Evolution
Habitat.Notes: No published evidence of aquatic habitat use in this species. While some extinct glyptodonts have some weak and contradictory evidence suggesting a semi-aquatic habit, we will not make inferences to this taxa.

Common.Name: Giant aye-aye
Mass.Notes: The estimate is the mean of four different regression estimates based upon humerus (n = 3) midshaft cortical area and four different regression estimates based upon femur (n = 2) midshaft cortical area. The reported body mass estimates are rounded versions of those provided in Fleagle and Gilbert 2008.
Mass.Reference: Werdelin and Sanders 2010 Cenozoic Mammals of Africa; Fleagle and Gilbert 2008 Elwyn Simons a Search for Origins
Diet.Notes: No empirical proxy evidence found.
Diet.Reference: Godfrey et al. 2004 Journal of Human Evolution
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Extant Daubentonia are caecum fermenters. We suspect that the extinct aye-aye was as well, given that its body mass (14kg) is not so large as to make hindgut caecum fermentation unlikely.
Habitat.Notes: This species was likely arboreal given its relation to the extant aye-aye and its similar morphology
Habitat.Reference: Godfrey et al. 2004 Journal of Human Evolution

Common.Name: Bennett's Tree Kangaroo
Diet.Notes: This species is primarily a folivore, consuming the leaves of up to 30 different tree and vine species. They also consume a lesser amount of ripe and unripe fruit, and flowers. Arman and Prideaux 2015 compiled all available diet studies, concluding that this species is a browser.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2015 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Arman and Prideaux 2015 Austral Ecology
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Kangaroos posssess foregut fermentation systems, but instead of them being divided into sacs, they are linear and have higher throughputs - comparable in function to hindgut colon fermentation in fact. Thus this system maximizes material flow and rate of fermentation at the expense of cell wall digestion. The implications of this is that food intake rates are less limited in macropods than in ruminants when foraging high fiber foods: as forage quality decreases ruminants reduce consumption rate (because they require longer fermentation times on high fiber foods), whereas macropod intake rate remains more or less constant.
Fermentation.Type.Reference: Hume 2002 Acta Zoologica Sinica; Dawson et al. 1989 Fauna of Australia
Habitat.Notes: This animal dwells in lowland rainforest up to montane forest. They are nocturnal and primarily active in trees, however, they make regular trips to the ground to travel to other foraging trees.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2015 Handbook of the Mammals of the World

Common.Name: Doria's Tree Kangaroo
Mass.Reference: Flannery et al. 1996 Tree Kangaroos A Curious Natural History
Diet.Method: Expert Opinion; Observed low sample size (1-5) foraging
Diet.Notes: Little known, described consuming leaves and some fruit and feeding both in canopy and on forest floor.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2015 Handbook of the Mammals of the World
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Kangaroos posssess foregut fermentation systems, but instead of them being divided into sacs, they are linear and have higher throughputs - comparable in function to hindgut colon fermentation in fact. Thus this system maximizes material flow and rate of fermentation at the expense of cell wall digestion. The implications of this is that food intake rates are less limited in macropods than in ruminants when foraging high fiber foods: as forage quality decreases ruminants reduce consumption rate (because they require longer fermentation times on high fiber foods), whereas macropod intake rate remains more or less constant.
Fermentation.Type.Reference: Hume 2002 Acta Zoologica Sinica; Dawson et al. 1989 Fauna of Australia
Habitat.Method: Observed low sample size (1-5) habitat use
Habitat.Notes: This animal dwells in mid-montane to upper montane rainforest and alpine scrub. Poorly studied but has been described as foraging both in trees and on the ground.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2015 Handbook of the Mammals of the World

Common.Name: Grizzled Tree Kangaroo
Diet.Method: Expert Opinion; Observed low sample size (1-5) foraging
Diet.Notes: Little empirical evidence of diet, but described as consuming leaves and occasionally fruit. They have also been described feeding from forest floor.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2015 Handbook of the Mammals of the World
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Kangaroos posssess foregut fermentation systems, but instead of them being divided into sacs, they are linear and have higher throughputs - comparable in function to hindgut colon fermentation in fact. Thus this system maximizes material flow and rate of fermentation at the expense of cell wall digestion. The implications of this is that food intake rates are less limited in macropods than in ruminants when foraging high fiber foods: as forage quality decreases ruminants reduce consumption rate (because they require longer fermentation times on high fiber foods), whereas macropod intake rate remains more or less constant.
Fermentation.Type.Reference: Hume 2002 Acta Zoologica Sinica; Dawson et al. 1989 Fauna of Australia
Habitat.Method: Observed low sample size (1-5) habitat use; Inferred from Genus
Habitat.Notes: This species lives in lowland to mid-montane primary and secondary rainforests. This species has received little research attention, so exact use of terrestrial vs arboreal habitats is unclear. Presuming semi-arboreality, following the habit of this genus.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2015 Handbook of the Mammals of the World

Common.Name: Tenkile
Mass.Reference: Flannery 1993 Records of the Australian Museum
Diet.Notes: Tenkiles are folivores feeding on trees, vines, and epiphytes. They forage both in the canopy and on the ground.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2015 Handbook of the Mammals of the World
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Kangaroos posssess foregut fermentation systems, but instead of them being divided into sacs, they are linear and have higher throughputs - comparable in function to hindgut colon fermentation in fact. Thus this system maximizes material flow and rate of fermentation at the expense of cell wall digestion. The implications of this is that food intake rates are less limited in macropods than in ruminants when foraging high fiber foods: as forage quality decreases ruminants reduce consumption rate (because they require longer fermentation times on high fiber foods), whereas macropod intake rate remains more or less constant.
Fermentation.Type.Reference: Hume 2002 Acta Zoologica Sinica; Dawson et al. 1989 Fauna of Australia
Habitat.Method: Observed low sample size (1-5) habitat use; Inferred from Genus
Habitat.Notes: This species lives in montane tropical rainforest, where it forages both on ground and in canopy. This species is poorly studied.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2015 Handbook of the Mammals of the World

Common.Name: Vogelkop Tree Kangaroo
Diet.Method: Expert Opinion; Observed low sample size (1-5) foraging
Diet.Notes: No empirical evidence of diet, but described as consuming leaves and occasionally fruit.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2015 Handbook of the Mammals of the World
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Kangaroos posssess foregut fermentation systems, but instead of them being divided into sacs, they are linear and have higher throughputs - comparable in function to hindgut colon fermentation in fact. Thus this system maximizes material flow and rate of fermentation at the expense of cell wall digestion. The implications of this is that food intake rates are less limited in macropods than in ruminants when foraging high fiber foods: as forage quality decreases ruminants reduce consumption rate (because they require longer fermentation times on high fiber foods), whereas macropod intake rate remains more or less constant.
Fermentation.Type.Reference: Hume 2002 Acta Zoologica Sinica; Dawson et al. 1989 Fauna of Australia
Habitat.Method: Observed low sample size (1-5) habitat use; Inferred from Genus
Habitat.Notes: The Vogelkop tree kangaroo lives in montane tropical rainforest. Largely unstudied. We are designating semi-arboreality based on habit of genus.
Habitat.Reference: Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Mass.Method: Inferred from relative of suggested similar size
Diet.Notes: Pujos et al. 2012 uses the width of mandibular symphysis relative to mandibular length to argue that this genus were browsers. No empirical, proxy evidence found.
Diet.Reference: Pujos et al. 2012 Journal of Mammalian Evolution
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Smith et al. 2010 Nature Geoscience lists sloths as hindgut fermenters, because of their body size. However, all extant sloth species are foregut fermenters (Clauss 2004 Mammal Review). Fermentation type is a conservative trait, and extant two-toed and three-toed sloth species are more closely related to various of the now-extinct ground sloths than they are to each other (Pujos et al. 2012 Journal of Mammalian Evolution; Presslee et al. 2019 Nature Ecology and Evolution). Foregut fermentation is either the ancestral fermentation type of all sloth species, or it evolved at least twice in distinct (extant) sloth lineages. The most parsimonious fermentation type for extinct sloths would thus be foregut fermentation. However, Megatheriids pose a biological anamoly as there are no foregut fermentation species known at those body sizes (largest known was Sivatherium, a giraffid at 1250 kg). Vizcaino et al. 2006 and Clauss et al. 2003 suggests therefore that the extremely large Megatheriid sloths (Genera Megatherium and Eremotherium) may have been hindgut fermenters. As is, without better evidence, we will consider all sloths outliers in the ilk of Sivatherium and classify them as foregut fermenters until better evidence is available.
Fermentation.Type.Reference: McDonald and Pelikan 2006 Quaternary International; Clauss 2004 Mammal Review; Pujos et al. 2012 Journal of Mammalian Evolution; Presslee et al. 2019 Nature Ecology and Evolution; Vizcaino et al. 2006 Ameghiniana; Clauss et al. 2003 Oecologia
Limb.Morphology.Notes: Most taxa had the capacity, given their wide structural vertebral, to forage upright, resting on their tail. Appendicular morphology, particularly of the humerus, of all sloth families, other than the Mylodontidae, suggest a generalized locomotion habit (de Oliveira and Santos 2008).
Limb.Morphology.Reference: Naish 2012 Tetrapod Zoology; de Oliveira and Santos 2018 Journal of Morphology
Habitat.Notes: Functional morphology suggests a semi-arboreal habit, but this could have been of cliffs instead of trees.
Habitat.Reference: Pujos et al. 2007 Zoological Journal of the Linnean Society; Pujos et al. 2012 Journal of Mammalian Evolution

Common.Name: Sumatran Rhinoceros
Diet.Notes: Hullot et al. 2019 reviewed the diet of this species, which is highly folivorous. They eat a substantial amount of bamboo as well, but we are classifying that as browsing.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Hullot et al. 2019 Mammal Research
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Hindgut colon fermenting species sacrifice fermentation efficiency (e.g. completeness) for rate of passage. Cell-walls are only partially digested, but without the chokepoint provided by the rumen, they can continually consume vegetation thus meeting their nutrient demands. As such they are also able to consume lower-quality vegetation.
Limb.Morphology.Notes: Technically unguligrade, but modified with thick fleshy pads to hold weight, therefore functionally more similar to digitigrade
Habitat.Notes: This species is a generalist from lowland forests to high-elevation cloud forests. They are an excellent swimmer, having swum to small islands of the coast. Seem to prefer more heterogeneous, semi-disturbed forests to more homogeneous primary forests. They appear to require mud to avoid skin cracking and spend considerable amounts of time, potentially most of the day, in aquatic habitats. It is debatable whether they should be scored as semi-aquatic, but given that that aquatic habitats appear to be obligate for them, and they significant disturbance and nutrient inputs they must contribute to aquatic ecosystems, will score as semi-aquatic.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Common.Name: Black Rhinoceros
Diet.Notes: From Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa's summary: black rhinos are strict browsers of shrubs and forbs. During the wet season, when grasses grow up over shrubs and forbs grass may compose up to 10% of diet simply by accidental ingestion. Prefers Euphorbia, Grewia, and Acacia. Will push down trees to access browse above 2m. In their recent review of extant rhino diets, Hullot et al. 2019, confirmed this dietary classification.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa; Hullot et al. 2019 Mammal Research
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Hindgut colon fermenting species sacrifice fermentation efficiency (e.g. completeness) for rate of passage. Cell-walls are only partially digested, but without the chokepoint provided by the rumen, they can continually consume vegetation thus meeting their nutrient demands. As such they are also able to consume lower-quality vegetation.
Limb.Morphology.Notes: Technically unguligrade, but modified with thick fleshy pads to hold weight, therefore functionally more similar to digitigrade
Habitat.Notes: This species as well as white rhinos, unlike the Asian rhinos, are poor swimmers that will drown if they lose footing in deep water. While a poor swimmer, wallowing is important to this species as is the presence of surface-water, though they can go 5-days without drinking during dispersal. This species occurs across many habitat types, but particularly in mesic savanna, wetter montane forests, mesic dune forests, and semi-deserts. Do not occur in rainforests, potentially because of inability to thermoregulate in the humidity or because of absence of food.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Mass.Notes: Comparison species is Candiacervus cretensis
Diet.Notes: Isotopes and dental wear indicate a strict diet of browse. Little else known.
Diet.Reference: Kubo et al. 2015 Palaeogeography, Palaeoclimatology, Palaeoecology
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Method: Observed low sample size (1-5) habitat use; Inferred from absence of evidence
Habitat.Notes: No evidence of aquatic habitat use in this species or extant relatives
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Common.Name: Pacarana
Diet.Method: Expert Opinion; Observed low sample size (1-5) foraging
Diet.Notes: Wilson and Mittermeier describe this species as a generalist herbivore, consuming a variety of plants parts: from leaves and stems to roots, tubers, fruits, seeds, and nuts. Given that this species is a generalist, to be conservative we scored a 1 for graminoids, as we highly suspect graminoid tubers or seeds are involved.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2016 Handbook of the Mammals of the World
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Rodents possess hindgut caecum fermentation systems. Hindgut caecum fermenters are generally smaller-bodied than hindgut colon fermenters. In colon fermenters the caecum is largely modified to become part of the colon, whereas in caecum fermenters, they remain separate structures. Caecums are generally modified into complex structures that retain solutes and fine particles for fermentation while larger particles are excreted through colon, reducing the extent of plant-wall breakdown.
Habitat.Notes: The pacarana live in semi-open to closed forests, requiring rocky outcrops for dens. They spend the majority of their time on the ground, but can climb and will do so regularly.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2016 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; White and Alberico 1992 Mammalian Species

Common.Name: North Island Giant Moa
Mass.Notes: The species possessed strong sexual dimorphism. The value is the mean of the median male (56.6 kg) and female (111.976 kg) body mass.
Mass.Reference: Olson and Turvey 2013 Proceedings of the Royal Society B
Diet.Method: Functional craniodental morphology; Inferred from habitat associations
Diet.Notes: Unfortunately no coprolite evidence has been found to indicate the diet of this species. However, based on morphology, it's likely that their diet was similar to D. robustus (Wood et al. 2020). No empirical proxy evidence found
Diet.Reference: Wood et al. 2020 New Zealand Journal of Ecology
Fermentation.Type.Method: Inferred from Infraclass; Inferred from diet
Fermentation.Type.Notes: No empirical evidence nor expert opinions regarding the fermentation type of these birds. Their nearest, albeit distant, relatives are the tinamous of South America (Mitchell et al. 2014, Phillips et al. 2010), who are generalist herbivores with enlarged cecas (Garitano-Zavala et al. 2003). However, given their massive size, and the evolution of colon-based fermentation among other large-bodied ratites (rheas and ostriches), we are going to infer hindgut colon digestion as to the best of our knowledge there are no hindgut ceca fermentating animals of these sizes, and given that other truly herbivorous ratites have colons. However, emus and cassuaries have only simple guts. Also, it should be noted that all ratites lack crops (Sales 2006).
Fermentation.Type.Reference: Sales 2006 Avian and Poultry Biology Reviews; Mitchell et al. 2014 Science; Phillips et al. 2010 Systematic Biology; Garitano-Zavala et al. 2003 Ornitologia Neotropical
Limb.Morphology.Notes: Other than the miharung, which was unguligrade, and loons and grebes, which are plantigrade, all other birds are digitigrade
Habitat.Notes: Most moa species, with the exception of the rarely-preserved North Island species, have had their habitat well-described and ranged low rainforest to high elevation tundra. No description of use of aquatic resources or specialized aquatic adaptions.
Habitat.Reference: Worthy 1990 New Zealand Journal of Zoology

Common.Name: South Island Giant Moa
Mass.Notes: The species possessed strong sexual dimorphism. The value is the mean of the median male (80.333 kg) and female (151.723 kg) body mass.
Mass.Reference: Olson and Turvey 2013 Proceedings of the Royal Society B
Diet.Notes: A large coprolite deposit including numerous species showed that between-habitat differences were more stark than between-species differences. Diet overall, for all species, was dominated by herbs and subshrubs. D. robustus consumed few monocots, either because of interspecific differences or habitat where coprolites were found (Wood et al. 2008). However, Wood et al. 2020 in their review of coprolite and gizzard contents report a diverse presence of Poaceae and Cyperaceae in this species' diet, which they do not describe in text. Yet analyzing the raw data shows that graminoids only constitute 1.7% of diet.
Diet.Reference: Wood et al. 2008 Quaternary Science Reviews; Wood et al. 2020 New Zealand Journal of Ecology
Fermentation.Type.Method: Inferred from Infraclass; Inferred from diet
Fermentation.Type.Notes: No empirical evidence nor expert opinions regarding the fermentation type of these birds. Their nearest, albeit distant, relatives are the tinamous of South America (Mitchell et al. 2014, Phillips et al. 2010), who are generalist herbivores with enlarged cecas (Garitano-Zavala et al. 2003). However, given their massive size, and the evolution of colon-based fermentation among other large-bodied ratites (rheas and ostriches), we are going to infer hindgut colon digestion as to the best of our knowledge there are no hindgut ceca fermentating animals of these sizes, and given that other truly herbivorous ratites have colons. However, emus and cassuaries have only simple guts. Also, it should be noted that all ratites lack crops (Sales 2006).
Fermentation.Type.Reference: Sales 2006 Avian and Poultry Biology Reviews; Mitchell et al. 2014 Science; Phillips et al. 2010 Systematic Biology; Garitano-Zavala et al. 2003 Ornitologia Neotropical
Limb.Morphology.Notes: Other than the miharung, which was unguligrade, and loons and grebes, which are plantigrade, all other birds are digitigrade
Habitat.Notes: Most moa species, with the exception of the rarely-preserved North Island species, have had their habitat well-described and ranged low rainforest to high elevation tundra. No description of use of aquatic resources or specialized aquatic adaptions.
Habitat.Reference: Worthy 1990 New Zealand Journal of Zoology

Common.Name: Diprotodon
Mass.Notes: Primary source inaccessible
Diet.Method: Expert Opinion; Functional craniodental morphology; Observed low sample size (1-5) fossil evidence (fossilized stomach); Proxy dental wear (microwear); Proxy isotopes (C13, 018, Sr87)
Diet.Notes: Price et al 2017 used C13, O18, and Sr87 isotopes. By doing so they documented a mixed diet of C3 and C4 vegetation and that Diprotodon migrated, likely in groups over ~200km. However, C4 in this region could be Atriplex, instead of grass. Indeed, the Australian Musem 2020 mentions Atriplex found in the abdominal region of a specimen, in what appears to be a fossilized stomach (primary source not reported). Grocket 1997 likewise found a mixed C3/C4 diet. Webb 2009 describes Diprotodons as mixed feeders of grasses and browse, citing Grocke 1997. Unfortunately, there appears to be little empirical evidence to differentiate between Atriplex and grass consumption as the driver of the C4 isotopes. Other authors, such as Johnson and Prideaux 2004, classify Diprotodons as browsers. DeSantis 2017 concurs with isotope results that Diprotodon was a mixed feeder of C3/C4, and finds that their microwear patterns are similar to swamp wallabies, suggesting a variable but browse-heavy diet. Sharp and Rich (2016) report on unusually strong bite height forces as evidenced by skull morphology. These could indicate a diet of extremely tough, high fiber vegetation, a habit of digging with canines, or potential sexual selection (e.g. fighting with canines). Given this uncertainty, we will classify them as mixed feeders preferring browse and give this a certainty score of 1.
Diet.Reference: Price et al. 2017 Proceedings of the Royal Society B; Grocke 1997 Australian Journal of Botany; Webb 2009 Boreas; Arman and Prideaux 2015 Austral Ecology; The Australia Museum 2019; Johnson and Prideaux 2004 Austral Ecology; DeSantis et al. 2017 Paleobiology; Sharp and Rich 2016 Journal of Anatomy
Fermentation.Type.Method: Inferred from Order; Inferred from sister Families; Proxy isotopes (N15)
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Dawson 2006 reports hindgut authoratively, but her methods are unclear. Her evidence is likely that Vombatidae and Phascolarctidae, sister families, are both hindgut fermenters. Grocke and Bocherens 1996 interpreted Nitrogen isotope data from a diprodontid as evidence of hindgut fermentation as well. Given their large body size, hindgut colon fermentation is most likely.
Fermentation.Type.Reference: Dawson 2006 Alcheringa; Grocke and Bocherens 1996 Comptes Rendus de lAcadamie des Sciences, Series II
Limb.Morphology.Notes: Both fore and hindlegs are weight-bearing and do not suggest opportunistic bipedalism or utility for digging or grabbing vegetation (Coombs 1983)
Limb.Morphology.Reference: The Australia Museum 2019; Coombs 1983 Transactions of the American Philosophical Society
Habitat.Method: Expert Opinion; Inferred from habitat association (proxy isotopes C13, O18)
Habitat.Notes: According to the Australian Museum (2019) this species preferred open habitats and avoided hilly, rocky terrain. Their methods are unclear. Price et al. 2017 analyzed isotopic data that indicated seasonal migratory behavior across their nearly continent-wide range. No indication of aquatic habitat usage
Habitat.Reference: The Australia Museum 2019; Price et al. 2017 Proceedings of the Royal Society B

Mass.Notes: This value is the mean of 37 different regression estimates, using various anatomical measurements. The authors note that the regression they used were not based on South American taxa. Xenarthrans often have unusual body dimensions and the body mass estimates of these regressions were variable.
Mass.Reference: Smith et al. 2003 Ecology; Farina et al. 1998 Mastozoologia Neotropical
Diet.Notes: Bocherens et al. 2017 used C13 collagen and Capatite and found high isotopic values suggesting grazing, or unusual feeding morphology.
Diet.Reference: Bocherens et al. 2017 Gondwana Research
Fermentation.Type.Method: Functional craniodental morphology; Inferred from diet; Proxy isotopes (C13, N15)
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Likely hindgut, but type unknown. The extant relatives, armadillos, are insectivores and have simple sac stomachs. Some have suggested the same for glyptodonts (Bocherens et al. 2017 Gondwana Research), but it seems impossible that they would sustain their metabolism as obigate herbivores without fermentation. Bocherens et al. (2017 Gondwana Research) found that their isotopic values (for Doedicurus spp, Glyptodon spp, Glyptotherium) suggested either aquatic habitat or a fast fermentation rate. Vizcaino et al. (2011 Ameghiniana) suggested that given the estimated low metabolic rate of Xenarthans but the relatively complex teeth of cingulates compared to sloths, that sloths have more efficient fermentation in digestive tract than glyptodonts. The best evidence indicates that sloths had foregut non-ruminant digestion.  Hindgut digestion is the most  ancestral type, far less derived than foregut fermentation. We will therefore infer that these animals were likely hindgut and also hingut colon, since there are few large mammals that use caecums
Fermentation.Type.Reference: Smith et al. 2010 Nature Geoscience; Bocherens et al. 2017 Gondwana Research; Vizcaino et al. 2011 Ameghiniana
Limb.Morphology.Notes: Plantigrady is one component of a suite of traits, including armor, low metabolism, ability to withstand hypoxia, and other slow life history habits
Limb.Morphology.Reference: Superina and Loughry 2011 Journal of Mammalian Evolution
Habitat.Method: Inferred from vegetation association (proxy isotopes C13, O18); Observed low sample size (1-5) ichnofossils
Habitat.Notes: High isotopic values suggest aquatic diet, and ichnosites show presence in 1 marshland in South America (McDonald 2005)
Habitat.Reference: Bocherens et al. 2017 Gondwana Research

Common.Name: Beira
Diet.Notes: Fecal analyses and observational studies indicate a strict browsing diet, though there have been few studies of this species.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: Beiras prefer rocky, stony hills and plateau-tops with mixed Acacia scrub.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa

Common.Name: Kangaroo Island Emu
Mass.Reference: Yates and Worthy 2019 Journal of Vertebrate Paleontology
Diet.Notes: Under some taxonomies these are considered conspecific to extant emus and likely have the same diet.
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Despite being large herbivores, emus have simple guts and high through-put rates. Despite this, they obtain around 50% of their maintenance energy from fermented carbohydrates. Fermentation occurs in the ileum (lower smaller intestine) instead of the cecum, and shows little morphological specialization as a fermentation site. Ostriches and rheas on the other hand have developed increased fermentation capacity comparable to mammalian herbivores.  It should be noted that all ratites lack crops (Sales 2006).
Fermentation.Type.Reference: Herd and Dawson 1984 Physiological Zoology; Buchsbaum et al. 1986 Ecology
Limb.Morphology.Notes: Other than the miharung, which was unguligrade, and loons and grebes, which are plantigrade, all other birds are digitigrade
Habitat.Notes: Emus are terrestrial species occurring across a variety of habitats. No significant or obligate use of aquatic resources.
Habitat.Reference: Birds of the World 2020 Cornell Lab of Ornithology

Common.Name: King Island Emu
Mass.Reference: Yates and Worthy 2019 Journal of Vertebrate Paleontology
Diet.Notes: Under some taxonomies these are considered conspecific to extant emus and likely have the same diet.
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Despite being large herbivores, emus have simple guts and high through-put rates. Despite this, they obtain around 50% of their maintenance energy from fermented carbohydrates. Fermentation occurs in the ileum (lower smaller intestine) instead of the cecum, and shows little morphological specialization as a fermentation site. Habitat.Reference: Birds of the World 2020 Cornell Lab of Ornithology

Common.Name: Emu
Mass.Notes: This estimate is based the average of the male and female body size. Both the male and female mass estimate are based on 11 specimens. We collected this value from Dunning 2008 CRC Handbook of Avian Body Masses. This book is a collection of published literature about bird masses and is not the primary source of these estimates.
Mass.Reference: Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; Dunning 2008 CRC Handbook of Avian Body Masses
Diet.Notes: In a semi-arid region, analysis of 221 scats found that grasses comprised 27% of diet, followed by dry shoots (35%), roots (5%), and leaves (3%), with seeds constituting the bulk of their diet (30%) (Dunstan et al. 2013). In a more mesic region (Grampians National Park, Victoria), emu diet was primarily dominated by dicotyledons, with grasses a minor food component (Quin 1996). Emus also consume invertebrates, though the quantity is not apparent in any empirical literature.
Diet.Reference: Dunstan et al. 2013 Emu; Quin 1996 Emu
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Despite being large herbivores, emus have simple guts and high through-put rates. Despite this, they obtain around 50% of their maintenance energy from fermented carbohydrates. Fermentation occurs in the ileum (lower smaller intestine) instead of the cecum, and shows little morphological specialization as a fermentation site. Ostriches and rheas on the other hand have developed increased fermentation capacity comparable to mammalian herbivores.  It should be noted that all ratites lack crops (Sales 2006).

Habitat.Reference: Birds of the World 2020 Cornell Lab of Ornithology

Common.Name: Tufted Deer
Diet.Method: Observed fecal analysis; Observed low sample size (1-5) evidence
Diet.Notes: Stomach content analyses (Leslie et al. 2013) indicate a diet primarily of browse, but considered by some authors to be a mixed feeder. Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 consider this species a mixed feeder of bamboo, forbs, fruit, and grass, but don't report any empirical evidence.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Leslie et al. 2013 Mammalian Species
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: This spcies is adapted to cool climates and lives in damp forests, up to tree line, usually near water.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Common.Name: Pere David's Deer
Diet.Method: Expert Opinion; Observed low sample size (1-5) evidence
Diet.Notes: Very little empirical information available. Wilson and Mittermeier state that they consume grasses, reeds, and leaves.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: A swamp-adapted deer with wide hooves that are sensitive to hard-ground. An adept swimmer. Their extinction in the wild was likely due to conversion of wetlands and floodplains into agriculture.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; Pacini and Harper 2008 Tropical stream ecology

Common.Name: Siberian unicorn
Diet.Method: Functional craniodental and appendicular morphology; Proxy isotopes (C13, N15)
Diet.Notes: Lots of speculative discussion driven by this animals appendicular morphology, which suggests a very low to ground grazing posture. Browsing rhinos have a skull orientation that is neutral to body axis, while the one extant grazing rhino has a skull that faces strongly downward, like the Siberian unicorn (van der Made and Grube 2010, Zhegallo et al. 2005. Furthermore, their highly hypsodont molars are speculated to have been induced by feeding on dirty, abrasive food stuffs - like roots, or by being a hypergrazer. See Zhegallo et al. 2005. Isotopic analysis by Kosintsev et al. 2019 indicated a diet either of hypergrazing or Chenopodiaceae (C4 shrubs). Given the morphological suggestion of hypergrazing, plus the isotopic data, we are describing this species as a hypergrazer.
Diet.Reference: van der Made and Grube 2010 Elefantentreich; Zhegallo et al. 2005 Cranium; Kosintsev et al. 2019 Nature Ecology and Evolution
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Hindgut colon fermenting species sacrifice fermentation efficiency (e.g. completeness) for rate of passage. Cell-walls are only partially digested, but without the chokepoint provided by the rumen, they can continually consume vegetation thus meeting their nutrient demands. As such they are also able to consume lower-quality vegetation.
Limb.Morphology.Notes: Technically unguligrade, but modified with thick fleshy pads to hold weight, therefore functionally more similar to digitigrade
Habitat.Method: Inferred from Genus; Inferred from absence of evidence; Inferred from habitat association; Inferred from habitat association (proxy isotopes C13, N15)
Habitat.Notes: Inhabited open to forested steppe, likely in drier than modern climatic conditions. No evidence to suggest aquatic habits
Habitat.Reference: Kosintsev et al. 2019 Nature Ecology and Evolution

Common.Name: Straight-tusked Elephant
Diet.Method: Proxy dental wear (microwear and mesowear); Proxy isotopes (C13, 018, Sr87)
Diet.Notes: Isotopes and dental wear both indicate mixed feeding diet
Diet.Reference: Palombo 2005 Quaternary International; Rivals et al. 2012 Quaternary International; Rivals and Lister 2016 Quaternary Science Reviews
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Hindgut colon fermenting species sacrifice fermentation efficiency (e.g. completeness) for rate of passage. Cell-walls are only partially digested, but without the chokepoint provided by the rumen, they can continually consume vegetation thus meeting their nutrient demands. As such they are also able to consume lower-quality vegetation.
Habitat.Notes: Extant relatives and diet suggest a terrestrial habit, with only opportunistic use of aquatic environments.
Habitat.Reference: Palombo 2005 Proceedings of the International Symposium of Insular Vertebrate Evolution

Common.Name: Cyprus Dwarf Elephant
Mass.Reference: Davies and Lister 2001 The World of Elephants: Proceedings of the 1st International Congress
Diet.Notes: No empirical proxy evidence found
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Hindgut colon fermenting species sacrifice fermentation efficiency (e.g. completeness) for rate of passage. Cell-walls are only partially digested, but without the chokepoint provided by the rumen, they can continually consume vegetation thus meeting their nutrient demands. As such they are also able to consume lower-quality vegetation.
Habitat.Notes: Extant relatives and diet suggest a terrestrial habit, with only opportunistic use of aquatic environments. Although it should be noted that their ancestors swam to Cyprus, as many elephants can make long-distance swimming voyages. Heavily used caves on island.
Habitat.Reference: Hadjisterkotis and Reese 2008 European Journal of Wildlife Research

Mass.Notes: Primary source inaccessible
Diet.Notes: No empirical proxy evidence found. Smith et al. 2018 list this species as a grazer.
Diet.Reference: Smith et al. 2018 Science; Smith et al. 2003 Ecology
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Hindgut colon fermenting species sacrifice fermentation efficiency (e.g. completeness) for rate of passage. Cell-walls are only partially digested, but without the chokepoint provided by the rumen, they can continually consume vegetation thus meeting their nutrient demands. As such they are also able to consume lower-quality vegetation.
Habitat.Notes: Extant relatives and diet suggest a terrestrial habit, with only opportunistic use of aquatic environments.

Common.Name: Asian Elephant
Mass.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World
Diet.Notes: While preferring to browse in forested environments, Asian elephants are highly flexible to resource availability and will graze in open environments. Their dietary flexibility is speculated to be a reason they survived Stegodon orientalis (Zhang et al. 2017).
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Zhang et al. 2017 Quaternary International
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Hindgut colon fermenting species sacrifice fermentation efficiency (e.g. completeness) for rate of passage. Cell-walls are only partially digested, but without the chokepoint provided by the rumen, they can continually consume vegetation thus meeting their nutrient demands. As such they are also able to consume lower-quality vegetation.
Habitat.Notes: Asian elephants occupy, or at least once did, a broad range of habitats, from desert to rainforest. Their current distribution is primarily shaped by human absence. They appear to prefer edges between forests and grasslands. Have been recorded digging to groundwater with their tusks (Liv Baker, personal communication)
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2013 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Mass.Notes: See Larramendi 2016 for an in-depth discussion about the relationship between shoulder height and the body mass of extinct proboscideans.
Diet.Notes: No empirical proxy evidence found
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Hindgut colon fermenting species sacrifice fermentation efficiency (e.g. completeness) for rate of passage. Cell-walls are only partially digested, but without the chokepoint provided by the rumen, they can continually consume vegetation thus meeting their nutrient demands. As such they are also able to consume lower-quality vegetation.
Habitat.Notes: Extant relatives and diet suggest a terrestrial habit, with only opportunistic use of aquatic environments.

Common.Name: Asian Straight-tusked Elephant
Diet.Notes: Isotopes indicate mixed feeding to hyper grazing, but sample size is limited. Given their moderate hyposodonty, and the low certainty, will call this species a mixed feeder preferring graze.
Diet.Reference: Teague 2001 Thesis; Patnaik et al. 2019 Quaternary Science Reviews

Common.Name: Naumann's Elephant
Mass.Notes: The regression upon which this estimate is based Roth (1990) is based upon a relationship for extant probooscideans and is at least partially based on measurements from obese, captive animals. It may not apply well to dwarf species with different body proportions. See Larramendi 2016 for an in-depth discussion.
Mass.Reference: Raia et al. 2010 Global Ecology and Biogeography
Diet.Method: Proxy dental wear (microwear); Proxy isotopes (C13, O18)
Diet.Notes: Isotopes and dental wear suggest this species were grazers / bark eaters.
Diet.Reference: Mingxing et al. 2014 Quaternary Sciences
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Hindgut colon fermenting species sacrifice fermentation efficiency (e.g. completeness) for rate of passage. Cell-walls are only partially digested, but without the chokepoint provided by the rumen, they can continually consume vegetation thus meeting their nutrient demands. Mass.Reference: Herridge and Lister 2012 Proceedings of the Royal Society B
Diet.Notes: No empirical proxy evidence found

Common.Name: Eastern Moa
Diet.Notes: Coprolites and gizzards indicate a diet almost exclusively of browse (4% graminoid) (data from Wood et al. 2020)
Diet.Reference: Wood et al. 2020 New Zealand Journal of Ecology
Fermentation.Type.Method: Inferred from Infraclass; Inferred from diet
Fermentation.Type.Notes: No empirical evidence nor expert opinions regarding the fermentation type of these birds. Their nearest, albeit distant, relatives are the tinamous of South America (Mitchell et al. 2014, Phillips et al. 2010), who are generalist herbivores with enlarged cecas (Garitano-Zavala et al. 2003). However, given their massive size, and the evolution of colon-based fermentation among other large-bodied ratites (rheas and ostriches), we are going to infer hindgut colon digestion as to the best of our knowledge there are no hindgut ceca fermentating animals of these sizes, and given that other truly herbivorous ratites have colons. However, emus and cassuaries have only simple guts. Also, it should be noted that all ratites lack crops (Sales 2006).
