Limb.Morphology.Notes: Kubo et al. 2019 report plantigrade, which is true while foraging/standing. But when running Macropus are digitigrade (Kram and Dawson 1998 Comparative Biochemistry and Physiology Part B )
Limb.Morphology.Reference: Kram and Dawson 1998 Comparative Biochemistry and Physiology Part B
Habitat.Notes: Similar to M. fuliginosus, this species has broad habitat affinities, preferring heterogenous landscapes including mallee scrub, agricultural lands, woodland, forest, shrubland, and healthland. They prefer unburnt habitat with dense thickets for shelter from predators and inclement weather. No indication of aquatic habitat use in this species.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2015 Handbook of the Mammals of the World

Common.Name: Toolache Wallaby
Mass.Notes: Primary source inaccessible
Diet.Notes: No empirical proxy evidence found, listed as a mixed feeder by Johnson and Prideaux 2004, and as a mixed feeder preferring graze by Wilson and Mittermeier.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2015 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Johnson and Prideaux 2004 Austral Ecology; Dawson 2006 Alcheringa

Thus this system maximizes material flow and rate of fermentation at the expense of cell wall digestion. Limb.Morphology.Reference: Kram and Dawson 1998 Comparative Biochemistry and Physiology Part B
Habitat.Notes: Described in EltonTraits as a terrestrial species, yet historical accounts indicate that this species was dependent on marshland habitats, their draining was the likely the cause of their extinction. However, given that this would not be evident for fossil taxa, we are going to list this species as terrestrial.
Habitat.Reference: Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; Robinson and Young 1983 Department of Environment and Planning

Common.Name: Whiptail Wallaby
Diet.Method: Expert Opinion; Observed low sample size (1-5) foraging
Diet.Notes: Whiptail wallabies are primarily grazers, preferring grass leaves. However, they will also consume ferns and legumes. They are mostly free-water independent, except during severe drought.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2015 Handbook of the Mammals of the World
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Kangaroos posssess foregut fermentation systems, but instead of them being divided into sacs, they are linear and have higher throughputs - comparable in function to hindgut colon fermentation in fact. Thus this system maximizes material flow and rate of fermentation at the expense of cell wall digestion. Limb.Morphology.Notes: Kubo et al. 2019 report plantigrade, which is true while foraging/standing. But when running Macropus are digitigrade (Kram and Dawson 1998 Comparative Biochemistry and Physiology Part B )
Limb.Morphology.Reference: Kram and Dawson 1998 Comparative Biochemistry and Physiology Part B
Habitat.Notes: This species lives in open eucalypt forest in hilly country, preferring to spend time on steeper slopes when active during the day, moving to gentle, lower slopes during night foraging. No indication of aquatic (or arboreal) habitat use.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2015 Handbook of the Mammals of the World

Mass.Notes: Primary source inaccessible
Diet.Notes: Johnson and Prideaux 2004, in their summary paper, list this species as a grazer. No clear indication of their method. No additional data found.
Diet.Reference: Johnson and Prideaux 2004 Austral Ecology; Dawson 2006 Alcheringa
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Kangaroos posssess foregut fermentation systems, but instead of them being divided into sacs, they are linear and have higher throughputs - comparable in function to hindgut colon fermentation in fact. Thus this system maximizes material flow and rate of fermentation at the expense of cell wall digestion. The implications of this is that food intake rates are less limited in macropods than in ruminants when foraging high fiber foods: as forage quality decreases ruminants reduce consumption rate (because they require longer fermentation times on high fiber foods), whereas macropod intake rate remains more or less constant.
Limb.Morphology.Reference: Kram and Dawson 1998 Comparative Biochemistry and Physiology Part B
Habitat.Notes: Considered a savanna denizen. No details on aquatic habits.
Habitat.Reference: Johnson and Prideaux 2004 Austral Ecology; Dawson 2006 Alcheringa

Common.Name: Common Wallaroo
Diet.Method: Observed fecal analysis; Observed foraging; Proxy isotopes (C13)
Diet.Notes: Telfer and Bowman find mixed feeding with preference for grass in this species, with grass consumption ~75% on average. Likewise, Creese et al. 2019 found that grasses comprised 72-78% of their diet. According to Wilson and Mittermeier, this species prefers leaves of low-fiber, high-nitrogen grasses, but also will consume small quantities of chenopods, shrubs of Malvaceae, forbs, sedges, reeds, and browse. Has been observed entering shallow water to consume aquatic vegetation.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2015 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Telfer and Bowman 2006 Austral Ecology; Creese et al. 2019 Australian Mammalogy
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Kangaroos posssess foregut fermentation systems, but instead of them being divided into sacs, they are linear and have higher throughputs - comparable in function to hindgut colon fermentation in fact. Thus this system maximizes material flow and rate of fermentation at the expense of cell wall digestion. The implications of this is that food intake rates are less limited in macropods than in ruminants when foraging high fiber foods: as forage quality decreases ruminants reduce consumption rate (because they require longer fermentation times on high fiber foods), whereas macropod intake rate remains more or less constant.
Fermentation.Type.Reference: Hume 2002 Acta Zoologica Sinica; Dawson et al. 1989 Fauna of Australia
Limb.Morphology.Notes: Kubo et al. 2019 report plantigrade, which is true while foraging/standing. But when running Macropus are digitigrade (Kram and Dawson 1998 Comparative Biochemistry and Physiology Part B )
Limb.Morphology.Reference: Kram and Dawson 1998 Comparative Biochemistry and Physiology Part B
Habitat.Notes: The common wallaroo occurs across Australia in a diversity of habitats, however, prefer to be close to rocky escarpments and complex terrain adjacent to open feeding areas. Although largely  free-water independent, they are described as digging wells to groundwater in creek beds. No indication of aquatic or arboreal habitat use.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2015 Handbook of the Mammals of the World

Common.Name: Red-necked Wallaby
Diet.Notes: Green et al. 2014 in the Snowy Mountains and in Tasmania documented a diet of ~70% dicots (~40 of which were herbaceous forbs), 40% grasses (including sedges). This aligns with Wilson and Mittermeier's classification as mixed feeder. In their review they find that in low elevation areas they are selective grazers and catholic consumers of forbs. In high elevation zones, however, they primarily consume woody browse.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2015 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Green et al. 2015 Australian Mammalogy
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Kangaroos posssess foregut fermentation systems, but instead of them being divided into sacs, they are linear and have higher throughputs - comparable in function to hindgut colon fermentation in fact. Thus this system maximizes material flow and rate of fermentation at the expense of cell wall digestion. The implications of this is that food intake rates are less limited in macropods than in ruminants when foraging high fiber foods: as forage quality decreases ruminants reduce consumption rate (because they require longer fermentation times on high fiber foods), whereas macropod intake rate remains more or less constant.
Fermentation.Type.Reference: Hume 2002 Acta Zoologica Sinica; Dawson et al. 1989 Fauna of Australia
Limb.Morphology.Notes: Kubo et al. 2019 report plantigrade, which is true while foraging/standing. But when running Macropus are digitigrade (Kram and Dawson 1998 Comparative Biochemistry and Physiology Part B )
Limb.Morphology.Reference: Kram and Dawson 1998 Comparative Biochemistry and Physiology Part B
Habitat.Notes: This species occurs from coastal heath and shrubland up to sclerophyllous forest and woodland at the winter snowline. Forages in open grassy patches adjacent to dense shrub cover. No indication of aquatic or arboreal habitat use.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2015 Handbook of the Mammals of the World

Common.Name: Red Kangaroo
Diet.Notes: Primarily a grazer, but forbs can also be heavily consumed, comprising 38-99% of diet. Among shrubs, they show preference for shrubs of Solanceae and Malvaceae, while avoiding chenopods and trees.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2015 Handbook of the Mammals of the World
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Kangaroos posssess foregut fermentation systems, but instead of them being divided into sacs, they are linear and have higher throughputs - comparable in function to hindgut colon fermentation in fact. Thus this system maximizes material flow and rate of fermentation at the expense of cell wall digestion. The implications of this is that food intake rates are less limited in macropods than in ruminants when foraging high fiber foods: as forage quality decreases ruminants reduce consumption rate (because they require longer fermentation times on high fiber foods), whereas macropod intake rate remains more or less constant.
Fermentation.Type.Reference: Hume 2002 Acta Zoologica Sinica; Dawson et al. 1989 Fauna of Australia
Limb.Morphology.Notes: Kubo et al. 2019 report plantigrade, which is true while foraging/standing. But when running Macropus are digitigrade (Kram and Dawson 1998 Comparative Biochemistry and Physiology Part B )
Limb.Morphology.Reference: Kram and Dawson 1998 Comparative Biochemistry and Physiology Part B
Habitat.Notes: The largest extant kangaroo species, red kangaroos dwell in arid to semi-arid areas across central Australia to the western coast. They prefer open, flat topographies and lives in a variety of vegetation communities, preferring open understories of short grass and forbs, avoiding tallgrass. Free-water dependent, but can go days without drinking. No evidence of aquatic or arboreal habitat use.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2015 Handbook of the Mammals of the World

Common.Name: American Mastodon
Diet.Method: Observed dental bolus; Proxy dental wear (microwear); Proxy isotopes (C13, O18)
Diet.Notes: Dental microwear suggests mostly a browser, but in some populations there is sign of grazing (Green et al. 2017). Supported by Rivals et al. 2012 - of 21 dental boluses, all contained woody vegetation: Picea spp, Pinus spp, Salix spp, Populus spp, and Alnus. Bravo-Cuevas et al. 2017 found isotopic evidence showing a strong C3 diet of browse in central Mexico.
Diet.Reference: Green et al. 2017 Palaeogeography, Palaeoclimatology, Palaecology; Rivals et al. 2012 Quaternary International; Teale and Miller 2012 Quaternary Research; Bravo Cuevas et al. 2017 Palaeogeography, Palaeoclimatology, Palaeoecology
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Hindgut colon fermenting species sacrifice fermentation efficiency (e.g. completeness) for rate of passage. Cell-walls are only partially digested, but without the chokepoint provided by the rumen, they can continually consume vegetation thus meeting their nutrient demands. As such they are also able to consume lower-quality vegetation.
Habitat.Notes: Extant relatives and diet suggest a terrestrial habit, with only opportunistic use of aquatic environments.

Common.Name: Columbian Mammoth
Diet.Method: Proxy dental wear (microwear); Proxy isotopes (C13, O18)
Diet.Notes: Craniodental morphology suggests that the Columbian mammoth was a grazer. However, Perez-Crespo et al. (2012) analyzed isotopes from 25 samples for 13 Mexican localities and found strong evidence of mixed feeding capacity: 6 individuals had an exclusive C4 diet, 19 had some consumption of C3 vegetation. Microwear data and other isotopic studies supports dietary flexibility as well, but with a preference for graze (Rivals et al. 2019, Mayte et al. 2016).
Diet.Reference: Perez Crespo et al. 2012 Quaternary International; Rivals et al. 2012 Quaternary International; Rivals et al. 2019 Quaternary Science Reviews; Mayte et al. 2016 Quaternary International
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Hindgut colon fermenting species sacrifice fermentation efficiency (e.g. completeness) for rate of passage. Cell-walls are only partially digested, but without the chokepoint provided by the rumen, they can continually consume vegetation thus meeting their nutrient demands. As such they are also able to consume lower-quality vegetation.
Habitat.Notes: Extant relatives and diet suggest a terrestrial habit, with only opportunistic use of aquatic environments.

Common.Name: Pygmy Mammoth
Mass.Reference: Davis 2017 Proceedings of the Royal Society B; Agenbroad 2009 Proceedings of the 7th California Islands Symposium
Diet.Notes: Microwear comparison to extant proboscideans and gives a strong signal of browsing - that these island mammoths diet became similar to Forest elephants and Asian elephants, despite being descendents of the grazing/mixed-feeding Columbian mammoth (Semprebon et al. 2015). Additional microwear analysis indicates an increased consumption of hard-objects compared to Columbian mammoths (i.e. seeds) (Smith and DeSantis 2018)
Diet.Reference: Semprebon et al. 2015 Quaternary International; Smith and DeSantis 2018 Palaeogeography, Palaeoclimatology, Palaeoecology
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Hindgut colon fermenting species sacrifice fermentation efficiency (e.g. completeness) for rate of passage. Cell-walls are only partially digested, but without the chokepoint provided by the rumen, they can continually consume vegetation thus meeting their nutrient demands. As such they are also able to consume lower-quality vegetation.
Habitat.Notes: Extant relatives and diet suggest a terrestrial habit, with only opportunistic use of aquatic environments.

Common.Name: Woolly Mammoth
Diet.Notes: Rivals et al. 2012 analyzed 127 samples from the North Sea and 32 from Alaska. Microwear indicated that they were grazers in Alaska, and Grazers / Mixed-Feeders in the North Sea. Rivals and Lister (2016) analyzed samples from Great Britain, which indicated grazer
Diet.Reference: Rivals et al. 2012 Quaternary International; Rivals and Lister 2016 Quaternary Science Reviews
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Hindgut colon fermenting species sacrifice fermentation efficiency (e.g. completeness) for rate of passage. Cell-walls are only partially digested, but without the chokepoint provided by the rumen, they can continually consume vegetation thus meeting their nutrient demands. As such they are also able to consume lower-quality vegetation.
Habitat.Notes: Extant relatives and diet suggest a terrestrial habit, with only opportunistic use of aquatic environments.

Common.Name: Drill
Diet.Method: Observed low sample size (1-5) foraging and fecal analysis
Diet.Notes: Little known, a cryptic species. Observations indicate fruit consumption. Feces contain invertebrates and seeds.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2013 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa
Fermentation.Type.Notes: All primate species except colobins have hindgut fermentation systems, with most (especially larger-bodied families) using the colon as the site of fermentation. Hindgut colon fermenting species sacrifice fermentation efficiency (e.g. completeness) for rate of passage. Cell-walls are only partially digested, but without the chokepoint provided by the rumen, they can continually consume vegetation thus meeting their nutrient demands. As such they are also able to consume lower-quality vegetation.
Fermentation.Type.Reference: Hume 2002 Acta Zoologica Sinica; Lambert 1998 Evolutionary Anthropology
Habitat.Notes: Closed forest to transitional open woodland, grasslands, although most of those open woodlands have been cut. Forage primarily on ground but some also forage in trees
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2013 Handbook of the Mammals of the World

Common.Name: Mandrill
Diet.Notes: Omnivorous, but specialize on fruit (in 76% of fecal samples), seeds (52%), and insects (88%), as well as leaves (57%)
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2013 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa
Fermentation.Type.Notes: All primate species except colobins have hindgut fermentation systems, with most (especially larger-bodied families) using the colon as the site of fermentation. Hindgut colon fermenting species sacrifice fermentation efficiency (e.g. completeness) for rate of passage. Cell-walls are only partially digested, but without the chokepoint provided by the rumen, they can continually consume vegetation thus meeting their nutrient demands. As such they are also able to consume lower-quality vegetation.
Fermentation.Type.Reference: Hume 2002 Acta Zoologica Sinica; Lambert 1998 Evolutionary Anthropology
Habitat.Notes: This species inhabits evergreen rainforest, semi-montane forests, and forest islands in savanna. Females and young forage in trees, but males spend most of their time on the ground.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2013 Handbook of the Mammals of the World

Mass.Notes: Primary source inaccessible
Diet.Method: Functional craniodental morphology; Inferred from habitat associations
Diet.Notes: Flannery (1999) argued that this taxa is a grazer due to tooth morphology and the habitat associated with fossil remains. However, Johnson and Prideaux 2004, classify this species as a browser. Given that there are no large grazers in this family, reflecting potential morphological/evolutionary limitations in marsupial skull evolution (see Bennett and Goswami 2013 BMC Biology), it would be ill-advised to rank this species as a hypergrazer following Flannery. Instead we will rank this species as a mixed feeder. Given such opposing evidence, we will give this a certainty score of 0
Diet.Reference: Johnson and Prideaux 2004 Austral Ecology; Dawson 2006 Alcheringa; Flannery 1999 Records of the Western Australian Museum; Johnson and Prideaux 2004 Austral Ecology; Bennett and Goswami 2013 BMC Biology
Fermentation.Type.Method: Inferred from Order; Inferred from sister Families; Proxy isotopes (N15)
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Dawson 2006 reports hindgut authoratively, but her methods are unclear. Her evidence is likely that Vombatidae and Phascolarctidae, sister families, are both hindgut fermenters. Grocke and Bocherens 1996 interpreted Nitrogen isotope data from a diprodontid as evidence of hindgut fermentation as well.
Limb.Morphology.Notes: Both fore and hindlegs are weight-bearing and do not suggest opportunistic bipedalism or utility for digging or grabbing vegetation (Coombs 1983)
Limb.Morphology.Reference: The Australia Museum 2019; Coombs 1983 Transactions of the American Philosophical Society
Habitat.Notes: No evidence of aquatic habitat use in this species
Habitat.Reference: Flannery 1999 Records of the Western Australian Museum

Common.Name: Red Brocket
Diet.Method: Expert Opinion; Observed low sample size (1-5) evidence
Diet.Notes: Primarily consumes fruits and seeds but also folivorous and florivorous, primarily during the dry season when fruits are unavailable.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: This wide-ranging species prefers dense, humid forests, but sometimes wanders into savanna close to forest edge.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Common.Name: Small Red Brocket
Mass.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World
Diet.Method: Expert Opinion; Observed low sample size (1-5) evidence
Diet.Notes: The small red brocket deer feeds primarily on fruits, flowers, and young tender shoots.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: Habitat restricted to relicts of the Serra do Mar coastal Atlantic forest, living from the coast to 1200 m above sea level.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Common.Name: Merida Brocket
Diet.Notes: Little empirical evidence, but diet is most likely similar to other Mazama species in consisting of fruits and foliage (Wilson and Mittermeier 2011)

Common.Name: Gray Brocket
Diet.Notes: During the dry season, fecal analysis by Serbent et al. 2011 found 2% graminoid consumption, 67.7% woody shrub consumption, and 7% herbaceous, and 12% fruit. This reinforces Wilson and Mittermeier.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Serbent et al. 2011 Journal of Arid Environments

Mass.Notes: Primary source inaccessible
Diet.Notes: No empirical information aside from their craniodental morphology which suggests a browsing habit. Given that their better-studied congener, the Irish elk is a mixed feeder as known from proxy evidence, we will call this a mixed feeder preferring browse to be ecologically conservative.
Diet.Reference: Abbazzi 2004 Rendiconti Lincei

Common.Name: Koala Lemur
Mass.Notes: The estimate is the mean of four different regression estimates based upon humerus (n = 6) midshaft cortical area and four different regression estimates based upon femur (n = 6) midshaft cortical area. The reported body mass estimates are rounded versions of those provided in Fleagle and Gilbert 2008.
Mass.Reference: Werdelin and Sanders 2010 Cenozoic Mammals of Africa; Fleagle and Gilbert 2008 Elwyn Simons a Search for Origins
Diet.Method: Functional craniodental morphology; Proxy dental wear (microwear)
Diet.Notes: Dental wear indicates that members of this genus were folivores
Diet.Reference: Godfrey et al. 2004 Journal of Human Evolution; Crowley and Godfrey 2012 Leaping Ahead
Fermentation.Type.Method: Inferred from body mass; Inferred from sister Family
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Hindgut, but type is unknown. Believed to share a common ancestor with Lepilemurs, who have caecum-based hindgut digestion. However, other than the capybara (45kg) there are few extant species, with caecum digestive systems and body masses much above 10kg (Hume 2002). Given the large size of these lemurs, we will infer Hindgut colon digestive systems.
Fermentation.Type.Reference: Lambert 1998 Evolutionary Anthropology; Clauss et al. 2003 Oecologia
Habitat.Notes: Morphology suggests a fully arboreal habit.
Habitat.Reference: Jungers et al. 2005 Journal of Human Evolution

Common.Name: Upland Moa
Diet.Notes: A large coprolite deposit including numerous species showed that between-habitat differences were more stark than between-species differences. Diet overall, for all species, was dominated by herbs and subshrubs. M. didinus consumed few monocots, either because of interspecific differences or habitat where coprolites were found (Wood et al. 2008). However, in Wood et al. 2020's data, 27% of records from coprolites and fossilized gizzards were graminoid (Poaceae or Cyperaceae)
Diet.Reference: Wood et al. 2008 Quaternary Science Reviews; Wood et al. 2020 New Zealand Journal of Ecology
Fermentation.Type.Method: Inferred from Infraclass; Inferred from diet
Fermentation.Type.Notes: No empirical evidence nor expert opinions regarding the fermentation type of these birds. Their nearest, albeit distant, relatives are the tinamous of South America (Mitchell et al. 2014, Phillips et al. 2010), who are generalist herbivores with enlarged cecas (Garitano-Zavala et al. 2003). However, given their massive size, and the evolution of colon-based fermentation among other large-bodied ratites (rheas and ostriches), we are going to infer hindgut colon digestion as to the best of our knowledge there are no hindgut ceca fermentating animals of these sizes, and given that other truly herbivorous ratites have colons. However, emus and cassuaries have only simple guts. Also, it should be noted that all ratites lack crops (Sales 2006).
Fermentation.Type.Reference: Sales 2006 Avian and Poultry Biology Reviews; Mitchell et al. 2014 Science; Phillips et al. 2010 Systematic Biology; Garitano-Zavala et al. 2003 Ornitologia Neotropical
Limb.Morphology.Notes: Other than the miharung, which was unguligrade, and loons and grebes, which are plantigrade, all other birds are digitigrade
Habitat.Notes: Most moa species, with the exception of the rarely-preserved North Island species, have had their habitat well-described and ranged low rainforest to high elevation tundra. No description of use of aquatic resources or specialized aquatic adaptions.
Habitat.Reference: Worthy 1990 New Zealand Journal of Zoology

Common.Name: Irish elk; Giant deer
Mass.Notes: Primary source inaccessible
Diet.Method: Observed low sample size (1-5) fossil evidence (dental bolus); Proxy dental wear (microwear and mesowear); Proxy isotopes (C13, O18)
Diet.Notes: Tooth enamel isotopes from 7 individuals indicate a diet primarily of grasses and forbs, supplemented by shrubs. Plant material in dental bolus of a single molar contained Artemesia and other Asters. However ,considering these boluses to be Anecdotal fossil evidence given the sample size. Tooth wear micro and meso analysis from Great Britain paints a slightly different picture, suggesting mixed feeder preferring grasses (Rivals and Lister 2016). True mixed feeding is corroborated in the review diet by Lister and Stuart 2019
Diet.Reference: Chritz et al. 2009 Palaeogeography, Palaeoclimatology, Palaeoecology; van Geel et al. 2018 Journal of Quaternary Science; Rivals and Lister 2016 Quaternary Science Reviews; Lister and Stuart 2019 Quaternary International
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Method: Observed low sample size (1-5) habitat use; Inferred from absence of evidence
Habitat.Notes: No evidence of aquatic habitat use in this species or extant relatives
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Mass.Notes: The authors list various methods but do not say how the mass of this particular species was estimated. They either used linear (isometric) dimensions based on extant relatives, used regression equations or assumed body mass to increase as the cube of linear dimensions
Mass.Reference: Raia et al. 2010 Global Ecology and Biogeography; Burness et al. 2001 Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America
Diet.Notes: Pujos et al. 2012 uses the width of mandibular symphysis relative to mandibular length to argue that this genus were browsers. No empirical, proxy evidence found.
Diet.Reference: Pujos et al. 2012 Journal of Mammalian Evolution
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Smith et al. 2010 Nature Geoscience lists sloths as hindgut fermenters, because of their body size. However, all extant sloth species are foregut fermenters (Clauss 2004 Mammal Review). Fermentation type is a conservative trait, and extant two-toed and three-toed sloth species are more closely related to various of the now-extinct ground sloths than they are to each other (Pujos et al. 2012 Journal of Mammalian Evolution; Presslee et al. 2019 Nature Ecology and Evolution). Foregut fermentation is either the ancestral fermentation type of all sloth species, or it evolved at least twice in distinct (extant) sloth lineages. The most parsimonious fermentation type for extinct sloths would thus be foregut fermentation. However, Megatheriids pose a biological anamoly as there are no foregut fermentation species known at those body sizes (largest known was Sivatherium, a giraffid at 1250 kg). Vizcaino et al. 2006 and Clauss et al. 2003 suggests therefore that the extremely large Megatheriid sloths (Genera Megatherium and Eremotherium) may have been hindgut fermenters. As is, without better evidence, we will consider all sloths outliers in the ilk of Sivatherium and classify them as foregut fermenters until better evidence is available.
Fermentation.Type.Reference: McDonald and Pelikan 2006 Quaternary International; Clauss 2004 Mammal Review; Pujos et al. 2012 Journal of Mammalian Evolution; Presslee et al. 2019 Nature Ecology and Evolution; Vizcaino et al. 2006 Ameghiniana; Clauss et al. 2003 Oecologia
Limb.Morphology.Notes: Most taxa had the capacity, given their wide structural vertebral, to forage upright, resting on their tail. Appendicular morphology, particularly of the humerus, of all sloth families, other than the Mylodontidae, suggest a generalized locomotion habit (de Oliveira and Santos 2008).
Limb.Morphology.Reference: Naish 2012 Tetrapod Zoology; de Oliveira and Santos 2018 Journal of Morphology
Habitat.Notes: Compared to D. nordenskioldi, this species appears to be terrestrial
Habitat.Reference: Pujos et al. 2012 Journal of Mammalian Evolution

Common.Name: Jefferson's Ground Sloth
Mass.Reference: Davis 2017 Proceedings of the Royal Society B; McDonald 2005 Bulletin of the Florida Museum of Natural History
Diet.Notes: Isotopes indicate a strict browsing diet. However, given that some samples come from more northern latitudes, they could have grazed C3 grasses. Microwear analysis supports this conclusion, showing similarity to Bradypus (the folivorous extant sloth) and suggesting a forested habitat (Resar 2012). Mesowear analysis also suggests a browsing diet, similar to Bradypus (Saarinen and Karme 2017)
Diet.Reference: France et al. 2007 Palaeogeography, Palaeoclimatology, Palaeoecology; McDonald et al. 2019 Quaternary International; Kohn et al. 2005 Geology; Resar 2012 Thesis; Saarinen and Karme 2017 Palaeogeography, Palaeoclimatology, Palaeoecology

Habitat.Notes: The incredible mass of this species makes it extraordinarily unlikely that it was arboreal No evidence of significant aquatic habitat usage.

Common.Name: Giant Ground Sloth
Mass.Notes: The mass estimate reported in Smith et al. 2003 cannot be found in any of the primary sources that Smith et al. 2003 lists. It is higher than any of the masses that are cited in the primary sources (Farina 1995: 4000 kg; Farina et al. 1998: 6073 kg; Bargo et al 2000: 3800 kg), so is not an average of the primary sources either. This suggests the estimate may be on the high side.
Diet.Method: Functional craniodental morphology; Proxy dental wear (microwear and mesowear)
Diet.Notes: Microwear analysis supports functional morphology assessment, indicating that this species was a folivore/frugivore. Likewise, discriminant analysis of mesowear clusters this species with extant folivorous Bradypus
Diet.Reference: Bargo 2001 Acta Palaeontologica Polonica; Green and Kalthoff 2015 Journal of Mammalogy; Saarinen and Karme 2017 Palaeogeography, Palaeoclimatology, Palaeoecology

However, Megatheriids pose a biological anamoly as there are no foregut fermentation species known at those body sizes (largest known was Sivatherium, a giraffid at 1250 kg). Vizcaino et al. 2006 and Clauss et al. 2003 suggests therefore that the extremely large Megatheriid sloths (Genera Megatherium and Eremotherium) may have been hindgut fermenters. As is, without better evidence, we will consider all sloths outliers in the ilk of Sivatherium and classify them as foregut fermenters until better evidence is available.
Fermentation.Type.Reference: McDonald and Pelikan 2006 Quaternary International; Clauss 2004 Mammal Review; Pujos et al. 2012 Journal of Mammalian Evolution; Presslee et al. 2019 Nature Ecology and Evolution; Vizcaino et al. 2006 Ameghiniana; Clauss et al. 2003 Oecologia
Limb.Morphology.Notes: Most taxa had the capacity, given their wide structural vertebral, to forage upright, resting on their tail. Appendicular morphology, particularly of the humerus, of all sloth families, other than the Mylodontidae, suggest a generalized locomotion habit (de Oliveira and Santos 2008).
Limb.Morphology.Reference: Naish 2012 Tetrapod Zoology; de Oliveira and Santos 2018 Journal of Morphology
Habitat.Notes: Functional morphology suggests a terrestrial habit.
Habitat.Reference: Pujos et al. 2012 Journal of Mammalian Evolution

Mass.Notes: Bone measurement not specified. Comparison species is Megatherium americanum
Diet.Notes: Pujos et al. 2012 uses the width of mandibular symphysis relative to mandibular length to argue that this genus were browsers. No empirical, proxy evidence found.
Diet.Reference: Pujos et al. 2012 Journal of Mammalian Evolution
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Smith et al. 2010 Nature Geoscience lists sloths as hindgut fermenters, because of their body size. However, all extant sloth species are foregut fermenters (Clauss 2004 Mammal Review). Fermentation type is a conservative trait, and extant two-toed and three-toed sloth species are more closely related to various of the now-extinct ground sloths than they are to each other (Pujos et al. 2012 Journal of Mammalian Evolution; Presslee et al. 2019 Nature Ecology and Evolution). Foregut fermentation is either the ancestral fermentation type of all sloth species, or it evolved at least twice in distinct (extant) sloth lineages. The most parsimonious fermentation type for extinct sloths would thus be foregut fermentation. However, Megatheriids pose a biological anamoly as there are no foregut fermentation species known at those body sizes (largest known was Sivatherium, a giraffid at 1250 kg). Vizcaino et al. 2006 and Clauss et al. 2003 suggests therefore that the extremely large Megatheriid sloths (Genera Megatherium and Eremotherium) may have been hindgut fermenters. As is, without better evidence, we will consider all sloths outliers in the ilk of Sivatherium and classify them as foregut fermenters until better evidence is available.
Fermentation.Type.Reference: McDonald and Pelikan 2006 Quaternary International; Clauss 2004 Mammal Review; Pujos et al. 2012 Journal of Mammalian Evolution; Presslee et al. 2019 Nature Ecology and Evolution; Vizcaino et al. 2006 Ameghiniana; Clauss et al. 2003 Oecologia
Limb.Morphology.Notes: Most taxa had the capacity, given their wide structural vertebral, to forage upright, resting on their tail. Appendicular morphology, particularly of the humerus, of all sloth families, other than the Mylodontidae, suggest a generalized locomotion habit (de Oliveira and Santos 2008).
Limb.Morphology.Reference: Naish 2012 Tetrapod Zoology; de Oliveira and Santos 2018 Journal of Morphology
Habitat.Notes: Functional morphology suggests a terrestrial habit.
Habitat.Reference: Grass 2014 Thesis

Common.Name: Sloth Lemur
Mass.Notes: The estimate is the mean of four different regression estimates based upon humerus (n = 5) midshaft cortical area and four different regression estimates based upon femur (n = 6) midshaft cortical area. The reported body mass estimates are rounded versions of those provided in Fleagle and Gilbert 2008.
Mass.Reference: Werdelin and Sanders 2010 Cenozoic Mammals of Africa; Fleagle and Gilbert 2008 Elwyn Simons a Search for Origins
Diet.Method: Functional craniodental morphology; Proxy dental wear (microwear)
Diet.Notes: Dental wear indicates that this family were seed predators, consuming a mixed diet of foliage and fruit
Diet.Reference: Godfrey et al. 2004 Journal of Human Evolution; Crowley and Godfrey 2012 Leaping Ahead
Fermentation.Type.Method: Inferred from body mass; Inferred from sister Family
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Hindgut, but type unknown. Sister family to Indriidae, who have hindgut-caecum digestive systems. However, other than the capybara (45kg) there are few extant species, with caecum digestive systems and body masses much above 10kg (Hume 2002). Unlike the other extinct lemur families, family level inference based on body mass is suspect for Palaeopropithecidae as their body masses are highly variable (from 11kg to 160kg). Going to infer hindgut colon for Archaeoindris and hindgut caecum for the smaller bodied species.
Fermentation.Type.Reference: Campbell et al. 2000 American Journal of Primatology; Clauss et al. 2003 Oecologia
Habitat.Notes: Functional morphology suggests this species was less specialized for arboreal lifestyle than Palaeopropithecus, so presume some terrestriality
Habitat.Reference: Jungers et al. 1997 PNAS; Shapiro et al. 2005 American Journal of Physical Anthropology

Common.Name: Sloth Lemur
Mass.Notes: The estimate is the mean of four different regression estimates based upon humerus (n = 1) midshaft cortical area and four different regression estimates based upon femur (n = 1) midshaft cortical area. The reported body mass estimates are rounded versions of those provided in Fleagle and Gilbert 2008. Mesopropithecus pithecoides is called Mesopropithecus dolichobrachion in Fleagle and Gilbert 2008.

Common.Name: Short-faced Kangaroo
Mass.Notes: Primary source inaccessible
Diet.Notes: Classified as a Browser by Johnson and Prideux 2004 and Dawson 2006. No empirical, proxy information found.
Diet.Reference: Johnson and Prideaux 2004 Austral Ecology; Dawson 2006 Alcheringa
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Extinct kangaroo fermentation systems are unknown, but presumed to be similar to extant kangaroos. Extant kangaroos posssess foregut fermentation systems, but instead of them being divided into sacs, they are linear and have higher throughputs - comparable in function to hindgut colon fermentation in fact. Thus this system maximizes material flow and rate of fermentation at the expense of cell wall digestion. The implications of this is that food intake rates are less limited in macropods than in ruminants when foraging high fiber foods: as forage quality decreases ruminants reduce consumption rate (because they require longer fermentation times on high fiber foods), whereas macropod intake rate remains more or less constant.
Limb.Morphology.Notes: Monodactyl hoof-like unguligrade, convergent on 'open-plains horses', suggesting a cursorial form of locomotion. Functional morphology of the forelimbs (Janis et al. 2020) suggests that this group did not bear weight on their forearms and were likely strictly bipedal, even at slow speeds, unlike modern, extant kangaroos which become quadrupedal or pentapedal.
Limb.Morphology.Reference: Prideaux et al. 2009 PNAS; Janis et al. 2020 Journal of Mammalian Evolution
Habitat.Notes: No indication of aquatic habitat usage
Habitat.Reference: Johnson and Prideaux 2004 Austral Ecology; Dawson 2006 Alcheringa

Common.Name: Giant Warthog
Mass.Notes: Primary source inaccessible
Diet.Notes: Lazagabaster et al. 2018's isotopic analysis indicated that the giant warthog was a strict grazer.
Diet.Reference: Lazagabaster et al. 2018 Palaeogeography, Palaeoclimatology, Palaeoecology; Harris and Cerling 2002 Journal of Zoology
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Hindgut colon fermenting species sacrifice fermentation efficiency (e.g. completeness) for rate of passage. Cell-walls are only partially digested, but without the chokepoint provided by the rumen, they can continually consume vegetation thus meeting their nutrient demands. As such they are also able to consume lower-quality vegetation.
Fermentation.Type.Reference: Hume 2002 Acta Zoologica Sinica; Meijaard and Groves 2002 Asian Wild Pig News
Habitat.Method: Observed low sample size (1-5) habitat use; Inferred from absence of evidence
Habitat.Notes: No evidence of aquatic habitat use in this species or extant relatives
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Common.Name: Mixotoxodon
Mass.Notes: Primary source inaccessible
Diet.Notes: Recent isotopic evidence (Perez-Crespo 2020) indicates a mixed feeding diet, but sample size was small. Morphological evidence suggests grazer, as does older isotopic evidence.
Diet.Reference: MacFadden and Shockey 1997 Paleobiology; MacFadden 2005 Quaternary Research; Perez-Crespo et al. 2020 The Southwestern Naturalist
Fermentation.Type.Method: Functional craniodental morphology; Inferred from Infraclass
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Smith et al. (2010 Nature Geosciences) classify this group as foregut fermenters, without a reference. However, Madden 2014 Cambridge University Press, makes a cogent and thorough argument that their craniodental morphology converges with extant hindgut fermentation in terms of crown height, ever-growing teeth, large masticatory muscle mass. These traits do not appear in ruminants or foregut fermenters. Furthermore, hindgut fermentation is an ancestral condition and is likely based on relation of notoungulates to sister groups (Forasiepe et al. 2016)
Fermentation.Type.Reference: Madden 2014 Hypsodonty in Mammals: Evolution, Geomorphology, and the Role of Earth System Processes; Shockey 2001 Acta Palaeontologica Polonica; Forasiepe et al. 2016 Bulletin of the American Museum of Natural History
Limb.Morphology.Notes: Rhino/tapir like foot, probably supported by thick pad. Functionally digitigrade
Habitat.Notes: These animals potentially had aquatic hippo-like habits based on overall morphology, but they also appear to have 'locking' knee-joints suggesting a habit more like Perissodactylas. Evidence also suggests occurrence in rainforest and open grassland. Given state of the debate, we will mark this species as terrestrial.
Habitat.Reference: Shockey 2001 Acta Palaeontologica Polonica

Mass.Notes: Primary source inaccessible
Diet.Notes: Genus-level results only, which describes this genus as a mixed feeder on the grazing end of the spectrum
Diet.Reference: Rotti et al. 2018 Palaeogeography, Palaeoclimatology, Palaeoecology
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Method: Observed low sample size (1-5) habitat use; Inferred from absence of evidence
Habitat.Notes: No evidence of aquatic habitat use in this species or extant relatives
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Mass.Notes: Primary source inaccessible
Diet.Notes: Genus-level results only, which describes this genus as a mixed feeder on the grazing end of the spectrum

Common.Name: Alpine Musk Deer
Diet.Notes: Graminoids constituted 26-47% of diet, increasing to 47% after monsoons as they are limited to consuming tender, fresh grasses. Likewise Bhattacharya et al. 2012 found that graminoids constituted up to 50% of their diet during the autumn. Other studies (cited in Wilson and Mittermeier) have reported that alpine musk deer avoid grass. This contradiction may have to do with food availability and preference.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Syed and Ilyas 2015 Animal Production Science; Bhattacharya et al. 2012 Proceedings of the Zoological Society
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: Believe it or not, these musk deer use their elongated dew claws to climb into trees to forage for lichen. This is likely a rare event, but still, startling. Their smaller congener, the forest musk deer (M. berevoskii) is frequently in trees, and would score as arboreal, but is less than 10 kg. In general habitat is shrubland, which they prefer to meadows. Dwell on undisturbed shady slopes.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Common.Name: Kashmir Muskdeer
Mass.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World
Diet.Notes: Assumed to be similar to M. leucogaster and thus to be primarily a browser.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World

Habitat.Notes: This species dwells in conifer and oak forests as well as subalpine shrub. Poorly known.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Common.Name: Black Musk Deer
Mass.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World
Diet.Notes: No empirical evidence, only anecdotal of grass, moss, and forbs. Since this group lacks specialized grazers, treating graze conservatively with 2.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World

Common.Name: Himalayan Muskdeer
Mass.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World
Diet.Notes: Khadka et al. 2017 found very low consumption of graminoids through the year (~1-3%). Diet was primarily woody plants, followed by forbs (~10-20%). Wilson and Mittermeier confirmed this assessment with grasses composing ~7% and diet overall being composed of leaves, forbs, and moss.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Khadka et al. 2017 Journal for Nature Conservation
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: A denizen of oak-birch forests between 3000 and 4400 m, as well as in bamboo forest, and open pastures. High degree of habitat variation across range. No indication of aquatic habitat use.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Common.Name: Siberian Musk Deer
Diet.Notes: Domanov 2013 analyzed rumen contents (n=16) finding absolutely no graminoid vegetation. Diet was principly lichen and shrubs, with some forbs and fungi. Diet further reviewed in Slaght et al. 2019 Oryx with no graminoid consumption observed. According to Wilson and Mittermeier diet is primarily (60-91%) lichens, though this is in the north part of their range, with some minor contribution of browse, moss, forbs, and grass.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Domanov 2013 Russian Journal of Theriology
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: A species of mountain taiga, from 300 to 1600 m, occurring in rhododendron shrub, light conifer forest, and floodplain popular-willow forests. No evidence of aquatic habitat usage.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Mass.Notes: The comparison species is likely Pecari tajacu, which is slightly larger.
Mass.Reference: Stinnesbeck 2017 Journal of South American Earth Sciences
Diet.Notes: No empirical proxy evidence found.
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Peccaries have sacciform foregut digestive systems like hippos and camels, except unlike camels they do not ruminate (e.g. regurgitate partially fermented food for secondary mechanical grinding).
Habitat.Method: Observed low sample size (1-5) habitat use; Inferred from absence of evidence
Habitat.Notes: No evidence of aquatic habitat use in this species or extant relatives
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Common.Name: Robust Elephant Bird
Mass.Reference: Hansford and Turvey 2018 Royal Society Open Science
Diet.Notes: Isotopes indicate a browsing diet of C3 and possible CAM vegetation. This family was likely nocturnal, based on reconstruction of optical lobe (Torres et al. 2018).
Diet.Reference: Torres et al. 2018 Proceedings of the Royal Society B
Fermentation.Type.Method: Inferred from Infraclass; Inferred from diet
Fermentation.Type.Notes: No empirical evidence nor expert opinions regarding the fermentation type of these massive birds. Their nearest, albeit very distant, relative are kiwis in New Zealand (Mitchell et al. 2014), who are insectivores. Given their massive size, and the evolution of colon-based fermentation among other large-bodied ratites (rheas and ostriches), we are going to infer hindgut colon digestion. However, note that emus and cassuaries have only simple guts. It should be noted that all ratites lack crops (Sales 2006).
Fermentation.Type.Reference: Sales 2006 Avian and Poultry Biology Reviews
Limb.Morphology.Notes: Other than the miharung, which was unguligrade, and loons and grebes, which are plantigrade, all other birds are digitigrade
Habitat.Notes: No evidence found that elephant birds significantly used aquatic habitats. Given their body size they were certainly not arboreal.

Common.Name: Bornean Yellow Muntjac
Diet.Method: Expert Opinion; Observed low sample size (1-5) evidence
Diet.Notes: Little is known, but described as consuming leaves, buds, forbs, seeds, fruits, and grass. Given the dietary pattern of this Genus, scoring graminoids as 1.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World

However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. Habitat.Notes: This species is reported to avoid mountains and use primary and secondary forests in Borneo.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Diet.Method: Expert Opinion; Observed low sample size (1-5) evidence
Diet.Notes: Primarily feeds on leaves and fruits, but also consumes some grasses and shoots.

Common.Name: Gongshan Muntjac
Diet.Notes: Nothing is known about this species, but probably a browser.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World

Common.Name: Sumatran Mountain Muntjac
Diet.Notes: This species was formerly classified as a subspecies of M. muntjak, so we use this species as a proxy. M. muntjak consumes a mixture of browse (buds, fruit, young leaves, twigs, small seeds) and sometimes green grass. Considered a major disperser of fruits.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: This species was formerly classified as a subspecies of M. muntjak, so we use this species as a proxy. M. muntjak is a forest-dwelling generalist, of deciduous and evergreen forests, including both old-growth and secondary, as well as plantations. Also uses grasslands and croplands near forest edge, and in parts of its range will use shrubland and savanna.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Common.Name: Southern Red Muntjac
Diet.Notes: Primarily a frugivorous browser, consuming fruits, buds, young leaves, seeds, and twigs. Also has been observed feeding on green grass at forest edges. Thought to play important roles in seed dispersal.

This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Method: Observed low sample size (1-5) habitat use; Inferred from absence of evidence
Habitat.Notes: Little known, a remote and only recently rediscovered species to western science. Occcurs in forets over 1000 m in elevation.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Common.Name: Annamite Muntjac
Mass.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World
Diet.Notes: Little known, but described as a browser and frugivore.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: A denizen of evergreen forests over 1000 m. No indication of particular aquatic habitat use.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Common.Name: Northern Red Muntjac
Diet.Notes: Exclusively consume C3 food resources, which in the tropics indicates browsing. Little else is known.
Diet.Reference: Pokharel et al. 2015 Journal of Biological Research-Thessaloniki
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Method: Observed low sample size (1-5) habitat use; Inferred from absence of evidence
Habitat.Notes: Very little is known about this species. Given that no other muntjak significantly uses aquatic habitats, we will infer 0 for this trait.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Common.Name: Large-antlered Muntjac
Mass.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World
Diet.Notes: Little known, but described as a browser and frugivore.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: Denizen of primary evergreen and semi-evergreen forests, though has been observed in secondary forests. No evidence of aquatic habitat usage in this species.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Common.Name: Darwin's Ground Sloth
Mass.Reference: McDonald 2005 Bulletin of the Florida Museum of Natural History
Diet.Notes: Morphological evidence suggests that this species, unlike Glossotherium or Lestodon, was a selective feeder with a mixed diet. Mylodontidae coprolites (considered by some to be of Mylodon darwinii) were dominated by Carex (Cyperaceae) and various Graminaea vegetation, as well as substantial herbaceous (forb) vegetation such as Ranunculus, Plantago, Plagiobathrys, Oreobolus, all indicators of boggy sedge-grasslands. However specific percentages of each plant type are not reported (Moore 1978).
Diet.Reference: Bargo et al. 2006 Journal of Morphology; Bargo and Vizcaino 2008 Ameghiniana; Moore 1978 Botanical Journal of the Linnean Society; Velazquez et al. 2015 Quaternary International
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Smith et al. 2010 Nature Geoscience lists sloths as hindgut fermenters, because of their body size. However, all extant sloth species are foregut fermenters (Clauss 2004 Mammal Review). Fermentation type is a conservative trait, and extant two-toed and three-toed sloth species are more closely related to various of the now-extinct ground sloths than they are to each other (Pujos et al. 2012 Journal of Mammalian Evolution; Presslee et al. 2019 Nature Ecology and Evolution). Foregut fermentation is either the ancestral fermentation type of all sloth species, or it evolved at least twice in distinct (extant) sloth lineages. The most parsimonious fermentation type for extinct sloths would thus be foregut fermentation. However, Megatheriids pose a biological anamoly as there are no foregut fermentation species known at those body sizes (largest known was Sivatherium, a giraffid at 1250 kg). Vizcaino et al. 2006 and Clauss et al. 2003 suggests therefore that the extremely large Megatheriid sloths (Genera Megatherium and Eremotherium) may have been hindgut fermenters. As is, without better evidence, we will consider all sloths outliers in the ilk of Sivatherium and classify them as foregut fermenters until better evidence is available.
Fermentation.Type.Reference: McDonald and Pelikan 2006 Quaternary International; Clauss 2004 Mammal Review; Pujos et al. 2012 Journal of Mammalian Evolution; Presslee et al. 2019 Nature Ecology and Evolution; Vizcaino et al. 2006 Ameghiniana; Clauss et al. 2003 Oecologia
Limb.Morphology.Notes: Quantitative geometric morphometrics suggest this family was especially adapted for digging (de Oliveira and Santos 2008)
Limb.Morphology.Reference: Naish 2012 Tetrapod Zoology; de Oliveira and Santos 2018 Journal of Morphology
Habitat.Notes: Functional morphology suggests a terrestrial habit.
Habitat.Reference: Pujos et al. 2012 Journal of Mammalian Evolution

Common.Name: Long-nosed Peccary
Mass.Notes: Primary source inaccessible
Diet.Method: Functional craniodental morphology; Proxy isotopes (C13); Proxy dental wear (microwear)
Diet.Notes: Bradham et al. 2018 analyzed microwear and isotopes from the Miocene to the Late Pleistocene. Mylohyus was a browser/frugivore/seed-eater during earlier land mammal ages, but during the later part of the Pleistocene (Rancholabrean) evidence indicates an increase in consumption of abrasive vegetation (grasses) and potentially the utilization of more open habitats. All peccaries are reported frequently having small amounts of insect and vertebrate matter in their stomachs and have been observed feeding on carrion and killing small mammals. Thus inferring a 1 for meat across peccaries.
Diet.Reference: Koch and Barnosky 2006 Annual Review of Ecology, Evolution, and Systematics; Bradham et al. 2018 Palaeogeography, Palaeoclimatology, Palaeocology
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Peccaries have sacciform foregut digestive systems like hippos and camels, except unlike camels they do not ruminate (e.g. regurgitate partially fermented food for secondary mechanical grinding).
Habitat.Method: Observed low sample size (1-5) habitat use; Inferred from absence of evidence
Habitat.Notes: No evidence of aquatic habitat use in this species or extant relatives
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Common.Name: Myotragus balearicus
Mass.Notes: The estimate is based on three forelimb and three hindlimb dimensions: the antero-posterior diameter of the distal humerus, the antero-posterior diameter of the proximal radius, the transversal diameter of the proximal metacarpal, the transversal diameter of the distal tibia, the antero-posterior diameter of the distal tibia, and the transversal diameter of the proximal metatarsal. The value is an based on more than 40 specimens across five different localities.
Mass.Reference: Turvey and Fritz 2011 Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society B; Kohler and Soya-Mola 2004 Brain, Behavior and Evolution
Diet.Notes: Coprolites (n=65) were composed almost entirely of woody vegetation, principally box Boxus balearica, a woody shrub with high content of alkaloids.
Diet.Reference: Alcover et al. 1999 Biological Journal of the Linnean Society
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Method: Functional morphology; Inferred from absence of evidence
Habitat.Notes: Most likely foraged on steep cliffs. No evidence of aquatic habitat use.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Common.Name: Red Goral
Diet.Notes: No strong detailed empirical studies have been done. According to Wilson and Mittermeier 2011, their primary diet are lichens, though they also consume grass, forbs, and browse.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: Prefers higher elevations than other goral species. Dwells in steep terrain vegetated with conifer woodlands, scrub, and meadows. No evidence of aquatic habitat usage.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Common.Name: Long-tailed Goral
Diet.Notes: Diet is seasonally variable but primarily graminoids, comprising 77-82%, while in the summer browsing dominates.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: Currently restricted to steep, high elevation habitats. Fossil evidence however indicates that this species was much more widespread, occurring in lower elevations and less topographically complex areas until the Paleolithic, when humans presumably hunted this species.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; Kim et al. 2019 Quaternary International

Common.Name: Himalayan Goral
Diet.Notes: Ashraf et al. 2016 found their diet to be primarily forbs, followed by shrubs and graze, however, Wilson and Mittermeier report that their diet is more than 90% graze.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Ashraf et al. 2017 Mammalia

However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: This species occupies rugged, steep, high elevation terrain (649-3789 m) on wooded mountains, preferring dense cover of trees and thorny scrubs.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; Ahmad et al. 2020 Global Ecology and Conservation

Common.Name: Chinese Goral
Mass.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World
Diet.Method: Expert Opinion; Observed low sample size (1-5) evidence
Diet.Notes: Wilson and Mittermeier indicate that this species is most likely a grazer. No empirical studies known. Given that being a hypergrazer is not a common trait, particularly among gorals, assigning 2 for browse .
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. Common.Name: Dama Gazelle
Diet.Notes: Selectively grazes only during the rainy season and early dry season (Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa)
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Hempson et al. 2015 Science; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa

However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: Prefers sparsely wooded grassland and even dense woodlands, though landscape change and persecution have pushed into desert habitats.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa

Common.Name: Grant's Gazelle
Diet.Notes: ~70% of the diet of Grant's gazelle is browse. Browse consumption increases with rainfall.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa

This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: This gazelle inhabits open savannas to hot, semi-deserts. In savanna-systems they prefer open glades.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa

Common.Name: Soemmerring's Gazelle
Diet.Notes: Prefers grasses and forbs, but will switch to shrubs during the dry season.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa

However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: Little known, but reported as preferring hilly open country with scattered thickets and the Acacia-Commiphora steppe.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Common.Name: Viti Levu Giant Pigeon
Mass.Method: Inferred from relative of suggested similar size
Mass.Notes: Worthy 2001 says Natunaornis gigoura is slightly smaller than Raphus cucullatus (HerbiTraits Estimate: 12.4 kg). Based on this we estimated that the mass of Natunaornis gigoura is 12 kg. We did not find precise mass estimates
Mass.Reference: HerbiTraits; Worthy 2001 Journal of the Royal Society of New Zealand
Diet.Notes: No empirical evidence found. Similar convergent morphology as the dodo, so we are inferring a diet of frugivory as well.
Fermentation.Type.Method: Inferred from diet; Inferred from Family
Fermentation.Type.Notes: No evidence for fermentation structure. Columbiformes in general have a simple stomach without fermentation (Clench and Mathias 1995), absorbing only readily available nutrients. though these highly derived megafaunal columbiforms may have secondarily evolved fermentation chambers. This remains unknown and unlikely given the putative frugivorous diets. Leaving certainty at 0.
Limb.Morphology.Notes: Other than the miharung, which was unguligrade, and loons and grebes, which are plantigrade, all other birds are digitigrade
Habitat.Notes: These dodo-like 'megafaunal' pigeons were flightless and most likely terrestrial in habit, though their use of aquatic environments has not been addressed and can't be ruled out.
Habitat.Reference: Rijsdijk et al. 2009 Quaternary Science Reviews

Common.Name: American mountain deer
Diet.Notes: No empirical evidence.
Diet.Reference: Smith et al. 2018 Science; Smith et al. 2003 Ecology
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Method: Observed low sample size (1-5) habitat use; Inferred from absence of evidence
Habitat.Notes: No evidence of aquatic habitat use in this species or extant relatives
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Common.Name: Giant Capybara
Mass.Notes: Primary source inaccessible
Diet.Notes: Smith et al. 2018 designates this species a grazer, likely inferring diet from extant capybaras.
Diet.Reference: Smith et al. 2018 Science; Smith et al. 2003 Ecology
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Capybaras are the largest species with caecum digestive systems and body masses much above 10kg (Hume 2002). We will take an inferential leap and consider giant capybaras as also having caecum digestive systems. Rodents possess hindgut caecum fermentation systems. Hindgut caecum fermenters are generally smaller-bodied than hindgut colon fermenters. In colon fermenters the caecum is largely modified to become part of the colon, whereas in caecum fermenters, they remain separate structures. Caecums are generally modified into complex structures that retain solutes and fine particles for fermentation while larger particles are excreted through colon, reducing the extent of plant-wall breakdown.
Fermentation.Type.Reference: Hume 2002 Acta Zoologica Sinica; Clauss et al. 2003 Oecologia
Habitat.Method: Observed low sample size (1-5) habitat use
Habitat.Notes: This giant capybara was most certainly also semi-aquatic, as this appears to be a conserved trait among this lineage.
Habitat.Reference: MacFadden and Shockey 1997 Paleobiology; Perez et al. 2017 Journal of Mammalian Evolution

Mass.Reference: Turvey and Fritz 2011 Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society B
Diet.Notes: Morphometrics of jaw bite forces and grinding motions suggest a diet similar to extant Bradypus sloths who are folivorous (McAfee 2011), as opposed to Choleopus sloths who are frugivorous-folivorous
Diet.Reference: McAfee 2011 Journal of Morphology

However, all extant sloth species are foregut fermenters (Clauss 2004 Mammal Review). Fermentation type is a conservative trait, and extant two-toed and three-toed sloth species are more closely related to various of the now-extinct ground sloths than they are to each other (Pujos et al. 2012 Journal of Mammalian Evolution; Presslee et al. 2019 Nature Ecology and Evolution). Foregut fermentation is either the ancestral fermentation type of all sloth species, or it evolved at least twice in distinct (extant) sloth lineages. The most parsimonious fermentation type for extinct sloths would thus be foregut fermentation. However, Megatheriids pose a biological anamoly as there are no foregut fermentation species known at those body sizes (largest known was Sivatherium, a giraffid at 1250 kg). Vizcaino et al. 2006 and Clauss et al. 2003 suggests therefore that the extremely large Megatheriid sloths (Genera Megatherium and Eremotherium) may have been hindgut fermenters. As is, without better evidence, we will consider all sloths outliers in the ilk of Sivatherium and classify them as foregut fermenters until better evidence is available.
Fermentation.Type.Reference: McDonald and Pelikan 2006 Quaternary International; Clauss 2004 Mammal Review; Pujos et al. 2012 Journal of Mammalian Evolution; Presslee et al. 2019 Nature Ecology and Evolution; Vizcaino et al. 2006 Ameghiniana; Clauss et al. 2003 Oecologia
Limb.Morphology.Notes: Most taxa had the capacity, given their wide structural vertebral, to forage upright, resting on their tail. Appendicular morphology, particularly of the humerus, of all sloth families, other than the Mylodontidae, suggest a generalized locomotion habit (de Oliveira and Santos 2008).
Limb.Morphology.Reference: Naish 2012 Tetrapod Zoology; de Oliveira and Santos 2018 Journal of Morphology
Habitat.Notes: Functional morphology suggests a semi-arboreal habit.
Habitat.Reference: Grass 2014 Thesis

Mass.Reference: Turvey and Fritz 2011 Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society B
