Diet.Notes: C3 diet, but mesodont teeth. Microwear indicates a folivorous diet and an absence of silicaceous grass material
Diet.Reference: Morosi and Ubilla 2017 Historical Biology; Corona et al. 2019 Andean Geology
Fermentation.Type.Method: Functional craniodental morphology; Inferred from Infraclass
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Smith et al. (2010 Nature Geosciences) classify this group as foregut fermenters, without a reference. Cassini et al (2012) argued based on occlusal surface area that litopterns were hindgut fermenters. However, Madden (2014) concluded that the masticatory muscle mass was more similar to foregut fermenters. Forasiepe et al. (2016) was unable to replicate Madden's analytic results and argues that based on the pleisiomorphy (e.g. ancestral state) of hindgut fermentation in ungulates hindgut fermentation is the most plausible condition. We will follow Forasiepe et al. 2016, acknowledging zero certainty.
Fermentation.Type.Reference: Forasiepe et al. 2016 Bulletin of the American Museum of Natural History; Cassini et al 2012 Early Miocene Paleobiology in Patagonia/Vizcaino; Madden 2014 Hypsodonty in Mammals: Evolution, Geomorphology, and the Role of Earth System Processes; Shockey 2001 Acta Palaeontologica Polonica
Habitat.Method: Inferred from absence of evidence; Inferred from habitat association (proxy isotopes C13, N15)
Habitat.Notes: Isotopes indicate that these were denizens of open forest environments (Morosi and Ubilla 2017). No indication of aquatic habitat usage
Habitat.Reference: Morosi and Ubilla 2017 Historical Biology

Mass.Notes: Primary source inaccessible
Diet.Notes: Isotopes indicate a grazing preference, but a mixed feeder in closed canopy environments; data only given for genus. Reported as Sclerocalyptus
Diet.Reference: Franca et al. 2015 Earth Science Reviews
Fermentation.Type.Method: Functional craniodental morphology; Inferred from diet; Proxy isotopes (C13, N15)
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Likely hindgut, but type unknown. The extant relatives, armadillos, are insectivores and have simple sac stomachs. Some have suggested the same for glyptodonts (Bocherens et al. 2017 Gondwana Research), but it seems impossible that they would sustain their metabolism as obigate herbivores without fermentation. Bocherens et al. (2017 Gondwana Research) found that their isotopic values (for Doedicurus spp, Glyptodon spp, Glyptotherium) suggested either aquatic habitat or a fast fermentation rate. Vizcaino et al. (2011 Ameghiniana) suggested that given the estimated low metabolic rate of Xenarthans but the relatively complex teeth of cingulates compared to sloths, that sloths have more efficient fermentation in digestive tract than glyptodonts. The best evidence indicates that sloths had foregut non-ruminant digestion.  Hindgut digestion is the most  ancestral type, far less derived than foregut fermentation. We will therefore infer that these animals were likely hindgut and also hingut colon, since there are few large mammals that use caecums
Fermentation.Type.Reference: Smith et al. 2010 Nature Geoscience; Bocherens et al. 2017 Gondwana Research; Vizcaino et al. 2011 Ameghiniana
Limb.Morphology.Notes: Plantigrady is one component of a suite of traits, including armor, low metabolism, ability to withstand hypoxia, and other slow life history habits
Limb.Morphology.Reference: Superina and Loughry 2011 Journal of Mammalian Evolution
Habitat.Notes: No published evidence of aquatic habitat use in this species. While some extinct glyptodonts have some weak and contradictory evidence suggesting a semi-aquatic habit, we will not make inferences to this taxa.

Mass.Method: Inferred from relative of suggested similar size
Mass.Notes: Source does not mention which comparison species has been used to estimate the size

Common.Name: Nilgiri Tahr
Diet.Method: Functional craniodental morphology; Observed fecal analysis; Observed foraging
Diet.Notes: Morphology suggests grazer. Indeed, in areas (and seasons) where graminoids are readily available, they appear to prefer graze. However, during dry seasons and in certain habitats they consume browse with apparently no impact.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Heywood 2010 Journal of Zoology
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: Nilgiri tahrs are inhabiitants of montane grasslands near steep slopes, which they use as escape terrain. The only caprinid in the tropics.  No indication of semi-aquatic habits.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; Sony et al. 2018 Ecological Engineering

Common.Name: Shasta Ground Sloth
Mass.Reference: Davis 2017 Proceedings of the Royal Society B; McDonald 2005 Bulletin of the Florida Museum of Natural History
Diet.Notes: Coprolites contained (in order of magnitude and identified via DNA barcoding) Pinaceae, Moraceae, Brassicaceae, Liliaceae, Poaceae, Boragaceae, Lamiacaea, and Chenopodiaceae (Poinar et al. 1998, Hofreiter et al. 2000). Dental microwear analysis showed close similarity to extant Bradypus, suggesting folivory (Green 2009). Yet the coprolites and functional morphology suggest a more mixed diet, including more roughage and fruits and some grass.
Diet.Reference: Hansen 1978 Paleobiology; Poinar et al. 1998 Science; Hofreiter et al. 2000 Molecular Ecology; Green 2009 Zoological Journal of the Linnean Society
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Smith et al. 2010 Nature Geoscience lists sloths as hindgut fermenters, because of their body size. However, all extant sloth species are foregut fermenters (Clauss 2004 Mammal Review). Fermentation type is a conservative trait, and extant two-toed and three-toed sloth species are more closely related to various of the now-extinct ground sloths than they are to each other (Pujos et al. 2012 Journal of Mammalian Evolution; Presslee et al. 2019 Nature Ecology and Evolution). Foregut fermentation is either the ancestral fermentation type of all sloth species, or it evolved at least twice in distinct (extant) sloth lineages. The most parsimonious fermentation type for extinct sloths would thus be foregut fermentation. However, Megatheriids pose a biological anamoly as there are no foregut fermentation species known at those body sizes (largest known was Sivatherium, a giraffid at 1250 kg). Vizcaino et al. 2006 and Clauss et al. 2003 suggests therefore that the extremely large Megatheriid sloths (Genera Megatherium and Eremotherium) may have been hindgut fermenters. As is, without better evidence, we will consider all sloths outliers in the ilk of Sivatherium and classify them as foregut fermenters until better evidence is available.
Fermentation.Type.Reference: McDonald and Pelikan 2006 Quaternary International; Clauss 2004 Mammal Review; Pujos et al. 2012 Journal of Mammalian Evolution; Presslee et al. 2019 Nature Ecology and Evolution; Vizcaino et al. 2006 Ameghiniana; Clauss et al. 2003 Oecologia
Limb.Morphology.Notes: Most taxa had the capacity, given their wide structural vertebral, to forage upright, resting on their tail. Appendicular morphology, particularly of the humerus, of all sloth families, other than the Mylodontidae, suggest a generalized locomotion habit (de Oliveira and Santos 2008).
Limb.Morphology.Reference: Naish 2012 Tetrapod Zoology; de Oliveira and Santos 2018 Journal of Morphology
Habitat.Notes: Functional morphology suggests a terrestrial habit.
Habitat.Reference: Grass 2014 Thesis

Mass.Notes: Primary source inaccessible
Diet.Method: Proxy dental wear (mesowear); Proxy isotopes (C13, O18)
Diet.Notes: Dental wear indicates browser (Saarinen and Karme 2017), as does isotopic data (Omena et al. 2020), which has incorporated values from previous studies (e.g. Dantas et al 2019)
Diet.Reference: Saarinen and Karme 2017 Palaeogeography, Palaeoclimatology, Palaeoecology; Omena et al. 2020 Historical Biology; Dantas et al. 2019 Historical Biology
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Smith et al. 2010 Nature Geoscience lists sloths as hindgut fermenters, because of their body size. However, all extant sloth species are foregut fermenters (Clauss 2004 Mammal Review). Fermentation type is a conservative trait, and extant two-toed and three-toed sloth species are more closely related to various of the now-extinct ground sloths than they are to each other (Pujos et al. 2012 Journal of Mammalian Evolution; Presslee et al. 2019 Nature Ecology and Evolution). Foregut fermentation is either the ancestral fermentation type of all sloth species, or it evolved at least twice in distinct (extant) sloth lineages. The most parsimonious fermentation type for extinct sloths would thus be foregut fermentation. However, Megatheriids pose a biological anamoly as there are no foregut fermentation species known at those body sizes (largest known was Sivatherium, a giraffid at 1250 kg). Vizcaino et al. 2006 and Clauss et al. 2003 suggests therefore that the extremely large Megatheriid sloths (Genera Megatherium and Eremotherium) may have been hindgut fermenters. As is, without better evidence, we will consider all sloths outliers in the ilk of Sivatherium and classify them as foregut fermenters until better evidence is available.
Fermentation.Type.Reference: McDonald and Pelikan 2006 Quaternary International; Clauss 2004 Mammal Review; Pujos et al. 2012 Journal of Mammalian Evolution; Presslee et al. 2019 Nature Ecology and Evolution; Vizcaino et al. 2006 Ameghiniana; Clauss et al. 2003 Oecologia
Limb.Morphology.Notes: Most taxa had the capacity, given their wide structural vertebral, to forage upright, resting on their tail. Appendicular morphology, particularly of the humerus, of all sloth families, other than the Mylodontidae, suggest a generalized locomotion habit (de Oliveira and Santos 2008).
Limb.Morphology.Reference: Naish 2012 Tetrapod Zoology; de Oliveira and Santos 2018 Journal of Morphology
Habitat.Notes: Functional morphology suggests a terrestrial habit.
Habitat.Reference: Pujos et al. 2012 Journal of Mammalian Evolution

Common.Name: Gomphothere
Diet.Method: Functional craniodental morphology; Proxy dental wear (microwear); Proxy isotopes (C13)
Diet.Notes: Franca et al. 2014 used isotopes and described N. platensis as primarily a grazer (n = 4), whereas Asevedo et al. (2012) used microwear and craniodental morphology, and a larger sample size to describe them as pure mixed feeders (n = 21). Omena et al. 2020 conducted isotopic analyses confirming a diet that included C4 vegetation, but that T. platensis was still a mixed feeder. Dantas et al. 2020 showed a diet (with isotopes) principly of C4 grass (83%), followed by fruits (12%), and few leaves (5%). Pansani et al. 2019 found true mixed feeding for this species. Going to leave as mixed feeder with preference for graze.
Diet.Reference: Dantas et al. 2013 Quaternary Research; Asevedo et al. 2012 Quaternary International; Franca et al. 2014 Quaternary Science Reviews; Omena et al. 2020 Historical Biology; Pansani et al. 2019 Quaternary Science Reviews; Dantas et al. 2020 Quaternary Science Reviews
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Hindgut colon fermenting species sacrifice fermentation efficiency (e.g. completeness) for rate of passage. Cell-walls are only partially digested, but without the chokepoint provided by the rumen, they can continually consume vegetation thus meeting their nutrient demands. As such they are also able to consume lower-quality vegetation.
Habitat.Notes: Extant relatives and diet suggest a terrestrial habit, with only opportunistic use of aquatic environments.
Habitat.Reference: Franca et al. 2014 Quaternary Science Reviews

Common.Name: Mule Deer
Diet.Notes: Wilson and Mittermeier describe mule deer as opportunistic intermediate feeders, who primarily consume browse.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: This species prefers edgy ecotonal habitats, across a range of environments. In general occupies open forest and shrubland, with steep and broken terrain. Some populations occur in rainforest and desert as well.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Common.Name: White-tailed Deer
Diet.Notes: A browser with flexible and diverse feeding capacity of young leaves, buds, twigs, forbs, fruits, and seeds.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: White-tailed deer are habitat generalists, but generally prefer successional, pioneer habitats. In forested climates, they prefer meadow-forest edges. Where they cooccur with mule deer (O. hemionus) the two species sort by habitat, with white-tailed deer occupying more mesic environments
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Common.Name: Okapi
Diet.Notes: Highly selective foragers that preferentially feed in treefall gaps. Ferns, forbs, and grasses are rarely consumed.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: A deep rainforest species of the Congo River, avoiding human settlements, extensive swamp forest or fully inundated sites, and open gallery forests. Prefer closed canopy primary or old secondary forest types.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Common.Name: Mountain Goat
Diet.Notes: Cobb et al. 2012 showed 100% reliance on browse in their introduced range, but that could be habitat-driven. Elsewhere, mountain goats consume ~50% grasses, 30% forbs, and 16% browse. Highly variable regionally, with some populations subsisting on lichen, some eating 90% grasses. Generally, they prefer graminoids but have the capacity to survive on browse, forbs, lichen, or grasses.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Cobb et al. 2012 Biennial Symposium of the Northern Wild Sheep and Goat Council
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: Mountain specialists who rarely stray more than 500 m from rocky escape habitat. Occur above and below treeline.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; Poole and Heard 2003 The Canadian Field-Naturalist

Common.Name: Harrington's mountain goat
Mass.Notes: Primary source inaccessible. We could access one of the three sources: Stuart 1991 Biological Reviews, 66: 453-562. This provides a different mass estimate for the species (30 kg) than Smith et al. 2003 does. Thus estimate mentioned in Smith et al. 2003 estimate likely stems from one of the other sources
Diet.Notes: Coprolites from these extinct mountain goats were composed of 33-47% grass (Sporobolus, Festuca, Oryopsis, and Agropyron) followed by conifers (Picea and Pseudotsuga).
Diet.Reference: Mead et al. 1986 Journal of Mammalogy
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: Habitat during the Late Pleistocene consisted of vertiginous escape terrain and forests of spruce (Picea engelmanii), limber pine (Pinus flexilis), rose (Rosa woodsii), and douglas fir (Psuedotsuga menziesii). Unlikely to have significantly used aquatic or arboreal environments
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; Mead et al. 1987 Quaternary Research

Common.Name: Klipspringer
Diet.Method: Observed fecal analysis; Observed foraging; Proxy isotopes (C13)
Diet.Notes: Only 4% of klipspringer's diet is grass. Hyperbrowsers.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: Occur across a great range of rainfall and vegetation types but dependent on rocky and mountainous terrain. They typically feed at the bases of rocky cliffs, which they retreat to to rest or escape predators.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa

Common.Name: Beisa Oryx
Mass.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World
Diet.Method: Observed fecal analysis; Observed foraging; Proxy isotopes (C13)
Diet.Notes: Direct observations of beisa oryx feeding have recorded a diet of 83% grass and 8.5% forb, 7.9% browse. This becomes more browse-heavy in the dry season. Carbon isotopes indicate 88% C4 diet. Reviewed in Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: Beisa prefer arid and semi-arid grasslands and shrublands, avoiding tallgrass and inundated soils.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa

Common.Name: Scimitar-horned Oryx
Species.Status: Extinct after 1500 CE, but wild in introduced range
Diet.Notes: Scimitar-horned oryx prefer to graze but will consume a substantial amount of browse (Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa)
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: Preferred habitat was the arid Sahelian steppe of grass, shrub, and drought-resistant trees. The expansion of Sahara divided population in two.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa

Common.Name: Gemsbok
Diet.Notes: Adapted to extremely high-fiber diets (Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa). Described as a grazer by Wilson and Mittermeier, confirmed by Codron et al. 2018 in their compilation of numerous dietary analyses (75% graze), and echoed by Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa. However other empirical evidence, from their introduced range in New Mexico, shows 33% composition of shrub, forb, and grass respectively, indicating mixed feeder preferring browse (as we are classifying forbs as browse). Given that graze may be predominant in their native range, calling gemsbok a full mixed feeder in capacity. These results were echoed in Lehmann's thesis where gemsbok consumed 60% grass and forb, and 30% shrub.
Diet.Reference: Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa; Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Lehmann 2015 Thesis; Cain et al. 2017 Wildlife Biology; Codron et al. 2018 Ecology and Evolution
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: Gemsbok prefer open semi-arid to arid grasslands with stands of woodland and shrub. Will venture into arid mountains and dune fields. Dry river beds and pans are important for the salt they provide and because they are known to dig wells to access groundwater.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa; Hamilton et al. 1977 Madoqua

Common.Name: Arabian Oryx
Diet.Notes: Arabian oryx prefer to graze, but commonly consume forbs, browse, roots, and tubers. Can go indefinitely without water, obtaining from succulent vegetation where available.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: Denizens of arid to semi-arid deserts. Given widespread population collapse, little is known about prior habitat affinities. A free-water independent species.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; Ismail et al. 2011 Journal of Arid Environments

Common.Name: Oribi
Diet.Method: Observed fecal analysis; Observed foraging; Proxy isotopes (C13)
Diet.Notes: Classified as variable grazers by Wilson and Mittermeier and Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa, which was confirmed by Codron et al. 2018 (90% graze based on compilation of dietary analyses). However, Djagoun et al. 2013 found that they were C3 browsers in their study area, indicating greater dietary flexibility than usually thought.
Diet.Reference: Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa; Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Djagoun et al. 2013 South African Journal of Wildlife Research
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: Inhabitant of flat and gently sloping grasslands and mixed woodlands with open understories, as maintained by fire or grazing. Thought to be free-water independent yet proximity to water does appear to be important in more arid parts of their range. Vegetation can vary from dry scrub to to montane grassland to coastal savanna. Across these habitats, oribi select high visibility pastures of short to medium sized grasses
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa

Common.Name: Muskox
Diet.Notes: About 33% of muskox diet are graminoids, the rest is browse supplemented some moss and lichen.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: Will scrape for snow to depths of 20-40cm. Very few muskox live along tree line ecotones, or below tree line, potentially due to competition from reindeer/caribou.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Common.Name: Argali
Diet.Notes: Classified as a grazer by Wilson and Mittermeier for primarily eating grassses, followed by forbs and seasonal browsing. Fecal analysis showed seasonal switching from grazing (winter and spring) to browsing of shrubs and forbs (summer and fall) (Wingard et al. 2011). Li et al. 2018 found similar heavy reliance on browse. Thus considering this a mixed feeder
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wingard et al. 2011 Journal of Arid Environments; Li et al. 2018 China Journal of Arid Land
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: This species dwells in undulating terrain with steep escape-terrain adjacent, though Wilson and Mittermeier note that they often escape predation without using escape terrain. For the most part, prefer arid habitats, including tundra, avoiding humid and densely vegetated areas.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Common.Name: Bighorn Sheep
Diet.Notes: In some regions, e.g. Sonoran Desert, bighorn sheep are primarily browsers (Guerrero-Cardenas et al. 2016 Therya). However, elsewhere, they are grazers, particularly during summer (Klinger et al. 2015). In general, it appears that they prefer graminoids.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Guerrero-Cardenas et al. 2016 Therya
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: Large range of habitats across distribution, from Mexico to Canada. In general, denizens of steep, vertiginous terrain, usually avoiding areas with obstructing vegetation.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Common.Name: Thinhorn Sheep; Dall's Sheep
Diet.Notes: Prefers to graze, often constituting ~80% of diet, although forbs and shrubs can be seasonally dominant, particularly in winter.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: Denizens of steep terrain in their high northern range,  tending to alpine, subalpine, and at times forested elevations.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Common.Name: Snow Sheep
Diet.Method: Expert Opinion; Observed low sample size (1-5) evidence
Diet.Notes: Prefer graze, but will consume browse, fungi, and lichens. Browse is particularly important in winter.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: Like other ovids, snow sheep dwell in or close to precitipitous country, which they use as escape terrain. Occur from sea to level to 1800 m, from marine coastal mountains to alpine tundra.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Common.Name: Mouflon
Diet.Notes: According to the Handbook of the Mammals of the World, O. orientalis is a hybrid between O. gmelini and O.cycloceros. Sheep are generally considered grazers, however the diet of mouflon in Spain was reported as primarily forbs and shrubs.Classifying this species as a 3-2 graze-browse
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Cransac et al. 1997 Revue dEcologie; Miranda et al. 2012 Wildlife Research
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: O. orientalis is a disputed species concept, split into three by Wilson and Mittermeier. Those three species use a variety of habitats, from steep, vertiginous terrain, to lowland river valleys.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Common.Name: Domestic sheep
Diet.Notes: Sheep prefer grass but also consume forbs and shrubs. They particularly like pasture forbs, such as clover and alfalfa.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Cransac et al. 1997 Revue dEcologie
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: Their introduced range (primarily on islands) has a broad spectrum of habitat types, from arid to tropical. In the absence of predation likely not dependent on steep escape terrain.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Common.Name: Pampas Deer
Diet.Notes: Graminoids constituted 17-34% of diet, peaking in wet season and averaging 22% year-round (Desbiez et al. 2011 Mammalian Biology)
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Desbiez et al. 2011 Mammalian Biology
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: Pampas deer occupy grasslands, bot savanna, pampas, and seasonally flooded grasslands.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Common.Name: Giant Ruffed Lemur
Mass.Notes: The estimate is the mean of four different regression estimates based upon humerus (n = 9) midshaft cortical area and four different regression estimates based upon femur (n = 9) midshaft cortical area. The reported body mass estimates are rounded versions of those provided in Fleagle and Gilbert 2008.
Mass.Reference: Werdelin and Sanders 2010 Cenozoic Mammals of Africa; Fleagle and Gilbert 2008 Elwyn Simons a Search for Origins
Diet.Method: Functional craniodental morphology; Proxy dental wear (microwear)
Diet.Notes: Dental wear indicates that this Genus were frugivores and folivores, but not seed predators. Isotopic data from fossil lemurs appears to not support general assumptions of isotopic inference and should not be used to understand these groups (Crowley and Godfrey 2012)
Diet.Reference: Godfrey et al. 2004 Journal of Human Evolution; Crowley et al. 2011 American Journal of Primatology; Crowley and Godfrey 2012 Leaping Ahead
Fermentation.Type.Method: Inferred from Family; Inferred from body size
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Extant Lemuridae have caecum digestive systems. Other than the capybara (45kg) there are few extant species, with caecum digestive systems and body masses much above 10kg (Hume 2002). Given the large size of these lemurs, we will infer Hindgut colon digestive systems. Leaving reliability at a 1 since higher intra-family diversity in fermentation strategy is likely given the highly divergent body size of this group.
Fermentation.Type.Reference: Campbell et al. 2000 American Journal of Primatology; Clauss et al. 2003 Oecologia
Habitat.Notes: Morphology suggests a semi-arboreal habit.
Habitat.Reference: Jungers et al. 2005 Journal of Human Evolution

Common.Name: Giant Ruffed Lemur
Mass.Notes: The estimate is the mean of four different regression estimates based upon humerus (n = 4) midshaft cortical area and four different regression estimates based upon femur (n = 4) midshaft cortical area. The reported body mass estimates are rounded versions of those provided in Fleagle and Gilbert 2008.
Mass.Reference: Werdelin and Sanders 2010 Cenozoic Mammals of Africa; Fleagle and Gilbert 2008 Elwyn Simons a Search for Origins

Common.Name: Crested Moa
Diet.Notes: Unfortunately no coprolite evidence has been found to indicate the diet of this species (Wood et al. 2020). Their limited distribution and particular habitat affinities make inference from other moa coprolites difficult. No empirical evidence could be located however, so inferring diet from P. elephantopus.
Diet.Reference: Wood et al. 2020 New Zealand Journal of Ecology
Fermentation.Type.Method: Inferred from Infraclass; Inferred from diet
Fermentation.Type.Notes: No empirical evidence nor expert opinions regarding the fermentation type of these birds. Their nearest, albeit distant, relatives are the tinamous of South America (Mitchell et al. 2014, Phillips et al. 2010), who are generalist herbivores with enlarged cecas (Garitano-Zavala et al. 2003). However, given their massive size, and the evolution of colon-based fermentation among other large-bodied ratites (rheas and ostriches), we are going to infer hindgut colon digestion as to the best of our knowledge there are no hindgut ceca fermentating animals of these sizes, and given that other truly herbivorous ratites have colons. However, emus and cassuaries have only simple guts. Also, it should be noted that all ratites lack crops (Sales 2006).
Fermentation.Type.Reference: Sales 2006 Avian and Poultry Biology Reviews; Mitchell et al. 2014 Science; Phillips et al. 2010 Systematic Biology; Garitano-Zavala et al. 2003 Ornitologia Neotropical
Limb.Morphology.Notes: Other than the miharung, which was unguligrade, and loons and grebes, which are plantigrade, all other birds are digitigrade
Habitat.Notes: Most moa species, with the exception of the rarely-preserved North Island species, have had their habitat well-described and ranged low rainforest to high elevation tundra. No description of use of aquatic resources or specialized aquatic adaptions.
Habitat.Reference: Worthy 1990 New Zealand Journal of Zoology

Common.Name: Heavy-Footed Moa
Diet.Notes: A large coprolite deposit including numerous species showed that between-habitat differences were more stark than between-species differences. Diet overall, for all species, was dominated by herbs and subshrubs. P. elephantopus consumed more monocots than any other species (potentially as much as 10%), either because of interspecific differences or habitat where coprolites were found (result is seconded by Wood et al. 2020)
Diet.Reference: Wood et al. 2008 Quaternary Science Reviews; Wood et al. 2020 New Zealand Journal of Ecology
Fermentation.Type.Method: Inferred from Infraclass; Inferred from diet
Fermentation.Type.Notes: No empirical evidence nor expert opinions regarding the fermentation type of these birds. Their nearest, albeit distant, relatives are the tinamous of South America (Mitchell et al. 2014, Phillips et al. 2010), who are generalist herbivores with enlarged cecas (Garitano-Zavala et al. 2003). However, given their massive size, and the evolution of colon-based fermentation among other large-bodied ratites (rheas and ostriches), we are going to infer hindgut colon digestion as to the best of our knowledge there are no hindgut ceca fermentating animals of these sizes, and given that other truly herbivorous ratites have colons. Mass.Notes: Presumably mandible length, though the measurment is not specified. Comparison species is Hemiauchenia paradoxa
Diet.Notes: While previous studies indicated a browsing diet, recent isotopic data (Pansani et al. 2019) found a generalist diet with mixed C3/C4 vegetation. Increasing graminoid consumption by 2. Dantas et al. 2020 also found similar results, with C4 grass comprising 45%, followed by fruits (32%), and leaves (23%)
Diet.Reference: Marcolino et al. 2012 Quaternary International; Pansani et al. 2019 Quaternary Science Reviews; Dantas et al. 2020 Quaternary Science Reviews
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Unlike ruminants, who have 4 chambers in their foregut, camelids have 3 and are considered non-ruminant ruminoids (Jassim and Hogan 2012). Their digestive system is slightly less efficient and has faster throughput than a similar-sized ruminant. They differ from other foregut non-ruminants however in actually ruminating.
Habitat.Method: Observed low sample size (1-5) habitat use; Inferred from vegetation association
Habitat.Notes: Coprolite diet data indicates an open habitat where they fed on shrubs, potentially at forest edges.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; Marcolino et al. 2012 Quaternary International

Common.Name: Stout-legged llama
Mass.Reference: Smith et al. 2003 Ecology; Stuart 1991 Biological Reviews
Diet.Notes: Stout-legged llamas have very low isotope values, indicating a C3 diet of browse.
Diet.Reference: Semprebon and Rivals 2010 Palaeogeography, Palaeoclimatology, Palaeoecology; Kohn et al. 2005 Geology
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Unlike ruminants, who have 4 chambers in their foregut, camelids have 3 and are considered non-ruminant ruminoids (Jassim and Hogan 2012). Their digestive system is slightly less efficient and has faster throughput than a similar-sized ruminant. They differ from other foregut non-ruminants however in actually ruminating.
Habitat.Method: Observed low sample size (1-5) habitat use; Inferred from absence of evidence
Habitat.Notes: No evidence of aquatic habitat use in this species or extant relatives
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Mass.Notes: Presumably mandible length, though the measurment is not specified. Comparison species is Hemiauchenia paradoxa
Diet.Notes: Franca et al. 2015 reports isotopes by genus, not species, concluding that this genus were mixed feeders that preferred browse.
Diet.Reference: Franca et al. 2015 Earth Science Reviews
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Unlike ruminants, who have 4 chambers in their foregut, camelids have 3 and are considered non-ruminant ruminoids (Jassim and Hogan 2012). Their digestive system is slightly less efficient and has faster throughput than a similar-sized ruminant. They differ from other foregut non-ruminants however in actually ruminating.
Habitat.Method: Observed low sample size (1-5) habitat use; Inferred from absence of evidence
Habitat.Notes: No evidence of aquatic habitat use in this species or extant relatives
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Common.Name: Large Sloth Lemur
Mass.Notes: The estimate is the mean of four different regression estimates based upon humerus (n = 4) midshaft cortical area and four different regression estimates based upon femur (n = 3) midshaft cortical area. The reported body mass estimates are rounded versions of those provided in Fleagle and Gilbert 2008.
Mass.Reference: Werdelin and Sanders 2010 Cenozoic Mammals of Africa; Fleagle and Gilbert 2008 Elwyn Simons a Search for Origins
Diet.Method: Functional craniodental morphology; Proxy dental wear (microwear)
Diet.Notes: Dental wear indicates that this family were seed predators, consuming a mixed diet of foliage and fruit
Diet.Reference: Godfrey et al. 2004 Journal of Human Evolution; Crowley and Godfrey 2012 Leaping Ahead
Fermentation.Type.Method: Inferred from body mass; Inferred from sister Family
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Hindgut, but type unknown. Sister family to Indriidae, who have hindgut-caecum digestive systems. However, other than the capybara (45kg) there are few extant species, with caecum digestive systems and body masses much above 10kg (Hume 2002). Unlike the other extinct lemur families, family level inference based on body mass is suspect for Palaeopropithecidae as their body masses are highly variable (from 11kg to 160kg). Going to infer hindgut colon for Archaeoindris and hindgut caecum for the smaller bodied species.
Fermentation.Type.Reference: Campbell et al. 2000 American Journal of Primatology; Clauss et al. 2003 Oecologia
Habitat.Notes: Functional morphology predicts a mostly arboreal habit
Habitat.Reference: Jungers et al. 1997 PNAS; Shapiro et al. 2005 American Journal of Physical Anthropology

Common.Name: Marsupial Tapir
Mass.Notes: Primary source inaccessible
Diet.Method: Expert Opinion; Functional craniodental morphology; Functional appendicular morphology; Observed low sample size (1-5) fossil evidence (dental microwear)
Diet.Notes: Microwear analysis of a single tooth indicated a browsing diet (DeSantis et al. 2017), supporting the classification by Johnson and Prideaux 2004 and Dawson 2006. Flannery and Archer 1985 suggested that Palorchestes had a unique 'bark-feeding' niche based on functional morphology. Richards et al. 2019's appendicular morphological assessment also suggests a browsing diet as they appear adapted for pulling down tree branches and potentially foraging bipedally. Likewise, their narrow face, bilophodont molars, and scooped incisors suggest selective browsing.
Diet.Reference: Johnson and Prideaux 2004 Austral Ecology; Dawson 2006 Alcheringa; DeSantis et al. 2017 Paleobiology; Richards et al. 2019 PLoS One
Fermentation.Type.Method: Inferred from Order; Inferred from sister Families; Proxy isotopes (N15)
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Dawson 2006 reports hindgut authoratively, but her methods are unclear. Her evidence is likely that Vombatidae and Phascolarctidae, sister families, are both hindgut fermenters. Grocke and Bocherens 1996 interpreted Nitrogen isotope data from a diprodontid as evidence of hindgut fermentation as well, though the exact relation of P. azeal to diprotodons is unclear. Some (e.g. Phylacine) consider P. azeal to be a Diprotodontidae, while others list them as their own family.
Limb.Morphology.Notes: Forearems were also highly specialized and unique, likely used to pluck vegetation and pull down branches (Richards et al. 2019). They may have assumed a bipedal posture when doing so.
Habitat.Notes: No specific proxy evidence of aquatic habitat use in this species. Their likely distribution was forested environments along coastal Australia, although the paleobiology database has occurrences further inland, in what today is arid. Their morphology suggests that they were branch-pulling, facultatively bipedal, browserswhich is not particularly suitable for an aquatic lifestyle.
Habitat.Reference: The Australia Museum 2019; Richards et al. 2019 PLoS One; The Paleobiology Database 2020

Mass.Notes: Smith et al. 2003 cites De Iuliis 2000 as the source, but this latter source does not provide a mass estimate.
Mass.Reference: Smith et al. 2003 Ecology; De Iuliis et al. 2000 Journal of Vertebrate Paleontology
Diet.Notes: Craniomorphometrics suggests that this species was a grazer. No empirical proxy evidence found.
Diet.Reference: De Iuliis et al. 2000 Journal of Vertebrate Paleontology
Fermentation.Type.Method: Functional craniodental morphology; Inferred from diet; Proxy isotopes (C13, N15)
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Likely hindgut, but type unknown. The extant relatives, armadillos, are insectivores and have simple sac stomachs. Some have suggested the same for glyptodonts (Bocherens et al. 2017 Gondwana Research), but it seems impossible that they would sustain their metabolism as obigate herbivores without fermentation. Bocherens et al. (2017 Gondwana Research) found that their isotopic values (for Doedicurus spp, Glyptodon spp, Glyptotherium) suggested either aquatic habitat or a fast fermentation rate. Vizcaino et al. (2011 Ameghiniana) suggested that given the estimated low metabolic rate of Xenarthans but the relatively complex teeth of cingulates compared to sloths, that sloths have more efficient fermentation in digestive tract than glyptodonts. The best evidence indicates that sloths had foregut non-ruminant digestion.  Hindgut digestion is the most  ancestral type, far less derived than foregut fermentation. We will therefore infer that these animals were likely hindgut and also hingut colon, since there are few large mammals that use caecums
Fermentation.Type.Reference: Smith et al. 2010 Nature Geoscience; Bocherens et al. 2017 Gondwana Research; Vizcaino et al. 2011 Ameghiniana
Limb.Morphology.Notes: Plantigrady is one component of a suite of traits, including armor, low metabolism, ability to withstand hypoxia, and other slow life history habits
Limb.Morphology.Reference: Superina and Loughry 2011 Journal of Mammalian Evolution
Habitat.Notes: No published evidence of aquatic habitat use in this species. While some extinct glyptodonts have some weak and contradictory evidence suggesting a semi-aquatic habit, we will not make inferences to this taxa.

Common.Name: Bonobo
Diet.Notes: Omnivorous ripe fruit specialists - which comprises ~ 60% of diet. Leaves and pith are supplemental foods. Group hunting has never been observed among bonobos.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2013 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa
Fermentation.Type.Notes: All primate species except colobins have hindgut fermentation systems, with most (especially larger-bodied families) using the colon as the site of fermentation. Hindgut colon fermenting species sacrifice fermentation efficiency (e.g. completeness) for rate of passage. Cell-walls are only partially digested, but without the chokepoint provided by the rumen, they can continually consume vegetation thus meeting their nutrient demands. As such they are also able to consume lower-quality vegetation.
Fermentation.Type.Reference: Hume 2002 Acta Zoologica Sinica; Lambert 1998 Evolutionary Anthropology
Habitat.Notes: Bonobos spend ~44% of their waking hours in trees and build elaborate arboreal sleeping nests. They live in a variety of tropical closed canopy forests.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2013 Handbook of the Mammals of the World

Common.Name: Chimpanzee
Diet.Notes: Omnivorous ripe fruit specialists - which comprises ~ 60% of diet. Leaves and pith are supplemental foods. Also group hunt a variety of species.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2013 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa
Fermentation.Type.Notes: All primate species except colobins have hindgut fermentation systems, with most (especially larger-bodied families) using the colon as the site of fermentation. Hindgut colon fermenting species sacrifice fermentation efficiency (e.g. completeness) for rate of passage. Cell-walls are only partially digested, but without the chokepoint provided by the rumen, they can continually consume vegetation thus meeting their nutrient demands. As such they are also able to consume lower-quality vegetation.
Fermentation.Type.Reference: Hume 2002 Acta Zoologica Sinica; Lambert 1998 Evolutionary Anthropology
Habitat.Notes: This species has a broad habitat affinity, from woodland-savanna mosaics to lowland rainforest. They forage in trees and build nests in trees for sleeping.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2013 Handbook of the Mammals of the World

Mass.Notes: This value is the mean of 43 different regression estimates, using various anatomical measurements. The authors note that the regression they used were not based on South American taxa. Xenarthrans often have unusual body dimensions and the body mass estimates of these regressions were variable.
Mass.Reference: Smith et al. 2003 Ecology; Farina et al. 1998 Mastozoologia Neotropical
Diet.Notes: Morphology indicates bulk feeder in open environments (Vizcaino et al. 2011). Isotopic data (Dantas et al. 2020) indicates a fruit (29%) and leaf (22%) dominated diet, closely followed by C4 grasses (49%).
Diet.Reference: Vizcaino et al. 2011 Ameghiniana; Dantas et al. 2020 Quaternary Science Reviews
Fermentation.Type.Method: Functional craniodental morphology; Inferred from diet; Proxy isotopes (C13, N15)

Habitat.Notes: No published evidence of aquatic habitat use in this species. While some extinct glyptodonts have some weak and contradictory evidence suggesting a semi-aquatic habit, we will not make inferences to this taxa.

Common.Name: Chiru
Diet.Notes: Chiru are mixed feeders consuming 33-66% grasses and sedges, primarily in the winter. The rest of the diet are dwarf shrubs and herbaceous plants.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: Chirus use open, high-elevation alpine and desert steppes. Rarely enter mountainous terrain. Occupied habitats have sparse vegetative cover.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; Leslie and Schaller 2008 Mammalian Species

Common.Name: Olive Baboon
Mass.Reference: Kelt and Meyer 2008 Global Ecology and Biogeography
Diet.Notes: Grass is a common food item for olive baboons and they utilize young meristems, seeds, and rhizomes. Otherwise, have an extremely diverse diet of numerous plant species, fruit, and invertebrate and vertebrate prey. Hunts are opportunistic and rarely appear planned.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2013 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa
Fermentation.Type.Notes: All primate species except colobins have hindgut fermentation systems, with most (especially larger-bodied families) using the colon as the site of fermentation. Hindgut colon fermenting species sacrifice fermentation efficiency (e.g. completeness) for rate of passage. Cell-walls are only partially digested, but without the chokepoint provided by the rumen, they can continually consume vegetation thus meeting their nutrient demands. As such they are also able to consume lower-quality vegetation.
Fermentation.Type.Reference: Hume 2002 Acta Zoologica Sinica; Lambert 1998 Evolutionary Anthropology
Habitat.Notes: A habitat generalist dwelling from semi-desert to rainforest. Free-water dependent.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2013 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa

Common.Name: Yellow Baboon
Mass.Reference: Kelt and Meyer 2008 Global Ecology and Biogeography
Diet.Notes: A hyper diverse selective diet of most plant types, carrion, and small prey animals. Selective about components of plants consumed, but appear to eat everything.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2013 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa
Fermentation.Type.Notes: All primate species except colobins have hindgut fermentation systems, with most (especially larger-bodied families) using the colon as the site of fermentation. Hindgut colon fermenting species sacrifice fermentation efficiency (e.g. completeness) for rate of passage. Cell-walls are only partially digested, but without the chokepoint provided by the rumen, they can continually consume vegetation thus meeting their nutrient demands. As such they are also able to consume lower-quality vegetation.
Fermentation.Type.Reference: Hume 2002 Acta Zoologica Sinica; Lambert 1998 Evolutionary Anthropology
Habitat.Notes: This species occupies dry bushland, steppes, coastal littoral zone. Requires surface-water. Usually sleep in trees.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2013 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa

Common.Name: Hamadryas Baboon
Mass.Reference: Kelt and Meyer 2008 Global Ecology and Biogeography
Diet.Notes: Hamadryas baboons feed heavily on Acacia flowers, leaves, and seeds, Gewia berries, grasses and sedges, and introduced pricky pear fruits. Opportunistically eat insects and small mammals.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2013 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa
Fermentation.Type.Notes: All primate species except colobins have hindgut fermentation systems, with most (especially larger-bodied families) using the colon as the site of fermentation. Hindgut colon fermenting species sacrifice fermentation efficiency (e.g. completeness) for rate of passage. Cell-walls are only partially digested, but without the chokepoint provided by the rumen, they can continually consume vegetation thus meeting their nutrient demands. As such they are also able to consume lower-quality vegetation.
Fermentation.Type.Reference: Hume 2002 Acta Zoologica Sinica; Lambert 1998 Evolutionary Anthropology
Habitat.Notes: This species lives in deserts but also montane forests. They sleep in rock crevices and cliffs. Like all Papio species, they require free-water.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2013 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa

Common.Name: Kinda Baboon
Mass.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2013 Handbook of the Mammals of the World
Diet.Notes: Formerly conspecific with the yellow baboon. Wilson and Mittermeier consider their diet to be similar. Consume nearly anything, including a substantial amount of grass.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2013 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa
Fermentation.Type.Notes: All primate species except colobins have hindgut fermentation systems, with most (especially larger-bodied families) using the colon as the site of fermentation. Hindgut colon fermenting species sacrifice fermentation efficiency (e.g. completeness) for rate of passage. Cell-walls are only partially digested, but without the chokepoint provided by the rumen, they can continually consume vegetation thus meeting their nutrient demands. As such they are also able to consume lower-quality vegetation.
Fermentation.Type.Reference: Hume 2002 Acta Zoologica Sinica; Lambert 1998 Evolutionary Anthropology
Habitat.Notes: This species dwells in light woodland and gallery forest. Less is known about this species, but presumably terrestrial like most of the other Papios.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2013 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa

Common.Name: Guinea Baboon
Mass.Reference: Kelt and Meyer 2008 Global Ecology and Biogeography
Diet.Notes: According to Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa, diet is primarily fruit, followed by a variety of herbaceous plant parts, flowers, buds, new leaves, roots, fungi, invertebrates. Wilson and Mittermeier mention the consumption of grass, but do not emphasize it, saying only that these species are omnivorous with fruit as their main food item.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2013 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa
Fermentation.Type.Notes: All primate species except colobins have hindgut fermentation systems, with most (especially larger-bodied families) using the colon as the site of fermentation. Hindgut colon fermenting species sacrifice fermentation efficiency (e.g. completeness) for rate of passage. Cell-walls are only partially digested, but without the chokepoint provided by the rumen, they can continually consume vegetation thus meeting their nutrient demands. As such they are also able to consume lower-quality vegetation.
Fermentation.Type.Reference: Hume 2002 Acta Zoologica Sinica; Lambert 1998 Evolutionary Anthropology
Habitat.Notes: A habitat generalist living in coastal mangrove forests, Guinean forest, and the Sahelian steppe. Free-water dependent.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2013 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa

Common.Name: Chacma Baboon
Mass.Reference: Kelt and Meyer 2008 Global Ecology and Biogeography
Diet.Notes: Codron et al. 2018 compile fecal analysis studies and find 29% of diet is grass. Diet includes a diversity of plant parts, like all Papio species.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2013 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Codron et al. 2018 Ecology and Evolution; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa
Fermentation.Type.Notes: All primate species except colobins have hindgut fermentation systems, with most (especially larger-bodied families) using the colon as the site of fermentation. Hindgut colon fermenting species sacrifice fermentation efficiency (e.g. completeness) for rate of passage. Cell-walls are only partially digested, but without the chokepoint provided by the rumen, they can continually consume vegetation thus meeting their nutrient demands. As such they are also able to consume lower-quality vegetation.
Fermentation.Type.Reference: Hume 2002 Acta Zoologica Sinica; Lambert 1998 Evolutionary Anthropology
Habitat.Notes: A habitat generalist, dwelling in woodlands, savannas, deserts, ocean cliffs, swamps, and montane regions. Free-water dependent. Elaborates on the wells dug by Oryx gazella to access water.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2013 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa

Mass.Method: Inferred from relative of suggested similar size
Mass.Notes: Source does not mention which comparison species has been used to estimate the size
Mass.Reference: Prevosti and Vizcaino 2006 Acta Palaeontologica Polonica
Diet.Notes: No empirical evidence.
Diet.Reference: Smith et al. 2018 Science; Smith et al. 2003 Ecology
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Method: Observed low sample size (1-5) habitat use; Inferred from absence of evidence
Habitat.Notes: No evidence of aquatic habitat use in this species or extant relatives
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; Tonni 2009 Quaternario do Rio Grande do Sul

Common.Name: Harlan's Ground Sloth
Mass.Notes: McDonald 2005 provides two mass estimates for Paramylodon harlani (914.81 kg and 1392.47 kg). PHYLACINE v1.2 uses the upper estimate only. Our mass estimates are derived from PHYLACINE so we follow this decision.
Mass.Reference: Davis 2017 Proceedings of the Royal Society B; McDonald 2005 Bulletin of the Florida Museum of Natural History
Diet.Method: Observed coprolites (Family); Observed low sample size (1-5) fossil data (isotopes C13)
Diet.Notes: Isotopic data from a single tooth in Texas positions Paramylodon in between Bison (grazer) and Palaeolama (browser), suggesting a mixed feeding diet. Coprolites, identified to family Mylodontidae, in Cerro Casa de Piedra, were dominated by grasses, followed by forbs and shrubs (Velazquez et al. 2015 Quaternary International)
Diet.Reference: Ruez 2005 Texas Journal of Science; Velazquez et al. 2015 Quaternary International
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Smith et al. 2010 Nature Geoscience lists sloths as hindgut fermenters, because of their body size. However, all extant sloth species are foregut fermenters (Clauss 2004 Mammal Review). Fermentation type is a conservative trait, and extant two-toed and three-toed sloth species are more closely related to various of the now-extinct ground sloths than they are to each other (Pujos et al. 2012 Journal of Mammalian Evolution; Presslee et al. 2019 Nature Ecology and Evolution). Foregut fermentation is either the ancestral fermentation type of all sloth species, or it evolved at least twice in distinct (extant) sloth lineages. The most parsimonious fermentation type for extinct sloths would thus be foregut fermentation. However, Megatheriids pose a biological anamoly as there are no foregut fermentation species known at those body sizes (largest known was Sivatherium, a giraffid at 1250 kg). Vizcaino et al. 2006 and Clauss et al. 2003 suggests therefore that the extremely large Megatheriid sloths (Genera Megatherium and Eremotherium) may have been hindgut fermenters. As is, without better evidence, we will consider all sloths outliers in the ilk of Sivatherium and classify them as foregut fermenters until better evidence is available.
Fermentation.Type.Reference: McDonald and Pelikan 2006 Quaternary International; Clauss 2004 Mammal Review; Pujos et al. 2012 Journal of Mammalian Evolution; Presslee et al. 2019 Nature Ecology and Evolution; Vizcaino et al. 2006 Ameghiniana; Clauss et al. 2003 Oecologia
Limb.Morphology.Notes: Quantitative geometric morphometrics suggest this family was especially adapted for digging (de Oliveira and Santos 2008)
Limb.Morphology.Reference: Naish 2012 Tetrapod Zoology; de Oliveira and Santos 2018 Journal of Morphology
Habitat.Notes: Functional morphology suggests a terrestrial habit.
Habitat.Reference: Grass 2014 Thesis

Mass.Reference: Turvey and Fritz 2011 Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society B
Diet.Notes: No empirical proxy evidence found. Morphology suggests browser.
Diet.Reference: Pujos et al. 2012 Journal of Mammalian Evolution
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Smith et al. 2010 Nature Geoscience lists sloths as hindgut fermenters, because of their body size. However, all extant sloth species are foregut fermenters (Clauss 2004 Mammal Review). Fermentation type is a conservative trait, and extant two-toed and three-toed sloth species are more closely related to various of the now-extinct ground sloths than they are to each other (Pujos et al. 2012 Journal of Mammalian Evolution; Presslee et al. 2019 Nature Ecology and Evolution). Foregut fermentation is either the ancestral fermentation type of all sloth species, or it evolved at least twice in distinct (extant) sloth lineages. The most parsimonious fermentation type for extinct sloths would thus be foregut fermentation. However, Megatheriids pose a biological anamoly as there are no foregut fermentation species known at those body sizes (largest known was Sivatherium, a giraffid at 1250 kg). Vizcaino et al. 2006 and Clauss et al. 2003 suggests therefore that the extremely large Megatheriid sloths (Genera Megatherium and Eremotherium) may have been hindgut fermenters. As is, without better evidence, we will consider all sloths outliers in the ilk of Sivatherium and classify them as foregut fermenters until better evidence is available.
Fermentation.Type.Reference: McDonald and Pelikan 2006 Quaternary International; Clauss 2004 Mammal Review; Pujos et al. 2012 Journal of Mammalian Evolution; Presslee et al. 2019 Nature Ecology and Evolution; Vizcaino et al. 2006 Ameghiniana; Clauss et al. 2003 Oecologia
Limb.Morphology.Notes: Most taxa had the capacity, given their wide structural vertebral, to forage upright, resting on their tail. Appendicular morphology, particularly of the humerus, of all sloth families, other than the Mylodontidae, suggest a generalized locomotion habit (de Oliveira and Santos 2008).
Limb.Morphology.Reference: Naish 2012 Tetrapod Zoology; de Oliveira and Santos 2018 Journal of Morphology
Habitat.Notes: Functional morphology suggests a terrestrial habit.
Habitat.Reference: Pujos et al. 2012 Journal of Mammalian Evolution

Mass.Reference: Turvey and Fritz 2011 Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society B
Diet.Notes: No empirical proxy evidence found. Morphology suggests browser.
Diet.Reference: Pujos et al. 2012 Journal of Mammalian Evolution
