Habitat.Notes: Functional morphology suggests a semi-arboreal habit.
Habitat.Reference: Grass 2014 Thesis

Common.Name: Collared Peccary
Diet.Notes: Diet is as diverse as their potential habitats (from tropical forest to desert). They consume roots, tubers, bulbs, cacti, and leaves. Thought to play an important role in seed dispersal. All peccaries are reported frequently having small amounts of insect and vertebrate matter in their stomachs and have been observed feeding on carrion and killing small mammals. Thus inferring a 1 for meat across peccaries.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Peccaries have sacciform foregut digestive systems like hippos and camels, except unlike camels they do not ruminate (e.g. regurgitate partially fermented food for secondary mechanical grinding).
Fermentation.Type.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Hume 2002 Acta Zoologica Sinica
Habitat.Notes: An extremely broad range of habitats: from tropical rainforest to hyper arid desert. Surprisingly tolerant of cold temperatures, despite being a tropically derived species. Has recently been observed in high elevation ponderosa pine forests in Arizona (EJL personal observation). No significant aquatic habitat usage.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Common.Name: Grey Rhebok
Diet.Notes: Feed exclusively on browse, of which they are selective feeders (Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa)
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: Grey rhebok prefer short grass pastures with rocky escape terrain between 20 and 30 degrees.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa

Common.Name: Long-horned African buffalo
Mass.Notes: Primary source inaccessible. The estimate in Smith et al. 2003 is the mean of the estimated male and female body mass in Milwski and Diamond 2000 Journal of Biogeography 27:957.978. However, we cannot access the source from which Milwsi and Dimand have taken the estimate.
Diet.Notes: Proxy isotopes indicate a diet of C4 grasses.
Diet.Reference: Garrett et al. 2015 Journal of Human Evolution
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Method: Observed low sample size (1-5) habitat use; Inferred from absence of evidence
Habitat.Notes: No evidence of aquatic habitat use in this species or extant relatives
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Common.Name: Rodrigues Solitaire
Mass.Notes: The estimate is the mean of male (27.8 kg) and female (17.4 kg) body size
Diet.Notes: No empirical evidence found. Similar convergent morphology as the dodo and considered sister species, so we are inferring a diet of frugivory as well.
Fermentation.Type.Method: Inferred from diet; Inferred from Family
Fermentation.Type.Notes: No evidence for fermentation structure. Columbiformes in general have a simple stomach without fermentation (Clench and Mathias 1995), absorbing only readily available nutrients. though these highly derived megafaunal columbiforms may have secondarily evolved fermentation chambers. This remains unknown and unlikely given the putative frugivorous diets. Leaving certainty at 0.
Limb.Morphology.Notes: Other than the miharung, which was unguligrade, and loons and grebes, which are plantigrade, all other birds are digitigrade
Habitat.Notes: These dodo-like 'megafaunal' pigeons were flightless and most likely terrestrial in habit, though their use of aquatic environments has not been addressed and can't be ruled out.
Habitat.Reference: Rijsdijk et al. 2009 Quaternary Science Reviews

Common.Name: Desert Warthog
Diet.Notes: Codron et al. 2018 compile fecal analysis studies and find 95% of diet is grass
Diet.Reference: Hempson et al. 2015 Science; IUCN Redlist 2018; Codron et al. 2018 Ecology and Evolution
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Hindgut colon fermenting species sacrifice fermentation efficiency (e.g. completeness) for rate of passage. Cell-walls are only partially digested, but without the chokepoint provided by the rumen, they can continually consume vegetation thus meeting their nutrient demands. As such they are also able to consume lower-quality vegetation.
Fermentation.Type.Reference: Hume 2002 Acta Zoologica Sinica; Meijaard and Groves 2002 Asian Wild Pig News
Habitat.Notes: A desert species preferring plains with predominantly sandy soils and avoiding hilly terrain. Usually within range of perennial water. Distribution is tightly linked to aardvark burrows, which warthogs need for shelter from predations and temperature fluctuations.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa

Common.Name: Common Warthog
Diet.Notes: Codron et al. 2018 compile fecal analysis studies and find 95% of diet is grass
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Hempson et al. 2015 Science; Treydte et al. 2006 Journal of Mammalogy; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Hindgut colon fermenting species sacrifice fermentation efficiency (e.g. completeness) for rate of passage. Cell-walls are only partially digested, but without the chokepoint provided by the rumen, they can continually consume vegetation thus meeting their nutrient demands. As such they are also able to consume lower-quality vegetation.
Fermentation.Type.Reference: Hume 2002 Acta Zoologica Sinica; Meijaard and Groves 2002 Asian Wild Pig News
Habitat.Notes: Common warthogs require perennial surface water and inhabit moist to dry savanna grasslands to open bushlands and woodlands. They sleep each night in burrows, which are often used by porcupines during the day. They were closely associated with aardvarks prior to the decline of aardvarks.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa

Common.Name: Cyprus Dwarf Hippopotamus
Mass.Notes: Primary source inaccessible
Mass.Reference: Turvey and Fritz 2011 Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society B
Diet.Method: Functional craniodental morphology; Inferred from Family
Diet.Notes: Lophodont teeth suggest browser. Only two references found, both by Sondaar, and using the same language. No empirical results given, instead functional morphology is stated without citation. However, given the island status of this species, and the presence of many browsing hippopotami, we will proceed using both inference and functional morphology. To be conservative, we will score graminoids as 1.
Diet.Reference: Sondaar and van der Geer 2000 Archaeozoology of the Near East IVA
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Hippos are the largest extant foregut digesting species, topped only by Sivatherium, the giant giraffids of the Miocene, which reached ~1,250 kg. Like camelids and kangaroos, they have foregut fermentation systems that are less complex than ruminants and thus have reduced fermentation efficiency but are better able to subsist on higher quantities of lower nutrient foods.
Habitat.Notes: A terrestrially adapted hippopotamus with pig-like feet and a lowering of eyes and nostrils. Cyprus today has limited freshwater, and this was probably somewhat true during the Pleistocene. Many remains have been found in caves, where they may have sheltered from sun. To be conservative, we will still mark this species as semi-aquatic until better information becomes available.
Habitat.Reference: Hadjisterkotis and Reese 2008 European Journal of Wildlife Research

Common.Name: Koala
Diet.Notes: Koalas are distinctive eucalyptus specialized folivores.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2015 Handbook of the Mammals of the World
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Hindgut caecum fermenters are generally smaller-bodied than hindgut colon fermenters. In colon fermenters the caecum is largely modified to become part of the colon, whereas in caecum fermenters, they remain separate structures. Caecums are generally modified into complex structures that retain solutes and fine particles for fermentation while larger particles are excreted through colon, reducing the extent of plant-wall breakdown.
Habitat.Notes: This eucalypt specialist is primarily arboreal except when dispersing to new trees. Also comes to ground during very hot summers for ground-based shade. On the edge of classifying as semi-arboreal, however, given its strict arboreal feeding habits, we are going to classify this species as exclusively arboreal.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2015 Handbook of the Mammals of the World

Common.Name: Giant Wombat
Mass.Notes: Primary source inaccessible
Diet.Method: Functional craniodental morphology; Proxy dental wear (mesowear); Proxy isotopes (C13, O18)
Diet.Notes: Phascolonus and Vombatus consumed the most C4 vegetation of any species in DeSantis et al. 2017's study site (Cuddie Springs). This could be Atriplex, but given the hypergrazing habits of their extant relatives, grazing is more likely.
Diet.Reference: DeSantis et al. 2017 Paleobiology; Johnson and Prideaux 2004 Austral Ecology; Dawson 2006 Alcheringa
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Given that extant wombats have hindgut colon fermentation systems giant extinct wombats likely did too, though no direct evidence is available.
Habitat.Notes: P. gigas appear to have primarily been denizens of deserts and semi-arid grasslands, with no indication of aquatic habitat usage.
Habitat.Reference: DeSantis et al. 2017 Paleobiology

Common.Name: Maxwell's Duiker
Diet.Notes: From over 350 stomach analyses, diet is almost entirely fruit, with some leaves (when fruits are scarce) and mushrooms.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: Inhabitants of mature and secondary forests, as well as gallery forests and coastal scrub and farmlands. Prefer dense undergrowth.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa

Common.Name: Bouvier's Red Colobus
Diet.Notes: Folivorous, but little studied. Likely consists of leaves supplemented with fruit
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2013 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Colobin monkeys appear to be the sole primate group that has developed foregut fermentation
Fermentation.Type.Reference: Hume 2002 Acta Zoologica Sinica; Lambert 1998 Evolutionary Anthropology; Nijboer and Clauss 2006 Thesis
Habitat.Method: Observed low sample size (1-5) habitat use
Habitat.Notes: Little is known about this species. Described as dwelling in swamp forests and being arboreal by Wilson and Mittermeier.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2013 Handbook of the Mammals of the World

Common.Name: Niger Delta Red Colobus
Diet.Notes: Folivorous, but little studied. Likely consists of leaves supplemented with fruit
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2013 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Colobin monkeys appear to be the sole primate group that has developed foregut fermentation
Fermentation.Type.Reference: Hume 2002 Acta Zoologica Sinica; Lambert 1998 Evolutionary Anthropology; Nijboer and Clauss 2006 Thesis
Habitat.Method: Observed low sample size (1-5) habitat use
Habitat.Notes: This species dwells in swamp forests and is arboreal, but little else is known.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2013 Handbook of the Mammals of the World

Common.Name: Oustalet's Red Colobus
Mass.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2013 Handbook of the Mammals of the World
Diet.Notes: Folivorous on numerous trees and shrubs.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2013 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Colobin monkeys appear to be the sole primate group that has developed foregut fermentation
Fermentation.Type.Reference: Hume 2002 Acta Zoologica Sinica; Lambert 1998 Evolutionary Anthropology; Nijboer and Clauss 2006 Thesis
Habitat.Notes: This species lives in lowland tropical rainforests, swamp forests, as well as savanna woodland. An arboreal species.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2013 Handbook of the Mammals of the World

Common.Name: Pennant's Red Colobus
Diet.Notes: Tree leaves are the primary food. In some areas petioles of mature leaves are dominant plant type, in others, young leaves.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2013 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Colobin monkeys appear to be the sole primate group that has developed foregut fermentation
Fermentation.Type.Reference: Hume 2002 Acta Zoologica Sinica; Lambert 1998 Evolutionary Anthropology; Nijboer and Clauss 2006 Thesis
Habitat.Notes: This species dwells from lowland forests at sea level to montane forests at 1500 m and is arboreal.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2013 Handbook of the Mammals of the World

Common.Name: Flat-headed Peccary
Mass.Reference: Smith et al. 2003 Ecology; Stuart 1991 Biological Reviews
Diet.Method: Functional craniodental morphology; Proxy dental wear (microwear); Proxy isotopes (C13)
Diet.Notes: Isotopic values indicate some C4 consumption, but mostly a browser during the Late Pleistocene. All peccaries are reported frequently having small amounts of insect and vertebrate matter in their stomachs and have been observed feeding on carrion and killing small mammals. Thus inferring a 1 for meat across peccaries.
Diet.Reference: Koch and Barnosky 2006 Annual Review of Ecology, Evolution, and Systematics; Schmidt 2008 Proceedings Indiana Academy of Science; Bradham et al. 2018 Palaeogeography, Palaeoclimatology, Palaeocology
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Peccaries have sacciform foregut digestive systems like hippos and camels, except unlike camels they do not ruminate (e.g. regurgitate partially fermented food for secondary mechanical grinding).
Habitat.Method: Observed low sample size (1-5) habitat use; Inferred from absence of evidence
Habitat.Notes: No evidence of aquatic habitat use in this species or extant relatives
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Common.Name: Sumatran Orangutan
Mass.Reference: Smith and Jungers 1997 Journal of Human Evolution
Diet.Notes: Sumatran orangutans are primarily frugivorous, preferring large ripe fruits. supplemented with young and mature leaves, seeds, shoots, bark, pith, flowers, eggs, soil, and invertebrates. Have been observed eating vertebrates, but very rarely.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2013 Handbook of the Mammals of the World
Fermentation.Type.Notes: All primate species except colobins have hindgut fermentation systems, with most (especially larger-bodied families) using the colon as the site of fermentation. Hindgut colon fermenting species sacrifice fermentation efficiency (e.g. completeness) for rate of passage. Cell-walls are only partially digested, but without the chokepoint provided by the rumen, they can continually consume vegetation thus meeting their nutrient demands. As such they are also able to consume lower-quality vegetation.
Fermentation.Type.Reference: Hume 2002 Acta Zoologica Sinica; Lambert 1998 Evolutionary Anthropology
Habitat.Notes: This species dwells in a variety of forested habitats on Sumatra. They are incredibly sensitive to even light levels of logging. They are primarily arboreal in habit.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2013 Handbook of the Mammals of the World

Common.Name: Bornean Orangutan
Mass.Reference: Smith and Jungers 1997 Journal of Human Evolution
Diet.Notes: Bornean orangutans are primarily frugivorous, supplemeted with leaves, shoots, inner bark, seeds, pith, flowerss, soil, herbs, invertebrates and (rarely) small vertebrates. During El Nino driven fluctuations in fruit production, orangutans will fall back on starvation foos of inner tree bark and hard seeds.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2013 Handbook of the Mammals of the World
Fermentation.Type.Notes: All primate species except colobins have hindgut fermentation systems, with most (especially larger-bodied families) using the colon as the site of fermentation. Hindgut colon fermenting species sacrifice fermentation efficiency (e.g. completeness) for rate of passage. Cell-walls are only partially digested, but without the chokepoint provided by the rumen, they can continually consume vegetation thus meeting their nutrient demands. As such they are also able to consume lower-quality vegetation.
Fermentation.Type.Reference: Hume 2002 Acta Zoologica Sinica; Lambert 1998 Evolutionary Anthropology
Habitat.Notes: Dwell in a variety of forest types, but only occassionally in montane forest. Bornean orangutans are principally arboreal, being the largest arboreal animal in the world.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2013 Handbook of the Mammals of the World

Common.Name: Bushpig
Diet.Notes: Codron et al. 2018 compile fecal analysis studies and find 2% of diet is grass. Root extensively for tubers and woody roots. Consume almost everything, but little grass, though they do consume Cyperaceae
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Codron et al. 2018 Ecology and Evolution; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Hindgut colon fermenting species sacrifice fermentation efficiency (e.g. completeness) for rate of passage. Cell-walls are only partially digested, but without the chokepoint provided by the rumen, they can continually consume vegetation thus meeting their nutrient demands. As such they are also able to consume lower-quality vegetation.
Fermentation.Type.Reference: Hume 2002 Acta Zoologica Sinica; Meijaard and Groves 2002 Asian Wild Pig News
Habitat.Notes: Bushpigs are terrestrial species occurring at higher elevations in dense vegetation with ample cover.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa

Common.Name: Red River Hog
Diet.Notes: Red river hogs root through soils for tubers and roots, and consume considerable amounts of fruit and seeds and herbaceous vegetation, including Cyperaceae.
Diet.Reference: Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Hindgut colon fermenting species sacrifice fermentation efficiency (e.g. completeness) for rate of passage. Cell-walls are only partially digested, but without the chokepoint provided by the rumen, they can continually consume vegetation thus meeting their nutrient demands. As such they are also able to consume lower-quality vegetation.
Fermentation.Type.Reference: Hume 2002 Acta Zoologica Sinica; Meijaard and Groves 2002 Asian Wild Pig News
Habitat.Method: Observed low sample size (1-5) habitat use; Inferred from absence of evidence
Habitat.Notes: Although associated with lowland forests and swmplands, their exact use of aquatic habitats is unknown (Pacini and Harper 2008). Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa do not mention use of wetland habitats. Wilson and Mittermeier describe them as using gallery forests, swamp margins, as well as dry forests, savanna woodlands, and cultivated areas.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; Pacini and Harper 2008 Tropical stream ecology; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa

Mass.Notes: The authors list various methods but do not say how the mass of this particular species was estimated. They either used linear (isometric) dimensions based on extant relatives, used regression equations or assumed body mass to increase as the cube of linear dimensions
Mass.Reference: Turvey and Fritz 2011 Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society B; Burness et al. 2001 Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America
Diet.Method: Functional craniodental morphology; Proxy dental wear (microwear and mesowear)
Diet.Notes: The square muzzle and hypsodonty, as well as micro and meso wear suggest a mixed feeder, potentially preferring graminoids. Conference proceedings abstract only, so little quantitative evidence accessible.
Diet.Reference: Palombo 2005 Proceedings of the International Symposium of Insular Vertebrate Evolution
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: Ichnofossils of tracks on beach  in wet sand, suggest use of littoral habitats, but most remains are from caves and upland sites
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; Fanelli et al. 2007 Bollettino della Societa Paleontologica Italiana

Common.Name: Mongolian Gazelle
Diet.Notes: Fecal analysis indicated a mixed feeding, but with a strong tendency towards browse.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Sugimoto et al. 2018 Journal of Mammalogy
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: Mongolian gazelles prefer arid steppes and grassy plains. A nomadic species in their arid and unpredictable geographic range, following food availability.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Common.Name: Tibetan Gazelle
Diet.Notes: Selective feeder of browse and forbs, with grasses only constituting at most 16% of diet, but usually less.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: Fairly sedentary inhabitant of open landscapes of high elevation alpine meadows and alpine steppe, as well as low elevation grasslands
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; Leslie 2010 Mammalian Species

Common.Name: Przewalski's Gazelle
Diet.Notes: Closely related to the Tibetan gazelle but a selective grazer with shrubs and forbs accounting for 12-34% of diet during growing season. Otherwise prefers grasses and sedges.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: Inhabitants of low-elevation valleys, grasslands steppes, stabilized sand dunes, desert-shrub ecotones.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; Leslie et al. 2010 Mammalian Species

Common.Name: Giant Short-faced Kangaroo
Mass.Notes: Primary source inaccessible
Diet.Notes: Classified as a Browser/Mixed Feeder by Johnson and Prideux 2004 and Dawson 2006. No empirical, proxy information found.
Diet.Reference: Johnson and Prideaux 2004 Austral Ecology; Dawson 2006 Alcheringa
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Extinct kangaroo fermentation systems are unknown, but presumed to be similar to extant kangaroos. Extant kangaroos posssess foregut fermentation systems, but instead of them being divided into sacs, they are linear and have higher throughputs - comparable in function to hindgut colon fermentation in fact. Thus this system maximizes material flow and rate of fermentation at the expense of cell wall digestion. The implications of this is that food intake rates are less limited in macropods than in ruminants when foraging high fiber foods: as forage quality decreases ruminants reduce consumption rate (because they require longer fermentation times on high fiber foods), whereas macropod intake rate remains more or less constant.
Limb.Morphology.Notes: Monodactyl hoof-like unguligrade, convergent on 'open-plains horses', suggesting a cursorial form of locomotion. Functional morphology of the forelimbs (Janis et al. 2020) suggests that this group did not bear weight on their forearms and were likely strictly bipedal, even at slow speeds, unlike modern, extant kangaroos which become quadrupedal or pentapedal.
Limb.Morphology.Reference: Prideaux et al. 2009 PNAS; Janis et al. 2020 Journal of Mammalian Evolution
Habitat.Notes: Fossil evidence indicates a mesic forested habitat. No indication of aquatic usage.
Habitat.Reference: Faith et al. 2011 Quaternary Research

Common.Name: Giant Short-faced Kangaroo
Mass.Notes: Primary source inaccessible
Diet.Method: Proxy dental wear (microwear); Proxy isotopes (C13, O18)
Diet.Notes: This species has a C4 isotopic signature, which could be driven by Atriplex or C4 grasses. Prideaux et al. 2009 use microwear and craniodental morphology and find strong evidence that this species was a chenopod (Atriplex) browse specialist.
Diet.Reference: Prideaux et al. 2009 PNAS

Habitat.Notes: Functional morphology suggests adaptations to open, flat terrain. No indication of aquatic habitat usage.

Common.Name: Giant forest wallaby
Mass.Notes: Primary source inaccessible
Diet.Method: Expert Opinion; Functional craniodental morphology; Proxy dental wear (mesowear); Proxy dental wear (microwear) (Genus); Proxy isotopes (C13, O18) (Genus)
Diet.Notes: Genus-level isotopic evidence (C13, O18) suggests a higher influence of C4 in their diet than in other 'browsers', but the C4 could be derived from Atriplex (DeSantis et al. 2017 Paleobiology). Butler et al. 2014 found P. anak to be a mixed feeder from mesowear analysis - which by their definition means that browse or graze was not >90% of diet. Note that Butler et al. used samples (n=10-15) from the Plio-Pleistocene. Elsewhere classified as a browser (Johnson and Prideaux 2004). Given this contradiction, we are reducing certainty to 1 and treating as a mixed feeder that prefers browse.
Diet.Reference: Johnson and Prideaux 2004 Austral Ecology; DeSantis et al. 2017 Paleobiology; Butler et al. 2014 Palaeogeography, Palaeoclimatology, Palaeoecology
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Extinct kangaroo fermentation systems are unknown, but presumed to be similar to extant kangaroos. Extant kangaroos posssess foregut fermentation systems, but instead of them being divided into sacs, they are linear and have higher throughputs - comparable in function to hindgut colon fermentation in fact. Thus this system maximizes material flow and rate of fermentation at the expense of cell wall digestion. The implications of this is that food intake rates are less limited in macropods than in ruminants when foraging high fiber foods: as forage quality decreases ruminants reduce consumption rate (because they require longer fermentation times on high fiber foods), whereas macropod intake rate remains more or less constant.
Limb.Morphology.Notes: Like Macropus kangaroos, Protemnodon could be considered plantigrade or digitigrade. Functional morphology of the forelimbs (Janis et al. 2020) suggests that this genus may have been more quadrupedal than extant large kangaroos.
Limb.Morphology.Reference: Carey et al. 2011 Quaternary Science Reviews; Kram and Dawson 1998 Comparative Biochemistry and Physiology Part B; Janis et al. 2020 Journal of Mammalian Evolution
Habitat.Notes: Inhabitants of mesic woodlands, no indication of aquatic habitat usage
Habitat.Reference: DeSantis et al. 2017 Paleobiology; Butler et al. 2014 Palaeogeography, Palaeoclimatology, Palaeoecology

Mass.Notes: Primary source inaccessible

Hope and Flannery, speculating based on tooth morphology and habitat conditions (estimated from pollen) suggested that this was a browser-grazer. We will classify this species as a mixed feeder but reduce our confidence to 0 given this contradiction.

Common.Name: Protopithecus
Mass.Reference: Turvey and Fritz 2011 Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society B; Hartwig and Cartelle 1996 Nature
Diet.Notes: Given the conservativsm of the diets in this family, Protopithicus was almost certainly a folivorous/frugivorous primate.
Diet.Reference: Halenar 2012 Dissertation
Fermentation.Type.Notes: All primates except colobin monkeys have hindgut fermentation systems. Larger bodied primates use the colon for fermentation, except for Atelidae, which conduct caecum based hindgut fermentation. Hindgut caecum fermenters are generally smaller-bodied than hindgut colon fermenters. In colon fermenters the caecum is largely modified to become part of the colon, whereas in caecum fermenters, they remain separate structures. Caecums are generally modified into complex structures that retain solutes and fine particles for fermentation while larger particles are excreted through colon, reducing the extent of plant-wall breakdown.
Habitat.Notes: Morphology suggests a semi-arboreal habit.
Habitat.Reference: Halenar 2011 The Anatomical Record

Common.Name: Blue Sheep
Diet.Notes: Aryal et al. 2015 found that ~50% of diet consisted of graminoid and sedges, with the rest composed of shrubs and forbs
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Aryal et al. 2015 Ecology and Evolution
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: A high elevation species  of alpine sedge meadows, and open areas on or near talus or rough vertiginous terrain. They also occur in lower elevation, arid, and hilly terrain. In parts of range, occur in montane grasslands, woodlands, and subalpine shrublands.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Common.Name: Saola
Mass.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World
Diet.Notes: One of the world's rarest mammals. Diet is poorly understood. Local people describe Saolas as browsers of herbaceous vegetation and understorey shrubs and trees. To be conservative, assigning a 1 to graze, as hyper-browsers are unusual and rare.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: Saola are inhabitants of moist, evergreen forests. Little is known about this species.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Common.Name: Caribou; Reindeer
Diet.Notes: Caribou consume a variety of tundra vegetation, principally lichens, moss, ferns, grasses, leaves, and shoots/buds of trees (particularly Salix and Betula). Dig craters in snow to access lichens in mid winter.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: Flagship species of tundra, high Arctic desert, alpine meadows, and open taiga. Some populations once occurred further South, in boreal and mixed forests. Suffers if temperatures exceed 15C and if snow iss deeper than 60-80cm.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Common.Name: Steenbok
Diet.Notes: Codron et al. 2018 reviewed fecal analysis literature and estimated 34% of diet is grass
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Hempson et al. 2015 Science; Codron et al. 2018 Ecology and Evolution
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: Inhabitants of woodlands, preferring dense understory cover and broken terrain. Opening of riverine forests by elephant trampling led to the disappearance of one population.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa

Common.Name: Cape Grysbok
Diet.Method: Observed fecal analysis; Proxy dental wear (mesowear)
Diet.Notes: Currently considered a browser from modern evidence, but mesowear analysis from Late Pleistocene sample indicates significant graminoid consumption which transitioned to browsing in the early Holocene (Faith 2011). Diet is estimated to be composed of 30% grass (Codron et al. 2018)
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Faith 2011 Quaternary Research; Codron et al. 2018 Ecology and Evolution
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: Disturbance specialists across a range of habitats, requiring spaces with pioneer plants and thus a high forb to grass ratio.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa

Common.Name: Dodo
Mass.Notes: This estimate is based on a sample of 174 femora of Raphus cucullatus.
Diet.Method: Observed low sample size (1-5) foraging; Proxy isotopes (C13)
Diet.Notes: Described as frugivores in historic accounts (Hume 2006). Isotopes indicate a C3 diet as well (Rijsdijk et al. 2009)
Diet.Reference: Hume 2006 Historical Biology; Rijsdijk et al. 2009 Quaternary Science Reviews
Fermentation.Type.Method: Inferred from diet; Inferred from Family
Fermentation.Type.Notes: No evidence for fermentation structure. Columbiformes in general have a simple stomach without fermentation (Clench and Mathias 1995), absorbing only readily available nutrients. though these highly derived megafaunal columbiforms may have secondarily evolved fermentation chambers. This remains unknown and unlikely given the putative frugivorous diets. Leaving certainty at 0.
Limb.Morphology.Notes: Other than the miharung, which was unguligrade, and loons and grebes, which are plantigrade, all other birds are digitigrade
Habitat.Notes: These dodo-like 'megafaunal' pigeons were flightless and most likely terrestrial in habit, though their use of aquatic environments has not been addressed and can't be ruled out.
Habitat.Reference: Rijsdijk et al. 2009 Quaternary Science Reviews

Common.Name: Southern Reedbuck
Diet.Notes: Codron et al. 2018 estimate, by compiling fecal analyses, that 94% of diet is composed grass. Kingdon et al. (2013) indicate that southern reedbucks are primarily fresh grass consumers, but will consume forbs and will browse extensively as well.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa; Codron et al. 2018 Ecology and Evolution
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: Prefers tall, dense grass, especially in wet-soiled, marshy habitats
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa

Common.Name: Mountain Reedbuck
Diet.Notes: In some locales 99% of stomach contents are grasses, of which they are selective and vary in species choice through seasons. However, at the end of a drought, some reedbuck had up to 20% browse contents in one location (Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa), indicating adaptive dietary switching in response to drought.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: Denizens of mountainous habitats, where they prefer grassy ridges and steep mountain slopes with broken terrain of volcanic flows, outcrops, and cinder cones. Require surface-water.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa

Common.Name: Bohor Reedbuck
Diet.Method: Observed fecal analysis; Observed foraging; Proxy isotopes (C13)
Diet.Notes: R. redunca is primarily a fresh-grass grazer as confirmed from multiple streams of evidence (Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa). However, Djagoun et al. 2013 found that they consume up to 47% C3 browse in West Africa during the dry season and 19% during the wet season. Thus we increase the content of browse to 2.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa; Djagoun et al. 2013 South African Journal of Wildlife Research
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: This species is strongly associated with woodland and floodplain grasslands. Water-dependent.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; Pacini and Harper 2008 Tropical stream ecology

Common.Name: Greater Rhea
Mass.Notes: This estimate is based on an unknown number of individuals of unknown sex. We collected this value from Dunning 2008 CRC Handbook of Avian Body Masses. This book is a collection of published literature about bird masses and is not the primary source of these estimates.
Mass.Reference: Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; Dunning 2008 CRC Handbook of Avian Body Masses
Diet.Notes: In Buenos Aires province, rhea diet was 27% grasses, but mostly dicot herbaceous plants (63%) (Comparatore and Yagueddu 2007 Ornitologia Neotropical). Pereira et al. 2003 in the Parana River Delta (Argentina) found that grasses constituted 35% (spring) - 45% (winter) of diet, with leguminous seed pods (Prosopis nigra) supplying ~ 21-38% and other herbaceous dicots supplying the bulk of their diet (~60%). In this study system insects only comprised less than 5% of diet, despite their emphasis in the description in Birds of the World, where they do in fact report that animal protein only comprises <1%.
Diet.Reference: Comparatore and Yagueddu 2007 Ornitologia Neotropical; Pereira et al. 2003 Journal of Range Management; Birds of the World 2020 Cornell Lab of Ornithology
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Rhea have an enlarged hindgut colon and caecum which allows true fermentation of plant fiber. Their digestive morphology is functionally similar to a horse.  It should be noted that all ratites lack crops (Sales 2006)
Fermentation.Type.Reference: Birds of the World 2020 Cornell Lab of Ornithology; Sales 2006 Avian and Poultry Biology Reviews
Limb.Morphology.Notes: Other than the miharung, which was unguligrade, and loons and grebes, which are plantigrade, all other birds are digitigrade
Habitat.Notes: Rheas are inhabitants of savannas and tall-grass pampas. Birds of the World mentions a preference to breed in the proximity of rivers, lakes, and swamps, but give no indication of aquatic foraging.
Habitat.Reference: Birds of the World 2020 Cornell Lab of Ornithology

Common.Name: Lesser Rhea
Mass.Notes: This estimate is based on three male specimens. We collected this value from Dunning 2008 CRC Handbook of Avian Body Masses. This book is a collection of published literature about bird masses and is not the primary source of these estimates.
Mass.Reference: Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; Dunning 2008 CRC Handbook of Avian Body Masses
Diet.Notes: In high arid pampas of Argentina, lesser rhea were found to primarily consume foliage (94% of diet), selecting forbs and shrubs and avoiding grasses, despite that grasses were the most abundant plant type (Paoletti and Puig 2016). This was seconded in a robust cross season, multi-year study which found strong avoidance of grasses and dedication to C3 foliage (99% of diet were leaves). No insects, little fruit/seed, and no graminoid contents found, despite graminoids dominating plant community (Marinero et al. 2017).
Diet.Reference: Paoletti and Puig 2007 Emu Austral Ornithology; Marinero et al. 2017 Emu Austral Ornithology
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Rhea have an enlarged hindgut colon and caecum which allows true fermentation of plant fiber. Their digestive morphology is functionally similar to a horse.  It should be noted that all ratites lack crops (Sales 2006)
Fermentation.Type.Reference: Birds of the World 2020 Cornell Lab of Ornithology; Sales 2006 Avian and Poultry Biology Reviews
Limb.Morphology.Notes: Other than the miharung, which was unguligrade, and loons and grebes, which are plantigrade, all other birds are digitigrade
Habitat.Notes: Lesser rheas use steppe and grassland ecosystems, but also prefer to forage in bogs and apparently prefer to breed in the highly productive mallin swamps of Patagonia. Given that this would not be evidenced in the fossil record, we are going to classify this species as terrestrial.
Habitat.Reference: Birds of the World 2020 Cornell Lab of Ornithology

Common.Name: Javan Rhinoceros
Diet.Notes: Javan rhinos are true browsers, consuming very little grass. Their diet is primarily saplings and woody shrubs and occassionally fruits (Groves and Leslie 2011 Mammalian Species). In their recent review of extant rhino diets, Hullot et al. 2019, confirmed this dietary classification. However, the lack of grass in their diet may reflect the loss of floodplain habitats where they once overlapped with Greater One-horned rhinos and probably grazed (Wilson and Mittermeier 2011).
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Groves and Leslie 2011 Mammalian Species; Hullot et al. 2019 Mammal Research
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Hindgut colon fermenting species sacrifice fermentation efficiency (e.g. completeness) for rate of passage. Cell-walls are only partially digested, but without the chokepoint provided by the rumen, they can continually consume vegetation thus meeting their nutrient demands. As such they are also able to consume lower-quality vegetation.
Limb.Morphology.Notes: Technically unguligrade, but modified with thick fleshy pads to hold weight, therefore functionally more similar to digitigrade
Habitat.Method: Observed low sample size (1-5) habitat use
Habitat.Notes: Javan rhinos are rare and have restricted ranges relative to their historic habitat affinities, but frequently forage in swamps along water-courses. Like the Sumatran rhino, they spend considerable time wallowing and are excellent swimmers. Forage in lowland forests and will climb up to montane cloud forest as well. Their use of aquatic habitats is compared to the Sumatran rhino, thus scoring as semi-aquatic, although this is contestable.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Common.Name: Greater One-horned Rhino
Diet.Notes: Formerly considered a mixed feeder by most authories. A detailed dietary analysis and microwear dataset (Hullot et al. 2019) found that they should probably be classified as a variable grazer, as grass contributes 60-90% of their diet.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Hullot et al. 2019 Mammal Research
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Hindgut colon fermenting species sacrifice fermentation efficiency (e.g. completeness) for rate of passage. Cell-walls are only partially digested, but without the chokepoint provided by the rumen, they can continually consume vegetation thus meeting their nutrient demands. As such they are also able to consume lower-quality vegetation.
Limb.Morphology.Notes: Technically unguligrade, but modified with thick fleshy pads to hold weight, therefore functionally more similar to digitigrade
Habitat.Notes: This species prefers tallgrass grasslands, along river systems in lowlands of the Himalayas. They avoid forests except when inundated. They use oxbow lakes and ponds for wallowing and feeding on aquatic plants. Apparently, they rarely stray more than 2 km from water. This species only significantly wallows during monsoon season, apparently because high humidity makes thermoregulation difficult. Designating this species as terrestrial.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Common.Name: Grey Snub-nosed Monkey
Mass.Reference: Smith et al. 2008 A Guide to Mammals of China
Diet.Notes: Consume a diversity of trees and shrubs, focusing on leaves, flowers, fruits/seeds, and buds. Also consumes insects. Documented consuming a minor amount of grass.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2013 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Xiang et al. 2012 American Journal of Primatology
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Colobin monkeys appear to be the sole primate group that has developed foregut fermentation
Fermentation.Type.Reference: Hume 2002 Acta Zoologica Sinica; Lambert 1998 Evolutionary Anthropology; Nijboer and Clauss 2006 Thesis
Habitat.Notes: This species dwells in steep, mountainous areas of mixed deciduous and evergreen forests. During winters, when it is usually below freezing, this species moves downslope to rivers. They spend the majority of their time in trees, but will make long journeys over land.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2013 Handbook of the Mammals of the World

Common.Name: Golden Snub-nosed Monkey
Mass.Reference: Smith et al. 2008 A Guide to Mammals of China
Diet.Notes: Leaves are consumed during the summer. During the winter these monkeys switch to eating either lichen or buds and bark.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2013 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Hou et al. 2018 American Journal of Primatology; Liu et al. 2013 American Journal of Primatology
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Colobin monkeys appear to be the sole primate group that has developed foregut fermentation
Fermentation.Type.Reference: Hume 2002 Acta Zoologica Sinica; Lambert 1998 Evolutionary Anthropology; Nijboer and Clauss 2006 Thesis
Habitat.Notes: This species lives in montane conifer and deciduous forests as well as bamboo forests. This environment can be snowed in for 6 months of the year, during which time they move down in elevation. They spend a considerable amount of time on the ground, but not precisely quantified.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2013 Handbook of the Mammals of the World

Common.Name: Myanmar Snub-nosed Monkey
Mass.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2013 Handbook of the Mammals of the World
Diet.Notes: A recently discovered species, with little known on diet until now. In 2019, Yang et al., report that this species consumes primarily young and mature leaves, fruits and seeds, buds, flowers, twigs, and bark from over 170 species. Also consume herbs and lichen.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2013 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Yang et al. 2019 Primates
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Colobin monkeys appear to be the sole primate group that has developed foregut fermentation
Fermentation.Type.Reference: Hume 2002 Acta Zoologica Sinica; Lambert 1998 Evolutionary Anthropology; Nijboer and Clauss 2006 Thesis
Habitat.Notes: This animal lives in steep mountainous areas of temperate forest and temperate rainforest. Less studied than other Rhinopithecus species, but also appears to be semi-arboreal.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2013 Handbook of the Mammals of the World

Common.Name: Barasingha
Diet.Notes: Reported as a mixed feeder preferring graminoids, yet Tewari and Rawat (2013) report higher consumption of browse than graminoids, partly reflecting browse abundance in their study area.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Tewari and Rawat 2013 International Scholarly Research Notices
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: Barasingha are generalist in habitat, but prefer marshy, shallow wetlands and open forests with abundant grass and grassy glades. The northern subspecies inhabit flooded tall grasslands, while the Indian subspecies occupies dry grasslands near forest edge.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; Pacini and Harper 2008 Tropical stream ecology

Common.Name: Brow-antlered Deer
Diet.Notes: Diet is composed of more than 80% graminoids
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Tuboi and Hussain 2016 Mammalian Biology
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: This species occurs in a variety of habitats in its fragmented range. In India, they live in floating marshes. However, in SE Asia they live grassy lowland forests, while on Hainan island they live in dry grassland. Although we would score living in floating marshes as a 1 for aquatic, given that this is only one population, we will score as 0.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Common.Name: Schomburgk's Deer
Mass.Method: Inferred from relative of suggested similar size
Mass.Notes: Considered of a similar size as Rucervus duvaucelii
Mass.Reference: Smith et al. 2003 Ecology; Huffman 2020 Ultimate Ungulate
Diet.Notes: The only reference to the diet of this species is old (1937) and anecdotal.
Diet.Reference: Giles 1937 Journal of the Siam Society
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Method: Observed low sample size (1-5) habitat use; Inferred from absence of evidence
Habitat.Notes: Little evidence known but once existed in the central plains of Thailand. No mention of aquatic habitat usage.
Habitat.Reference: Meijaard and Groves 2004 Journal of Zoology

Common.Name: Kipunji
Diet.Notes: Omnivorous, consuming mature leaves (22%), unripe fruits (14%), ripe fruits (13%), young leaves (12%), bark (11%), stalks (9%), flowers (9%), pith (7%), insects (2%), as well as seed pods, underground rhizomes and tubers, epiphytes, herbs, climbers, moss, fungi, and lichens. Frugivory increases increases during the wet season, while folivory increases during the dry season.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2013 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa
Fermentation.Type.Notes: All primate species except colobins have hindgut fermentation systems, with most (especially larger-bodied families) using the colon as the site of fermentation. Hindgut colon fermenting species sacrifice fermentation efficiency (e.g. completeness) for rate of passage. Cell-walls are only partially digested, but without the chokepoint provided by the rumen, they can continually consume vegetation thus meeting their nutrient demands. As such they are also able to consume lower-quality vegetation.
Fermentation.Type.Reference: Hume 2002 Acta Zoologica Sinica; Lambert 1998 Evolutionary Anthropology
Habitat.Notes: Denizen of montane forests, spending most of their time above ground, only occassionally feeding off the ground. Debatable to classify this species as semi-arboreal or terrestrial given lack of numeric evidence
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2013 Handbook of the Mammals of the World

Common.Name: Pyrenean Chamois
Diet.Notes: Pyrenean chamois seasonally swich between graminoids and shrubs and forbs (Espunyes et al. 2019), with females tending to prefer forbs. A classic mixed feeder.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Espunyes et al. 2019 PLoS One
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: This species occurs at higher elevations, in alpine and subalpine zones, primarily in ecotones between forested habitats and meadowlands. Prefers steep, rocky terrain.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Common.Name: Northern Chamois
Diet.Notes: Seasonal dietary switches from woody shrubs and forbs to grasses. A classic mixed feeder.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Raye et al. 2011 Ecological Research
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: An alpine species that utilizes timberlines, and the alpine grassland ecotone. However, like most animals, their habitat use is variable and they also use forested habitats, shrublands, and hilly forests. Regardless, prefer to have rocky, vertiginous escape terrain in proximity.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Common.Name: Philippine Spotted Deer
Diet.Notes: Little empirical evidence, but diet is a mix of leaves, buds, forbs, young grass, and fruit.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Ahrestani et al. 2016 Grazing and Browsing by Large Herbivores in South and Southeast Asia
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: Species is now restricted only to remnant habitats, particularly steep slopes of dipterocarp forests.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Common.Name: Philippine Deer
Diet.Method: Expert Opinion; Observed low sample size (1-5) evidence
Diet.Notes: Phillippine deer forage on forest edges where increased light availability stimulates plant growth. Feed on grasses, leaves, fallen fruit, and berries.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Ahrestani et al. 2016 Grazing and Browsing by Large Herbivores in South and Southeast Asia
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: Historically occurred in primary and secondary aged forests up to 2900m in elevation.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Common.Name: Javan Deer
Diet.Method: Expert Opinion; Observed low sample size (1-5) evidence
Diet.Notes: Javan deer have a broad diet of grasses, herbs, leaves and bark. Little empirical evidence found.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Ahrestani et al. 2016 Grazing and Browsing by Large Herbivores in South and Southeast Asia
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: A highly adaptable species, preferring tropical grasslands, but also living in forests, shrubland, and marshes.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Common.Name: Sambar
Diet.Notes: Sambar deer are described as grazers, preferring green grass. Its diet is very flexible and it readily switches to browsing of leaves, buds, flowers, and fruit.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Ahrestani et al. 2016 Grazing and Browsing by Large Herbivores in South and Southeast Asia
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: A habitat generalist of arid, dry, and moist orests, as well as pine and oak forests and montane woodlands. Ranges from tropical to temperate latitudes. Apparently, they prefer moist, deciduous forests in hilly country.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Common.Name: Rusingoryx
Mass.Reference: Faith et al. 2012 Palaeogeography, Palaeoclimatology, Palaeoecology
Diet.Notes: Isotopes indicate a diet of 74-86% C4 plants, depending on which isotopic mixing model is used.
Diet.Reference: Garrett et al. 2015 Journal of Human Evolution; Faith et al. 2011 Quaternary Research
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: Rusingoryx fossils are associated with dry and open habitat species.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; Faith et al. 2011 Quaternary Research

Common.Name: Saiga
Diet.Notes: A diverse diet of grasses, forbs, and browse. Spring diet is about 50% graminoids, which declines through year, with forbs and saltbush among other shrubs becoming an increasingly important component of diet. Apparently because of their rapid throughput, soils are more fertile where large numbers of saiga exist.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Notes: This species is split into two by Wilson and Mittermeier, who describe the western saiga as inhabiting flat plains, avoiding rough terrain and sand dunes, while the Mongolian saiga avoids flat lands and prefers gentle sloping landscapes. We suspect that this is simply a function of landform availability in their narrow, relictual range. Both species live in arid steppe, grassland, saltbush deserts, but take shelter in riparian thickets to avoid inclement weather. Migrate to avoid deep snow fall.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Common.Name: Fugitive Deer
Mass.Notes: Primary source inaccessible
Diet.Notes: No empirical evidence found.
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Method: Observed low sample size (1-5) habitat use; Inferred from absence of evidence
Habitat.Notes: No evidence found. Inferred from absence of evidence to not significantly use aquatic habitats.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Mass.Notes: Bone measurement not specified. Comparison species is Scelidotherium leptocephalum
Diet.Notes: Coprolites, identified to family Mylodontidae, in Cerro Casa de Piedra, were dominated by grasses, followed by forbs and shrubs (Velazquez et al. 2015 Quaternary International). However, isotopic data for this species indicates a mixed C3 diet (Salles et al. 2016, Domingo et al. 2012).
Diet.Reference: Domingo et al. 2012 Quaternary Science Reviews; Velazquez et al. 2015 Quaternary International; Salles et al. 2016 Palaeogeography, Palaeoclimatology, Palaeoecology
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Smith et al. 2010 Nature Geoscience lists sloths as hindgut fermenters, because of their body size. However, all extant sloth species are foregut fermenters (Clauss 2004 Mammal Review). Fermentation type is a conservative trait, and extant two-toed and three-toed sloth species are more closely related to various of the now-extinct ground sloths than they are to each other (Pujos et al. 2012 Journal of Mammalian Evolution; Presslee et al. 2019 Nature Ecology and Evolution). Foregut fermentation is either the ancestral fermentation type of all sloth species, or it evolved at least twice in distinct (extant) sloth lineages. The most parsimonious fermentation type for extinct sloths would thus be foregut fermentation. However, Megatheriids pose a biological anamoly as there are no foregut fermentation species known at those body sizes (largest known was Sivatherium, a giraffid at 1250 kg). Vizcaino et al. 2006 and Clauss et al. 2003 suggests therefore that the extremely large Megatheriid sloths (Genera Megatherium and Eremotherium) may have been hindgut fermenters. As is, without better evidence, we will consider all sloths outliers in the ilk of Sivatherium and classify them as foregut fermenters until better evidence is available.
Fermentation.Type.Reference: McDonald and Pelikan 2006 Quaternary International; Clauss 2004 Mammal Review; Pujos et al. 2012 Journal of Mammalian Evolution; Presslee et al. 2019 Nature Ecology and Evolution; Vizcaino et al. 2006 Ameghiniana; Clauss et al. 2003 Oecologia
Limb.Morphology.Notes: Quantitative geometric morphometrics suggest this family was especially adapted for digging (de Oliveira and Santos 2008)
Limb.Morphology.Reference: Naish 2012 Tetrapod Zoology; de Oliveira and Santos 2018 Journal of Morphology
Habitat.Method: Inferred from habitat association (proxy isotopes C13, N15)
Habitat.Notes: Domingo et al. 2012 Quaternary Science Reviews interpret isotopic data to suggest that these were dwellers of wooded areas. No evidence of aquatic or arboreal habits.
Habitat.Reference: NA; Domingo et al. 2012 Quaternary Science Reviews

Mass.Notes: The mass estimate reported in Smith et al. 2003 cannot be found in any of the primary sources that Smith et al. 2003 lists. It is higher than any of the masses that are cited in the primary sources (Farina 1995: 600 kg; Farina et al. 1998: 1057 kg; Bargo et al 2000: 850 kg), so is not an average of the primary sources either. This suggests the estimate may be on the high side.
Diet.Method: Observed coprolites (Family); Proxy dental wear (mesowear); Proxy isotopes (C13)
Diet.Notes: Both mesowear and isotopes indicate a mixed feeding diet, like other Mylodonts. Coprolites, identified to family Mylodontidae, in Cerro Casa de Piedra, were dominated by grasses, followed by forbs and shrubs (Velazquez et al. 2015 Quaternary International)
Diet.Reference: Saarinen and Karme 2017 Palaeogeography, Palaeoclimatology, Palaeoecology; Velazquez et al. 2015 Quaternary International

However, all extant sloth species are foregut fermenters (Clauss 2004 Mammal Review). Foregut fermentation is either the ancestral fermentation type of all sloth species, or it evolved at least twice in distinct (extant) sloth lineages. The most parsimonious fermentation type for extinct sloths would thus be foregut fermentation. However, Megatheriids pose a biological anamoly as there are no foregut fermentation species known at those body sizes (largest known was Sivatherium, a giraffid at 1250 kg). Vizcaino et al. 2006 and Clauss et al. 2003 suggests therefore that the extremely large Megatheriid sloths (Genera Megatherium and Eremotherium) may have been hindgut fermenters. As is, without better evidence, we will consider all sloths outliers in the ilk of Sivatherium and classify them as foregut fermenters until better evidence is available.
Fermentation.Type.Reference: McDonald and Pelikan 2006 Quaternary International; Clauss 2004 Mammal Review; Pujos et al. 2012 Journal of Mammalian Evolution; Presslee et al. 2019 Nature Ecology and Evolution; Vizcaino et al. 2006 Ameghiniana; Clauss et al. 2003 Oecologia

Limb.Morphology.Reference: Naish 2012 Tetrapod Zoology; de Oliveira and Santos 2018 Journal of Morphology
Habitat.Notes: Functional morphology suggests a terrestrial habit.
