Common.Name: Kashmir Gray Langur
Mass.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2013 Handbook of the Mammals of the World
Diet.Notes: No empirical information available. Handbook of the Mammals of the World says that the diet is similar to that of S. hector
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Colobin monkeys appear to be the sole primate group that has developed foregut fermentation.
Fermentation.Type.Reference: Hume 2002 Acta Zoologica Sinica; Lambert 1998 Evolutionary Anthropology; Nijboer and Clauss 2006 Thesis
Habitat.Notes: This species dwells in temperate moist, semi-evergreen, subalpine forest, and alpine scrub. They are described as being mostly terrestrial.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2013 Handbook of the Mammals of the World

Common.Name: Southern Plains Gray Langur
Diet.Notes: No empirical proxy evidence found.
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Colobin monkeys appear to be the sole primate group that has developed foregut fermentation.
Fermentation.Type.Reference: Hume 2002 Acta Zoologica Sinica; Lambert 1998 Evolutionary Anthropology; Nijboer and Clauss 2006 Thesis
Habitat.Notes: This species is little known. Classified as terrestrial by Wilman et al. 2014.
Habitat.Reference: Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Common.Name: Northern Plains Gray Langur
Diet.Notes: Northern plains gray langurs are folivore/frugivores, with leaves composing majority of diet followed by fruits, buds, flowers, and bark. In Madhya Pradesh, a group spent 39% of its time consuming leaves (mostly mature), 24% on seeds and fruits, 9% on flowers, 11% on buds amd bark. Caterpillars along with other insects can be a substantial component of diet in monsoon month - up to 25%.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2013 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Vandercone et al. 2012 International Journal of Primatology; Rahman et al. 2015 Asia Primates Journal
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Colobin monkeys appear to be the sole primate group that has developed foregut fermentation.
Fermentation.Type.Reference: Hume 2002 Acta Zoologica Sinica; Lambert 1998 Evolutionary Anthropology; Nijboer and Clauss 2006 Thesis
Habitat.Notes: Denizen of dry and moist tropical deciduous forest. This species is primarily terrestrial.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2013 Handbook of the Mammals of the World

Common.Name: Tarai Gray Langur
Mass.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2013 Handbook of the Mammals of the World
Diet.Notes: These langurs are folivore/frugivores. Over a year-long study, were observed spending 64% of their time foraging on leaves, 15% consuming fruitss, 6% on flowers, and 10% on insects.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2013 Handbook of the Mammals of the World
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Colobin monkeys appear to be the sole primate group that has developed foregut fermentation.
Fermentation.Type.Reference: Hume 2002 Acta Zoologica Sinica; Lambert 1998 Evolutionary Anthropology; Nijboer and Clauss 2006 Thesis
Habitat.Notes: A variety of habitats including semi-evergreen forests, alpine forests, deciduous forest, and savanna forests. This species spends ~20% of its time in trees.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2013 Handbook of the Mammals of the World

Common.Name: Tufted Gray Langur
Mass.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2013 Handbook of the Mammals of the World
Diet.Notes: These langurs are folivores/frugivores, consuming up to 80-90% fruits during some seasons. On average, they consume 48% leaves/shoots, and 45% fruits and seeds (measured by time spent foraging).
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2013 Handbook of the Mammals of the World
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Colobin monkeys appear to be the sole primate group that has developed foregut fermentation.
Fermentation.Type.Reference: Hume 2002 Acta Zoologica Sinica; Lambert 1998 Evolutionary Anthropology; Nijboer and Clauss 2006 Thesis
Habitat.Notes: This species generally occurs in drier forests, including tropical deciduous forest. This species is primarily terrestrial.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2013 Handbook of the Mammals of the World

Common.Name: Nepal Sacred Langur
Mass.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2013 Handbook of the Mammals of the World
Diet.Notes: The Nepal sacred langur's diet consists of 45-60% leafs and 20% ripe and unripe fruits. Also consume a variety of various plant parts such as rhizomes and flowers, bark, cambium, seeds, twigs, mosses, lichens, and some grass (probably <10% of total diet). Also feed on some invertebrates, though the commonness of this is unclear.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2013 Handbook of the Mammals of the World
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Colobin monkeys appear to be the sole primate group that has developed foregut fermentation.
Fermentation.Type.Reference: Hume 2002 Acta Zoologica Sinica; Lambert 1998 Evolutionary Anthropology; Nijboer and Clauss 2006 Thesis
Habitat.Notes: This species ranges from subtropical forests to alpine cedar forests. Wilson and Mittermeier describe them as terrestrial, but also state that they prefer to spend time in tree canopy, but come to ground to forage in open areas and to move. Treating this as semi-arboreality.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2013 Handbook of the Mammals of the World

Common.Name: Short-faced Kangaroo
Mass.Notes: Primary source inaccessible
Diet.Notes: All members of this genus are described as browsers, no more specific information found.
Diet.Reference: Johnson and Prideaux 2004 Austral Ecology; Dawson 2006 Alcheringa
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Extinct kangaroo fermentation systems are unknown, but presumed to be similar to extant kangaroos. Extant kangaroos posssess foregut fermentation systems, but instead of them being divided into sacs, they are linear and have higher throughputs - comparable in function to hindgut colon fermentation in fact. Thus this system maximizes material flow and rate of fermentation at the expense of cell wall digestion. The implications of this is that food intake rates are less limited in macropods than in ruminants when foraging high fiber foods: as forage quality decreases ruminants reduce consumption rate (because they require longer fermentation times on high fiber foods), whereas macropod intake rate remains more or less constant.
Limb.Morphology.Notes: Monodactyl hoof-like unguligrade, convergent on 'open-plains horses', suggesting a cursorial form of locomotion. Functional morphology of the forelimbs (Janis et al. 2020) suggests that this group did not bear weight on their forearms and were likely strictly bipedal, even at slow speeds, unlike modern, extant kangaroos which become quadrupedal or pentapedal.
Limb.Morphology.Reference: Prideaux et al. 2009 PNAS; Janis et al. 2020 Journal of Mammalian Evolution
Habitat.Notes: Inhabitants of forests, no indication of aquatic habitat usage
Habitat.Reference: Johnson and Prideaux 2004 Austral Ecology; Dawson 2006 Alcheringa

Mass.Notes: Palmqvist 2003 estimates that Soergelia minor weighed 225 kg. They base this upon an earlier estimate in Palmqvist 1996 of 227.6 kg, using unspecified craniodental/postcranial measurements. That latter estimate is based upon 13 specimens, ten of which were adults.
Mass.Reference: Palmqvist et al. 2003 Paleobiology; Palmqvist et al. 1996 Paleobiology
Diet.Notes: Isotopes and hyposodonty indicate a mixed feeding diet of grasses and foliage, likely in open savanna environments.

Common.Name: Flores Stegodont
Mass.Reference: Van Den Bergh et al. 2008 Quaternary International
Diet.Method: Observed low sample size (1-5) fossil observation proxy isotopes C13, 018
Diet.Notes: The only information available is from a conference abstract with small sample size and with methods barely discussed. Isotopes indicate an almost exclusive C4 diet for most samples, but some outlier individuals have isotopes reflecting mixed feeding.
Diet.Reference: Puspaningrum et al. 2014 VIth International Conference on Mammoths and Their Relatives
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Hindgut colon fermenting species sacrifice fermentation efficiency (e.g. completeness) for rate of passage. Cell-walls are only partially digested, but without the chokepoint provided by the rumen, they can continually consume vegetation thus meeting their nutrient demands. As such they are also able to consume lower-quality vegetation.
Habitat.Notes: Extant relatives and diet suggest a terrestrial habit, with only opportunistic use of aquatic environments.

Mass.Method: Inferred from relative of suggested similar size
Mass.Reference: Raia et al. 2010 Global Ecology and Biogeography
Diet.Method: Proxy dental wear (microwear); Proxy isotopes (C13, O18)
Diet.Notes: Zhang et al. 2017 use microwear analysis and conclude that this species was 'primarily a browser'. Isotope analysis by Ma et al. 2019 indicates that Stegodon orientalis primarily consumed browse with very little C4 consumption, and probably exclusively inhabited forested environments.
Diet.Reference: Zhang et al. 2017 Quaternary International; Ma et al. 2019 Quaternary Science Reviews

Mass.Notes: Asensio et al. 2004 do not specify which of these methods was used for this species. They simply states '[For perissodactyla] body masses were calculated using dental measurements and Janis equations (1990). Only when there were no dental data available did we use post-cranial measurements and Scotts equations (1990) to estimate body mass'. Also that a different version of this manuscript exists, with Prado as first author.
Diet.Method: Functional craniodental morphology; Proxy dental wear (microwear and mesowear)
Diet.Notes: Mesowear analysis indicates that these were mixed-feeders (van Asperen and Kahlke 2015). Isotopes echo this, showing a slight preference for browse in British specimens (Rivals and Lister 2016)
Diet.Reference: van Asperen and Kahlke 2015 Quaternary Science Reviews; Rivals and Lister 2016 Quaternary Science Reviews
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Hindgut colon fermenting species sacrifice fermentation efficiency (e.g. completeness) for rate of passage. Cell-walls are only partially digested, but without the chokepoint provided by the rumen, they can continually consume vegetation thus meeting their nutrient demands. As such they are also able to consume lower-quality vegetation.
Limb.Morphology.Notes: Technically unguligrade, but modified with thick fleshy pads to hold weight, therefore functionally more similar to digitigrade
Habitat.Method: Observed low sample size (1-5) habitat use; Inferred from absence of evidence
Habitat.Notes: No evidence of aquatic habitat usage. Carbon isotopes occupancy of steppes and forested habitats.
Habitat.Reference: Pushkina et al. 2014 Quaternary International

Mass.Notes: Asensio et al. 2004 do not specify which of these methods was used for this species. Only when there were no dental data available did we use post-cranial measurements and Scotts equations (1990) to estimate body mass'. Also that a different version of this manuscript exists, with Prado as first author.
Diet.Method: Functional craniodental morphology; Observed dental bolus; Proxy dental wear (microwear and mesowear); Proxy isotopes (C13, N15)
Diet.Notes: Mesowear analysis indicates that these were mixed-feeders (van Asperen and Kahlke 2015). Isotopes echo this, showing a slight preference for browse in British specimens (Rivals and Lister 2016). Stefaniak 2020 compile the most extensive review to date, including new isotopic data. They conclude that this species was mixed feeding browser of forested habitats, consuming both herbaceous and woody vegetation. They appear to have been strongly associated with riparian habitats.
Diet.Reference: van Asperen and Kahlke 2015 Quaternary Science Reviews; Rivals and Lister 2016 Quaternary Science Reviews; Stefaniak et al. 2020 Quaternary International

As such they are also able to consume lower-quality vegetation.
Limb.Morphology.Notes: Technically unguligrade, but modified with thick fleshy pads to hold weight, therefore functionally more similar to digitigrade
Habitat.Method: Observed low sample size (1-5) habitat use; Inferred from absence of evidence; Inferred from habitat association (proxy isotopes C13, N15); Observed fossil evidence
Habitat.Notes: Carbon isotopes indicate occupancy of forested habitats. Stefaniak et al. 2020 find that this species used riparian, mixed, and open-habitats.
Habitat.Reference: Pushkina et al. 2014 Quaternary International; Stefaniak et al. 2020 Quaternary International

Common.Name: Strong-tailed Kangaroo
Mass.Notes: Primary source inaccessible
Diet.Method: Observed low sample size (1-5) fossil evidence (dental wear microwear and proxy isotopes) (Genus); Proxy isotopes (C13, Zn, Sr) (Genus)
Diet.Notes: No species-level empirical data found. DeSantis et al. 2017 used a single Genus-level sample for isotopic and microwear analysis, which suggested a browsing diet. Grocke 1997 analyzed C13 isotopes from several locations at the Genus level and concluded that in most locations Sthenurus were consuming C3 vegetation. In one location, C4 was more dominant, but could have been Atriplex. Note that Nedin 1991 Lethaia also analyzed ratios of Zinc and Strontium and concluded that this genus were leaf-eaters. It is unclear how reliable that method is.
Diet.Reference: DeSantis et al. 2017 Paleobiology; Nedin 1991 Lethaia; Grocke 1997 Australian Journal of Botany
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Extinct kangaroo fermentation systems are unknown, but presumed to be similar to extant kangaroos. Extant kangaroos posssess foregut fermentation systems, but instead of them being divided into sacs, they are linear and have higher throughputs - comparable in function to hindgut colon fermentation in fact. Thus this system maximizes material flow and rate of fermentation at the expense of cell wall digestion. The implications of this is that food intake rates are less limited in macropods than in ruminants when foraging high fiber foods: as forage quality decreases ruminants reduce consumption rate (because they require longer fermentation times on high fiber foods), whereas macropod intake rate remains more or less constant.
Limb.Morphology.Notes: Monodactyl hoof-like unguligrade, convergent on 'open-plains horses', suggesting a cursorial form of locomotion. Functional morphology of the forelimbs (Janis et al. 2020) suggests that this group did not bear weight on their forearms and were likely strictly bipedal, even at slow speeds, unlike modern, extant kangaroos which become quadrupedal or pentapedal.
Limb.Morphology.Reference: Prideaux et al. 2009 PNAS; Janis et al. 2020 Journal of Mammalian Evolution
Habitat.Notes: Inhabitants of dense, closed canopy woodlands, no indication of aquatic habitat usage
Habitat.Reference: DeSantis et al. 2017 Paleobiology

Diet.Reference: DeSantis et al. 2017 Paleobiology; Nedin 1991 Lethaia; Grocke 1997 Australian Journal of Botany
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Extinct kangaroo fermentation systems are unknown, but presumed to be similar to extant kangaroos. Extant kangaroos posssess foregut fermentation systems, but instead of them being divided into sacs, they are linear and have higher throughputs - comparable in function to hindgut colon fermentation in fact. Thus this system maximizes material flow and rate of fermentation at the expense of cell wall digestion. The implications of this is that food intake rates are less limited in macropods than in ruminants when foraging high fiber foods: as forage quality decreases ruminants reduce consumption rate (because they require longer fermentation times on high fiber foods), whereas macropod intake rate remains more or less constant.
Limb.Morphology.Notes: Monodactyl hoof-like unguligrade, convergent on 'open-plains horses', suggesting a cursorial form of locomotion. Functional morphology of the forelimbs (Janis et al. 2020) suggests that this group did not bear weight on their forearms and were likely strictly bipedal, even at slow speeds, unlike modern, extant kangaroos which become quadrupedal or pentapedal.
Limb.Morphology.Reference: Prideaux et al. 2009 PNAS; Janis et al. 2020 Journal of Mammalian Evolution
Habitat.Notes: Inhabitants of dense, closed canopy woodlands, no indication of aquatic habitat usage
Habitat.Reference: DeSantis et al. 2017 Paleobiology

Common.Name: Strong-tailed Kangaroo
Mass.Notes: Primary source inaccessible
Diet.Method: Observed low sample size (1-5) fossil evidence (dental wear microwear and proxy isotopes) (Genus); Proxy isotopes (C13, sZn, Sr) (Genus)
Diet.Notes: No species-level empirical data found. DeSantis et al. 2017 used a single Genus-level sample for isotopic and microwear analysis, which suggested a browsing diet. Grocke 1997 analyzed C13 isotopes from several locations at the Genus level and concluded that in most locations Sthenurus were consuming C3 vegetation. In one location, C4 was more dominant, but could have been Atriplex. Note that Nedin 1991 Lethaia also analyzed ratios of Zinc and Strontium and concluded that this genus were leaf-eaters. It is unclear how reliable that method is.
Diet.Reference: DeSantis et al. 2017 Paleobiology; Nedin 1991 Lethaia; Grocke 1997 Australian Journal of Botany
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Extinct kangaroo fermentation systems are unknown, but presumed to be similar to extant kangaroos. Thus this system maximizes material flow and rate of fermentation at the expense of cell wall digestion. The implications of this is that food intake rates are less limited in macropods than in ruminants when foraging high fiber foods: as forage quality decreases ruminants reduce consumption rate (because they require longer fermentation times on high fiber foods), whereas macropod intake rate remains more or less constant.
Limb.Morphology.Notes: Monodactyl hoof-like unguligrade, convergent on 'open-plains horses', suggesting a cursorial form of locomotion. Functional morphology of the forelimbs (Janis et al. 2020) suggests that this group did not bear weight on their forearms and were likely strictly bipedal, even at slow speeds, unlike modern, extant kangaroos which become quadrupedal or pentapedal.
Limb.Morphology.Reference: Prideaux et al. 2009 PNAS; Janis et al. 2020 Journal of Mammalian Evolution
Habitat.Notes: Inhabitants of dense, closed canopy woodlands, no indication of aquatic habitat usage
Habitat.Reference: DeSantis et al. 2017 Paleobiology

Mass.Notes: Primary source inaccessible
Diet.Notes: Koch & Barnosky (2006) report report C13 values of -11.6, suggesting a browsing diet. Bravo-Cuevas et al. 2013 suggests the species is a mixed feeder with a preference for browsing, like Capromeryx minor, but provide no evidence.
Diet.Reference: Koch and Barnosky 2006 Annual Review of Ecology, Evolution, and Systematics; Bravo-Cuevas et al. 2013 Revista Mexicana de Ciencias Geologicas
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ruminants possess complex foregut digestive systems that are highly efficient at breaking down cellulose and lignin. However, passage to the stomach and intestine, where nutrients are absorbed, is slowed by this very thorough process. This puts chokepoint on their food consumption rates, increases retention length, and increases their need for high-nutrient low-fiber food items. For example, a bovid requires higher nutrient and lower fiber food than a similar sized hindgut fermenting species.
Habitat.Method: Observed low sample size (1-5) habitat use; Inferred from absence of evidence
Habitat.Notes: No evidence that this species, or any relative, substantially uses arboreal or aquatic habitats
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Common.Name: Asian Ostrich
Mass.Method: Inferred from relative of suggested similar size
Mass.Notes: We assume its size was similar to that of Struthio camelus
Diet.Notes: No empirical information found, but likely similar to the diet of S. camelus, of which S. asiaticus is sometimes treated as a subspecies.
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ostriches possess a horse-like functional digestive morphology with an enlarged colon and caecum, and indeed possess fatty acid production rates comparable to many wild African herbivores (Sales 2006). It should be noted that all ratites lack crops (Sales 2006)
Fermentation.Type.Reference: Sales 2006 Avian and Poultry Biology Reviews
Limb.Morphology.Notes: Ostriches are the only birds with two-toed feet, likely an adaption to cursoriality.
Habitat.Notes: Ostriches are terrestrial animals of open, arid habitats. The Asian ostrich roamed the Indian subcontinent up to southern Siberia.
Habitat.Reference: Birds of the World 2020 Cornell Lab of Ornithology

Common.Name: Ostrich
Mass.Notes: This estimate is based on 13 individuals of unknown sex. We collected this value from Dunning 2008 CRC Handbook of Avian Body Masses. This book is a collection of published literature about bird masses and is not the primary source of these estimates.
Mass.Reference: Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; Dunning 2008 CRC Handbook of Avian Body Masses
Diet.Notes: Ostriches are generalist herbivores that prefer green grasses and forbs, but will switch to consume leaves, flowers, and fruits of succulents and woody plants during the dry season (Milton et al. 1994) Ostriches in the Namib desert will pluck entire grasses out of the ground, apparently capable of digesting their abrasive roots in their gizzards, which unlike mammalian teeth will not wear out from consuming such abrasive food stuffs (Williams et al. 1993).
Diet.Reference: Birds of the World 2020 Cornell Lab of Ornithology; Williams et al. 1993 Ecology; Milton et al. 1994 The Journal of Wildlife Management;
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ostriches possess a horse-like functional digestive morphology with an enlarged colon and caecum, and indeed possess fatty acid production rates comparable to many wild African herbivores (Sales 2006).  It should be noted that all ratites lack crops (Sales 2006)
Fermentation.Type.Reference: Sales 2006 Avian and Poultry Biology Reviews
Limb.Morphology.Notes: Ostriches are the only birds with two-toed feet, likely an adaption to cursoriality.
Habitat.Notes: Ostriches are terrestrial animals of open, arid habitats.
Habitat.Reference: Birds of the World 2020 Cornell Lab of Ornithology

Common.Name: Somali ostrich
Mass.Notes: Similar sized to S. camelus, but trending slightly smaller. In domestic conditions average at 105 kg. The source provides no reference.
Diet.Notes: No empirical information found, but likely similar to the diet of S. camelus, of which S. molybdophanes is sometimes treated as a subspecies.
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Ostriches possess a horse-like functional digestive morphology with an enlarged colon and caecum, and indeed possess fatty acid production rates comparable to many wild African herbivores (Sales 2006).  It should be noted that all ratites lack crops (Sales 2006)
Fermentation.Type.Reference: Sales 2006 Avian and Poultry Biology Reviews
Limb.Morphology.Notes: Ostriches are the only birds with two-toed feet, likely an adaption to cursoriality.
Habitat.Notes: Ostriches are terrestrial animals of open, arid habitats.
Habitat.Reference: Birds of the World 2020 Cornell Lab of Ornithology

Common.Name: Palawan Bearded Pig
Mass.Notes: Comparison species is Sus barbatus
Diet.Notes: Little empirical information. Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 surmise that its diet is similar to the bearded pig of Borneo (S. barbatus), which consists of roots, fungi, invertebrates, and many plants, particularly fruit.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Hindgut colon fermenting species sacrifice fermentation efficiency (e.g. completeness) for rate of passage. Cell-walls are only partially digested, but without the chokepoint provided by the rumen, they can continually consume vegetation thus meeting their nutrient demands. As such they are also able to consume lower-quality vegetation.
Fermentation.Type.Reference: Hume 2002 Acta Zoologica Sinica; Meijaard and Groves 2002 Asian Wild Pig News
Habitat.Notes: This species occurs in primary and secondary forests, from lands to mid-montane rainforests as well as drier open woodlands and grasslands. No indication of aquatic habitat usage.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Common.Name: Bearded Pig
Mass.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World
Diet.Notes: Consumate generalists of nearly anything. Wilson and Mittermeier 2011: 'It is almost easier to state what they will not eat'. However, the documented vegetation is principally browse or fruit or nut mast. They likely consume some graminoids, but given their habitat they are likely primarily browsers.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Hindgut colon fermenting species sacrifice fermentation efficiency (e.g. completeness) for rate of passage. Cell-walls are only partially digested, but without the chokepoint provided by the rumen, they can continually consume vegetation thus meeting their nutrient demands. As such they are also able to consume lower-quality vegetation.
Fermentation.Type.Reference: Hume 2002 Acta Zoologica Sinica; Meijaard and Groves 2002 Asian Wild Pig News
Habitat.Notes: A habitat generalist but with preference for swamp forests, according to Pacini and Harper 2008. Herds of up to 3,000 individuals will make periodic migrations (every 2-4 years) where they swim across rivers and even into the ocean. During the rainy season they may move out of swampland habitats onto higher ground. Wilson and Mittermeier describe them more generally, as using lowland and hill forests, riverbanks, estuarine swamps, secondary forests, beaches, plantations, all sorts of plantations. They appear to move to track fruiting events. Given that aquatic habitat usage is opportunistic, we will mark this as a 0 for aquatic.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; Pacini and Harper 2008 Tropical stream ecology

Mass.Method: Inferred from relative of suggested similar size
Mass.Notes: Comparison species unknown. Not specified in Faurby et al. 2018
Diet.Notes: No empirical evidence found.
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Hindgut colon fermenting species sacrifice fermentation efficiency (e.g. completeness) for rate of passage. Cell-walls are only partially digested, but without the chokepoint provided by the rumen, they can continually consume vegetation thus meeting their nutrient demands. As such they are also able to consume lower-quality vegetation.
Fermentation.Type.Reference: Hume 2002 Acta Zoologica Sinica; Meijaard and Groves 2002 Asian Wild Pig News
Habitat.Method: Inferred from Genus; Inferred from absence of evidence
Habitat.Notes: No evidence of aquatic habitat use in this species or extant relatives
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Common.Name: Heude's pig
Mass.Notes: Trait assumed similar to Sus scrofa.
Diet.Notes: Trait assumed similar to Sus scrofa. Wild boar consume almost anything: browse, nuts, seeds, fruit, carrion, animals, tubers, roots, and some grass.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Ballari and Barrios Garcia 2014 Mammal Review
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Trait assumed similar to Sus scrofa. Hindgut colon fermenting species sacrifice fermentation efficiency (e.g. completeness) for rate of passage. Cell-walls are only partially digested, but without the chokepoint provided by the rumen, they can continually consume vegetation thus meeting their nutrient demands. As such they are also able to consume lower-quality vegetation.
Fermentation.Type.Reference: Hume 2002 Acta Zoologica Sinica; Meijaard and Groves 2002 Asian Wild Pig News
Limb.Morphology.Notes: Trait assumed similar to Sus scrofa.
Habitat.Notes: Trait assumed similar to Sus scrofa. An extreme generalist of forests, scrublands, agricultural landscapes, river systems, and mountains. It apparently reaches high densities in oak forests, as it feeds on mast. No indication of significant aquatic habitat usage.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Common.Name: Visayan Warty Pig
Mass.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World
Diet.Notes: Very rare and elusive in the wild. Some scats and foraging sign indicates that they consume browse and fruits, as well as carrion and small animals.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Hindgut colon fermenting species sacrifice fermentation efficiency (e.g. completeness) for rate of passage. Cell-walls are only partially digested, but without the chokepoint provided by the rumen, they can continually consume vegetation thus meeting their nutrient demands. As such they are also able to consume lower-quality vegetation.
Fermentation.Type.Reference: Hume 2002 Acta Zoologica Sinica; Meijaard and Groves 2002 Asian Wild Pig News
Habitat.Notes: This species formerly occurred from sea level to 1600 m, but with the loss of lower elvatio forests, they are now confined to the few remaining forested habitats at around 800 m. Require dense cover. No evidence of aquatic habitat use.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Common.Name: Sulawesi Warty Pig
Mass.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World
Diet.Notes: Sulawesi warty pigs consume a variety of roots, fallen fruit, leaves, and shoots, supplemented with invertebrates and small vertebrates, and carrion. No quantitative studies known. Wilson and Mittermeier mention an observation of them consuming grasses, noting that this is unlike babirusas.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Hindgut colon fermenting species sacrifice fermentation efficiency (e.g. completeness) for rate of passage. Cell-walls are only partially digested, but without the chokepoint provided by the rumen, they can continually consume vegetation thus meeting their nutrient demands. As such they are also able to consume lower-quality vegetation.
Fermentation.Type.Reference: Hume 2002 Acta Zoologica Sinica; Meijaard and Groves 2002 Asian Wild Pig News
Habitat.Notes: A habitat generalist occurring in rainforests, grasslands, swamps, and agricultural areas. Will show up in high elevation 'moss forests', but prefers valleys. No evidence of aquatic habitat usage.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Common.Name: Oliver's Warty Pig
Mass.Notes: Comparison species is Sus cebifrons
Diet.Notes: No empirical evidence found.
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Hindgut colon fermenting species sacrifice fermentation efficiency (e.g. completeness) for rate of passage. Cell-walls are only partially digested, but without the chokepoint provided by the rumen, they can continually consume vegetation thus meeting their nutrient demands. As such they are also able to consume lower-quality vegetation.
Fermentation.Type.Reference: Hume 2002 Acta Zoologica Sinica; Meijaard and Groves 2002 Asian Wild Pig News
Habitat.Method: Observed low sample size (1-5) habitat use; Inferred from absence of evidence
Habitat.Notes: Little is known about this species, but have been observed thick forest thickets.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Common.Name: Philippine Warty Pig
Mass.Notes: Comparison species is Sus cebifrons
Diet.Notes: No empirical evidence found.
Fermentation.Type.Notes: Hindgut colon fermenting species sacrifice fermentation efficiency (e.g. completeness) for rate of passage. Cell-walls are only partially digested, but without the chokepoint provided by the rumen, they can continually consume vegetation thus meeting their nutrient demands. As such they are also able to consume lower-quality vegetation.
Fermentation.Type.Reference: Hume 2002 Acta Zoologica Sinica; Meijaard and Groves 2002 Asian Wild Pig News
Habitat.Notes: Formerly abundant across habitat types, this species now occurs primarily in remote forests, including montane forests. Formerly in lowland rainforests. No indication of aquatic habitat usage.
Habitat.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Common.Name: Wild Boar
Diet.Notes: Wild boar consume almost anything: browse, nuts, seeds, fruit, carrion, animals, tubers, roots, and some grass.
Diet.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Ballari and Barrios Garcia 2014 Mammal Review
